SPEECH.PARA: CORPORATIONS LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1995

This Bill proposes amendments in the light of a recent court decision that has jeopardised the viability of the voluntary administration scheme under Part 5.3A of the Corporations Law, which commenced operation in June 1993.

Part 5.3A of the Corporations Law provides a regime for companies to enter voluntary administration as an alternative to liquidation. It is an extremely popular method of dealing with companies in financial difficulty. The scheme allows a company in financial difficulty to enter into a deed of company arrangement with its creditors. This enables the company to continue trading for a period with a view to producing some return for creditors, rather than being wound up immediately.

The advantage of taking this course from a creditor's perspective is that if the company is allowed to continue operating its business, there is a likelihood that a better return to creditors will be obtained than if the company is liquidated immediately. The mechanism also serves to avoid the costs and delays often associated with liquidations.

Statistics published by the Australian Securities Commission and industry bodies show that the voluntary administration scheme is an increasingly popular means of dealing with corporate financial difficulties. In a significant proportion of cases, companies enter into deeds of company arrangement with their creditors, rather than proceeding directly to winding up, in an effort to save the company, or at least its business.

In some cases, after a period of trading under a deed of company arrangement, it will become apparent that the continued trading of the company will not be successful. In that case, the creditors are permitted to have the company liquidated immediately. The Corporations Law provides for an automatic transition to a creditors' voluntary winding up in this regard.

In June this year, His Honour Mr Justice Cohen of the New South Wales Supreme Court held in Re Crawford House Press Pty Ltd (1995) 13 ACLC 874; (1995) 17 ACSR 295 that where persons deal with a company under a deed of company arrangement and that company moves into liquidation, those persons may not make a claim in the winding up for any outstanding liabilities of the company in relation to those dealings. His Honour remarked that this is not a result that could have been intended by the legislature and therefore called for urgent legislative amendment.
In the wake of the Crawford House decision, there have been calls for urgent legislative amendment, particularly from practitioners in the insolvency area.

As this matter is of such importance to ongoing and future voluntary administrations, the Government has moved swiftly to introduce a Bill which contains amendments to overcome the apparent anomaly in the Corporations Law.
Content of the Bill

The Bill contains only two substantive amendments to the Corporations Law. The first is designed to ensure that debts and claims arising while a company is under a deed of company arrangement are admissible to proof in a subsequent winding up. The second is intended to protect the validity of acts of liquidators who admitted such debts and claims on the basis that they were provable, prior to commencement of the amendments in the Bill.
Financial impact

The Bill is not expected to have any significant financial impact on government or business as the proposed amendments clarify the operation of existing provisions of the Corporations Law and will not result in additional costs. The Explanatory Memorandum describes the potential impact on creditors.
Conclusion

In conclusion, I confirm that, in accordance with the Heads of Agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation, the Ministerial Council on Corporations has been consulted and has given approval for the introduction of the Bill into the Parliament.
STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 1995

This bill will amend the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 has been to implement budget decisions relating to student assistance. The measures will focus the financial help provided by the taxpayer more sharply on those students most in need and improve services to clients and their families.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Austudy and permanent residents who choose not to become Australian citizens

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Austudy program is to assist financially disadvantaged students who are Australian citizens or permanent residents to complete secondary education and gain an initial tertiary qualification.

While substantial, the funds available for Austudy are limited and priorities for their expenditure must be set within overall budgetary constraints. The bill will amend the act so that, from 1 January 1996, Austudy will be targeted to students who have a long term commitment to contributing to the Australian community and who show their commitment by becoming Australian citizens. The decision to take out Australian citizenship will remain a matter of individual choice.

In the usual case, a student who is a permanent resident of australia will be able to receive Austudy until he or she meets the residency requirements for Australian citizenship (which is normally two years after the person is granted permanent resident status) and for one additional year. To be eligible to continue receiving Austudy after that year, the person must, before the end of that year, apply for Australian citizenship and have that application approved by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Students whose applications are approved within the required timeframe, if otherwise eligible, will continue to receive Austudy while they are waiting to attend a citizenship conferral ceremony.

As people may not apply for citizenship in their own right until they are 16 years old, students who have met the residency requirement before they turn 16 will have one year from their 16th birthday to become, or obtain approval to become, an Australian citizen during which time they may be eligible for Austudy. The basic student payment for 16 and 17 olds will be available to permanent residents

PARA.EMPHASIS: Consolidation of income support for secondary students aged 16 and 17

SPEECH.PARA: To continue the process of streamlining government assistance to families, all payments to 16 and 17 year-old secondary students will be administered through the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) from 1 July 1996.
The basic family payment currently paid for 16 and 17 year old secondary students by the Department of Social Security will be replaced by a payment known as the basic student payment.

This will remove the inconvenience of families having to deal with both the Department of Social Security for family payment and DEET for Austudy to establish eligibility for benefits for older student children. It also reflects the government's intention that assistance to young people in this age group is conditional on their participation in education or training.

The basic student payment will be means tested on the student's income and the income of his or her parent or parents. There will also be a family assets test. The income and assets tests thresholds will be similar to those currently applying to the basic family payment.

The basic student payment will be a maximum of $500 a year. It will be paid in two instalments of $250 (maximum). In most cases these payments will be made in January and July of the year of study to the student's nominated parent or approved care organisation.

Arrangements will be put in place for students who, on 30 June 1996, are 16 or 17 and eligible for the basic family payment to transfer to the basic student payment on 1 July 1996. Students who turn 16 on or after 1 July 1996 and who have been eligible for the basic family payment immediately before they turn 16, will transfer to the basic student payment on their 16th birthday.
The bill includes a number of consequential amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 to abolish family payment for children 16 years and over.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Changes to the Austudy/Abstudy supplement scheme

SPEECH.PARA: The Austudy/Abstudy supplement scheme is a loan scheme under which tertiary students can forgo part or all of their Austudy or Abstudy benefits up to a maximum of $3,500 a year for an interest-free loan of twice the amount of benefits forgone, that is, up to $7,000 a year.

Students who have already received Austudy or Abstudy at the time of application may maximise the amount of supplement they are able to receive by forgoing some, or all, of those benefits previously paid. However, under the existing arrangements this must be done by specified cut off dates of 31 May (for benefits received during the period from 1 January to 31 May) or 30 September (for benefits received during the period from 1 July to 30 September).

This bill proposes to abolish these cut off dates so that students can trade Austudy or Abstudy benefits at any time before the end of their eligibility period. The student therefore will be able to take the maximum amount of supplement to which he/she is entitled at a time of their own choosing. This will mean that a student who applies late in the eligibility period will be able to obtain a greater amount of supplement than under the existing arrangements. The amendments will take effect from 1 January 1996.

Supplement loans are also available to a second category of students. Dependent tertiary students who meet all the criteria for Austudy or Abstudy apart from the parental income test are able to obtain a loan of up to $2,000 a year if their parents' "adjusted income" is under $50,850.

Only a small number of students have chosen to take up this option. The government has decided, therefore, that, from 1 January 1996, loans for students from families with parental income above the Austudy or Abstudy limits will no longer be available. This is consistent with the government's commitment to target assistance to those in greatest need. The bill includes amendments to give effect to this decision.
Students from low income families who are eligible for Austudy or Abstudy will not be affected by this change. These students will continue to have access to supplement loans of up to $7,000 a year.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Penalty for failure to notify a change in circumstances

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, currently a person who is in receipt of benefits under the act is obliged to tell the department, within seven days of their occurrence certain events that may affect the level of benefit being paid. In some circumstances, a failure to do so could lead to a person being imprisoned for up to twelve months.
The government has decided to increase the amount of time a person has to tell the department of such events from seven to fourteen days. It has also decided to remove the criminal offence.

However, it still remains important that the department becomes aware of changes in the circumstances of a person receiving a benefit, because it could mean that a person is receiving more benefit than the legal entitlement.

Therefore, in place of the criminal sanction, the bill inserts a provision that makes a person liable for a penalty of ten dollars for each week, or part of a week , up to a maximum of one thousand dollars. Where the person fails to inform the department within 14 days of an event which affects eligibility.

Failure to notify changes in circumstances is now the most significant factor contributing to the size of student assistance debt. It is hoped that this change will encourage the earlier reporting of changes and will ultimately reduce the level of student indebtedness.

The bill includes an amendment to omit reference to the Austudy and Abstudy Dependent Spouse Allowance (DSA) which is necessary because of the government's decision to abolish this allowance. From 1 January 1996, clients in respect of whom the DSA would have been payable will be able to apply for the parenting allowance provided by the Department of Social Security.
The bill also proposes a number of other minor amendments to the act. These are explained in this bill's explanatory memorandum.
Overall, these measures build on progressive improvements to Austudy client services in recent years to reinforce the government's commitment to assist students in greatest need.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: SUPERANNUATION INDUSTRY (SUPERVISION) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995
Mr President, superannuation is the central pillar of the government's strategy to boost retirement incomes and raise national savings.

As a result of government reforms, most working Australians are now covered by superannuation. Regular contributions being made today will generate higher retirement incomes in the future. And, the growth of superannuation savings is encouraged by generous tax concessions.

The government's decision to promote superannuation brings important responsibilities for the financial sector. Financial institutions and advisers must explain the benefits of long term investment in a diversified portfolio. To encourage the industry to take a longer term view on investments, the government now requires that funds report their average return for the past five years, as well as individual figures for each of those years.
Most importantly, fund managers must justify the government's decision to have superannuation managed in the private sector by investing responsibly and delivering strong fund performance over time.
The government's commitment to improving superannuation coverage and the adequacy of end benefits is matched by an equally strong commitment to enhancing the security of member entitlements.

A sound regulatory framework of `checks and balances' is essential for maintaining public confidence in superannuation and ensuring the long term success of the government's retirement incomes policy.

The government's prudential framework is embodied in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) (or SIS) legislation. Integral components of the SIS regime ensure that fund members have access to both their fund's internal complaints handling arrangements and the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal.
The main purposes of this bill are:
to expand and strengthen the jurisdiction of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal;
to ensure that fund auditors certify that funds comply with certain provisions of the SIS Act and Regulations; and
to transfer various modification orders made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner into the body of the SIS Act.
I would now like to expand on each of these elements of the bill.
The government set up the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal last year to provide fund members with low cost, informal and speedy dispute resolution.

The tribunal has made good progress in its first year. In the 12 months ending June 1995, the tribunal received a total of 416 written complaints that were within its jurisdiction. Around a quarter of these were resolved, with the balance still in the statutory-based inquiry and conciliation phases as at the end of the financial year.

Unfortunately, the tribunal has been subject to some criticism relating to the statutory limits on its jurisdiction. These limits have caused a large number of complaints to be excluded by the tribunal on the grounds that they could not be handled under existing legislative constraints.
Included amongst these were complaints about disability benefits involving the assessment of medical evidence and certain complaints about life office superannuation products.
This bill aims to improve the effectiveness of the tribunal by clarifying and strengthening its jurisdiction over these kinds of complaints.

Complaints about disability claims are set to be handled by the tribunal from 1 November 1995 when the regulation excluding the consideration of `medical evidence' expires. This bill will enhance the effectiveness of the tribunal handling medical evidence complaints in two important ways.

First, it will protect the members of funds that arrange disability cover through an external insurer, by enabling the tribunal to make orders directly against that insurer. This means funds will not face the unfunded liabilities which could otherwise arise where a fund is ordered to pay a disability benefit that has been rejected by its external insurer.

Secondly, the bill puts in place various time limits to prevent the tribunal being swamped with intractable `old' disability complaints where the trail of medical evidence has gone cold. That is, where the illness or injury which led to a claim may have been obscured by subsequent complications or a new condition.

Broadly, the tribunal will not be able to consider complaints about disability claims decided by fund trustees before 1 November 1994. Given that I announced the tribunal would deal with `medical evidence' complaints in October 1994, the amendments are essentially prospective.

To further enhance the tribunal's efficiency in this area, the government will also support the development of `best practice' guidelines for disability claims handling by the superannuation industry. The peak industry associations are consulting closely with the tribunal and Insurance & Superannuation Commission to develop these guidelines, which will be published by way of a Circular. Although compliance with these guidelines will be voluntary, it is expected that they will promote better decision-making by funds and insurers thereby minimising the volume of `medical evidence' complaints to the tribunal.

With regard to life office superannuation, it was always the government's intention that the tribunal should have coverage over all superannuation products, including those offered by life offices. Unfortunately, the legislation did not give full or certain effect to this intention and the tribunal has been unable to effectively deal with a common source of complaint, namely, allegations about life office agent misrepresentation.

The bill rectifies this problem by enabling the tribunal to deal with complaints about superannuation-related annuity products and life office agent misrepresentation. Where the sale of a life office superannuation policy was unfair or unreasonable, the bill enables the tribunal to order the cancellation, variation or repayment of the policy.

The amendments to cover life office superannuation are fully prospective, in that the tribunal's new jurisdiction will apply only to life products purchased after Royal Assent. People with complaints about life products purchased before that date can pursue their concerns through the life industry complaints scheme, as at present.

The government recognises that life offices have a strong presence in the highly competitive retail superannuation market and that allegations of life agent misrepresentation have been a source of particular concern. However, they are not the only public offer superannuation providers, and it is important that all market players are treated equally before the tribunal, to the extent that this is appropriate and practicable. To this end, further amendments will be made at the earliest opportunity in 1996 to ensure that, as far as possible, the new remedies for sale misconduct are extended to all public offer superannuation providers and intermediaries.

Expanding the tribunal's jurisdiction through the amendments in this bill will add considerably to the tribunal's operational workload. In anticipation of this, the bill provides for the creation of a new full-time Deputy Chairperson position and two additional part-time members. Together with the recent upgrading of the tribunal's secretariat, these measures demonstrate the government's strong commitment to ensuring that the tribunal is able to fulfil its charter.

The government has carefully examined the High Court decision of Brandy v Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission & others, handed down in February this year, and is satisfied that the existing legislation and the proposed amendments will not involve the tribunal exercising judicial power.
The second main element of the bill is amendments to enhance the prudential supervision of the superannuation industry.
The bill amends the SIS Act to require that fund trustees arrange for a qualified auditor to carry out yearly `compliance audits'.

A fund's auditor will be required to certify that the fund complies with certain requirements of the SIS Act and Regulations. The trustee is then required to pass on that report to the Insurance & Superannuation Commission.

This external check builds on existing audit requirements in the SIS regime. Auditors are already required to sign off on a fund's financial statements. They are also subject to whistleblower provisions which force auditors to report suspected breaches of the law to the ISC.

The tougher audit rules are supplemented by the ISC's own program of audits to check that funds comply with prudential rules and are run in the best interests of fund members. The ISC conducted nearly 800 fund audits around Australia in 1994/95.
Taken together, these measures will help protect the interests of fund members.
The bill transfers into the SIS Act various modification orders made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner under Part 29 of the act.

Many of these modification orders that are being transferred are temporary orders expiring on 30 June 1996. Accordingly, unless they are transferred into the body of the SIS Act they will cease to have effect on that date causing substantial disruption to industry.

The modification orders are generally made to deal with transitional or technical problems in the legislation which are having unintended effects on industry. They provide an avenue for the Commissioner to appropriately respond to such problems in the interim period before Parliamentary amendments to the legislation can be made.
The modification orders being transferred relate to a number of varied matters and their inclusion in the body of the SIS Act will improve the clarity and effectiveness of the legislation.

The transfer of these modification orders into the SIS Act reflects the government's belief that modification orders made by the Commissioner should be incorporated into the body of the act at the earliest possible opportunity.

Turning to financial implications, the bill provides for the creation of a deputy chairperson and two part time members of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal to deal with the increased workload the tribunal will have. In a full year, the cost of these positions is estimated to be about $270,000.

In addition, a further resource bid will be brought forward for consultation as required with the Department of Finance, in the additional estimates process. The full ongoing year cost of the bid is expected to be of the order of $500,000. Further `one-off' costs, including a new case management system, would be a further $210,000.

In conclusion, superannuation has a vital role to play in Australia's economic future. This bill demonstrates the government's commitment to ensuring that there is a strong and effective supervisory framework for superannuation. The amendments will improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the ISC and Superannuation Complaints Tribunal and consequently protect member entitlements and maintain public confidence in the superannuation system.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CARER PENSION AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1995

Earlier this year the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Family Measures) Bill 1995 was introduced. That bill provided for the implementation of initiatives announced in the 1995 budget that responded not only to the particular needs that families with children have at certain times, but also to making the system simpler and more consistent.

The government recognises, however, that it is essential for the Australian social security system to be responsive to the needs of all groups in the Australian community. To that end, the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill 1995 serves to give legislative effect to a wide range of 1995 budget initiatives.
One group of 1995 budget initiatives will mean a better deal for people caring for others in the community, as well as for those receiving care.

First, the bill will ensure that a person who cares for another person may qualify for a carer pension even if the caree is not in receipt of a social security or veterans' affairs pension or a social security benefit. A person whose family income and assets are less than $61,020 and $559,250, respectively, will be able to have someone on carer pension look after them. These limits will rise in line with the family payment income and assets tests. Carers will, of course, have to meet all other existing qualification criteria for carer pension.

Secondly, from July 1996 it will no longer be a qualification requirement for carer pension that the carer live in the same or an adjacent house to the person receiving care. As long as they provide the necessary level of care, it will not matter where the carer lives.

Thirdly, from March 1996, carers will also continue to get carer pension for a further 14 weeks following the admission of a care recipient to a nursing home, unlike current arrangements where qualification ceases as soon as the person being cared for permanently enters a nursing home. This period of payment will give carers time to adjust and look for work or meet the requirements of other income support payments.
The bill also ensures that the same beneficial arrangements for people in nursing homes will be available for people being cared for in the community.

From March 1996, if a person receiving care moves into the home of their carer, the care recipient's former home will be disregarded under the assets test for two years. Similarly, a carer's former home will not count as an asset for two years if they move into the home of the person for whom they are caring. In addition, from March 1996, rent assistance will be immediately available to a social security recipient who must leave their home to be cared for by somebody in the community, or to care for someone.
A further group of initiatives contained in this bill relates to rent assistance. Rent assistance is a supplement for people who are in the private rental market.
First, from March 1996, the maximum rates of rent assistance will increase by $5 per fortnight for families with children.

Secondly, rent thresholds will increase by $5 per fortnight to coincide with the March 1996 CPI increase. This will allow better targeting of assistance to rent assistance recipients who pay relatively higher rents.

There are currently a number of rent assistance recipients who are `saved' at beneficial rates of rent assistance equal to the amount they received prior to rent assistance reforms in 1989 and 1993. This results in their receiving a higher rate of income support than similar recipients assessed under the current provisions. The bill provides that, from March 1996, any CPI increases in the total social security entitlements of these `saved' recipients will reduce their `saved' rate of rent assistance until the `saved' rate equates with the normal current rate of rent assistance.

The bill also provides for the payment, from January 1997, of a new residential care allowance. This new indexed allowance will replace rent assistance for residents of nursing homes and hostels. Residential care allowance will be paid at the same rate, and be subject to the same threshold, indexation and all other arrangements, as currently apply to rent assistance.

Social security pensioners with little or no other income apart from their pension, are often unable to access lump sum amounts to help meet living or capital expenses such as emergency replacement of household equipment and car repairs.

This bill will help recipients of some social security pensions and benefits by allowing a lump sum advance of a person's payment. The maximum advance available will be the lesser of $500 or 6 per cent of one year's pension payments and will be repayable by deductions from ongoing fortnightly pension payments over 13 fortnights. Advances will be made only to persons with the ability to manage financially on a reduced payment for the duration of the repayment period. A person will be able to increase the amount of deductions for early repayment or apply to have deductions reduced in times of hardship.

In addition to the measures contained in the Social Security Legislation (Family Measures) Amendment Bill 1995 and the special rent assistance measure for families described earlier, sole parents receiving guardian allowance will be paid an extra $4 per fortnight from September 1996.

Families will also benefit from other measures announced in the 1995 budget. These measures provide for the simplification of the application and assessment process for family payment and child care assistance, including combining the child care assistance and family payment annual review processes and better aligning the definitions for child care assistance and family payment. Ongoing entitlement to child care assistance and family payment will be able to be reassessed at the same time. There will be increased emphasis on child care assistance compliance, through the introduction of family compliance reviews, including data-matching and risk based interviews. The bill will authorise data-matching activity, from 1 January 1996, in relation to the information provided to the Department of Social Security for determining whether child care assistance should be paid to a person, to ensure that the information is accurate and consistent with information provided by the person to other Commonwealth agencies.

The Data-matching Program is conducted under the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990. The Data-matching act was originally given two years of operation, with a sunset clause to take effect in January 1993. Although the government later attempted on two occasions to have the sunset clause repealed, the Parliament decided to extend its operation for a finite term. Unless amended, the Data-matching Act will operate until January 1996.

After four years of operation, the government considers that the Data-matching Program has achieved, and will continue to achieve, substantial savings in public expenditure. It is an important control on personal financial assistance schemes, helping to keep them free of abuse and fraud. Accordingly, one of the amendments proposed by this bill to the Data-matching Act provides for the repeal of the sunset clause.

Another amendment in this bill relates to departure certificates. Specifically, a departure certificate is required for all social security pensioners who leave Australia and, currently, pensioners who remain absent from Australia for more than six months without a departure certificate have their pensions cancelled automatically. Pension may only be re-granted when the pensioner returns to Australia.
The harshness of the departure certificate provisions has created concern and some complaints.

New arrangements to be implemented by this bill will mean that pensioners who leave Australia without obtaining a departure certificate will have their pensions suspended, rather than cancelled, after they have been absent for a period of six months. Pension will not be cancelled until the pensioner has been absent from Australia for twelve months.

A review form will be sent to their last known address and pension will be restored, with full arrears, if the review form is returned within three months of its issue and the person still qualifies for pension. In cases where the review form is returned more than three months after its issue, but before the anniversary of the pensioner's date of departure from Australia, pension will be restored from the date of return of the form only, with no arrears being payable.

The Secretary to the Department of Social Security will have the discretion to restore pension, with full arrears, up to two years from the pensioner's date of departure from Australia, in circumstances when being able to comply with procedures, was beyond the pensioner's control.

With a view to providing for more certainty in decision making and alleviating concerns about recovery for a small number of debtors whose circumstances warrant leniency, this bill proposes amendments to the waiver provisions in the Social Security Act 1991 to:
clarify that part of a debt may be waived in appropriate circumstances;
provide for general recovery of debts over $50 where recovery can be effected by withholdings from social security payments;
provide for decisions on recovery of debts to be put on the same basis as commercial decisions about present values;
provide for negotiated settlements in the administrative appeals process in addition to through civil action;
provide for non-recovery of debts where there are special circumstances (within certain limitations) that would make recovery inequitable; and
provide for waiver where a person has a notional entitlement to parenting allowance.
The bill also makes a number of non-budget portfolio amendments to social security and associated legislation.

A payment received by a trainee in part-time training in a Labour Force Program currently is not taken into account as income for the purposes of the Social Security Act, if the trainee is also receiving a social security or service pension.

Amendments in this bill expand this exemption from the definition of income to include a payment made to a trainee in part-time training or work experience under a Labour Market Program where the trainee is receiving a social security benefit or youth training allowance and the payment is made to cover expenses associated with participation in the training or work experience.

The bill amends the waiting period provisions relevant to job search allowance, newstart allowance and sickness allowance to allow any part of a particular waiting period already served by a person to be transferable across payment types.
The bill also makes a number of further amendments to sickness allowance.

The qualification conditions for sickness allowance for certain 15 year olds will be modified in two ways. First, clients who are independent of their parents' or other adult financial support will qualify for sickness allowance without having to meet the work history or 13 week CES registration elements of qualification. Secondly, clients who live at home with a parent who is receiving a social security pension or benefit, a service pension or certain education payments will be able to access sickness allowance if they can establish a work history or job offer.

Qualification for sickness allowance is generally limited to two years. The two year preclusion period does not apply if incapacity for work is caused by a different or more serious medical condition or by relapse of a chronic condition or by the fact that the person is undergoing a program of counselling, treatment or therapy for drug or alcohol abuse. The bill amends the Social Security Act so that, in addition to the above exception, the two year preclusion period does not apply if a person's incapacity for work is caused by a medical condition and the person is awaiting surgery that is expected to improve the person's condition within two years from the date on which the person was re-granted sickness allowance.

The bill also removes the requirement for a medical practitioner to indicate whether a social security recipient's condition is likely to improve if that person receives treatment or undertakes a rehabilitation program, as it is considered that the requirement is not essential to determining qualification for, or payability of, sickness allowance.

Further, in relation to sickness allowance, amendments are made to allow the liquid assets test waiting period to be waived in hardship cases. This will align sickness allowance with waiver provisions that already exist in relation to job search allowance, newstart allowance and youth training allowance.
The bill amends sole parent and sole parent special needs provisions in the Social Security Act to clarify those situations where a person is obliged to pursue maintenance.
As well, the bill includes two categories of amendments relating to bereavement allowance.

The bill amends the bereavement provisions for carer pension to provide that bereavement payments will be paid to a person who ordinarily receives carer pension when the person who they care for, dies during respite care.

The provisions that deal with special short term bereavement payments for family payment, child disability allowance and double orphan pension are amended to ensure that the four week bereavement period commences on the day after the child's death.

The Social Security Act provides protection of ongoing social security pensions and benefits from garnishee action. This same protection is to be extended to a number of one-off or lump sum social security payments that have been introduced in the last few years, such as the employment entry payment and advance payments of job search allowance.

The bill clarifies the conditions under which a person's social security pension, benefit or allowance will cease to be payable due to the person's failure to nominate a bank account into which the person's social security payments are to be made. A person may be paid a social security payment up to 28 days from the day the person becomes entitled to the payment. The person then has three months from the date the payment ceases to be payable to nominate an account. If the person nominates an account within three months then arrears are payable. If the person nominates after three months, arrears may only be paid from the date on which the nomination was made.

Other amendments made by this bill meet an undertaking previously given by the government during the second reading debate on the Social Security (Parenting Allowance and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Act 1994, that amendments would be made to the Social Security Act to draw attention to the ability to `convert' an imprisonment term to a monetary penalty via the operation of the penalty units scheme in the Crimes Act 1914. Similar amendments are also made to the Farm Household Support Act 1992.
The bill makes some minor amendments relating to compensation recovery.

In this regard, it clarifies the situation that when a person's entitlement to periodic compensation payments under a law of a State or Territory is converted into an entitlement to a lump sum and it is calculated by reference to a period, the person is considered to have received in each fortnight during the period, a periodic compensation payment equal to the lump sum divided by the number of fortnights in the period.

The bill addresses too the situation of a person receiving a compensation affected payment under the Social Security Act who receives a lump sum compensation payment and whose partner is qualified for a compensation affected payment under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. In that case, the smaller of the compensation part of the lump sum or the amount obtained by adding the compensation affected payments made under the Social Security Act and the pension payments made under the Veterans Entitlements act is recoverable.
The bill also makes a number of minor or technical amendments that, for example, remove superfluous terms from the Social Security Act.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS TARIFF LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995
The Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, which is now before the chamber, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. I will briefly outline the changes of substance.

Schedule 1 is operative from the seventeenth of March 1995 and contains an amendment to item 31 in part II of schedule 4 to the principal act. This concessional item allows the duty free importation of aircraft parts, materials and test equipment for use in the manufacture, repair or maintenance of aircraft with the exception of goods used in the servicing of aircraft. Following the government's acceptance in 1991 of recommendations contained in Industry Commission report No. 9 on the commercial tariff concession and by-law systems, the terms of item 31 in schedule 4 were revised.
By a broad application of the current conditions, it has been possible to import, duty free, most goods used in aircraft.

The government has now decided to restrict the coverage of this item by excluding textiles and goods made of textiles for use on aircraft. This initiative will remove the competitive advantage previously accorded imported goods over locally sourced goods by the use of item 31. It will also encourage the use of Australian raw textile materials.
Schedule 2 of the bill is operative from the first of April 1995. Customs tariff rates of duty have been subjected to a phasing regime since July 1988.

Blood packs and blood pack systems used for collecting, processing, storing and administering blood and blood components have traditionally been classified by the Australian Customs Service as infusion and transfusion sets for blood and other fluids. They were subject to ten percent duty prior to the first of July 1995, phasing to five percent in 1996.

This classification was successfully challenged in the administrative appeals tribunal with the result that the AAT set aside the customs classification, considering the goods to be properly classified to a duty free item. The immediate removal of the ten percent assistance would have had a detrimental effect on local industry and is not consistent with the intent of the government's tariff phase down programme. This government is aware of the consequences to industry of sudden and large reductions in the level of protection.

This amendment reinstates the intended level of assistance for the subject goods by specifically designating blood packs and blood pack systems used for collecting, processing, storing and administering blood and blood components in the tariff classification that customs originally considered appropriate.

Schedule 3, which is operative from the tenth of May 1995, implements the 1995/1996 federal budget announcement of an increase of ten percent in the customs rate of duty for manufactured tobacco and tobacco products. The previously legislated increase of five percent for these goods planned for August 1995 will now not proceed.

Schedule 4 is operative from the first of July 1995 and contains a number of amendments. The first inserts an additional note in chapter 27 to define "fuel oil". In recent years oil refineries have been producing fuel oils of lower density which are capable of being used in diesel engines. The effect of this note will be to exclude light fuel oils from the new definition of fuel oil and in future those light fuel oils will attract the diesel fuel rate of duty.

Secondly, the rates of customs duty on aviation gasoline are increased by 0.883 cents per litre on aviation kerosene and by 1.847 cents per litre on aviation gasoline. These increases were announced by the treasurer in the 1995/1996 federal budget. The additional revenue will provide funding for aviation safety regulation and be part of the industry's contribution to the recovery of airway services costs attributable to aviation gasoline powered aircraft.

Another change inserts in chapter 73 an additional note to confirm the tariff classification of razor wire. The new additional note implements a decision of the world customs organization that this wire be classified in tariff heading seventy three thirteen.

Schedule 4a is operative on and from the eleventh of October 1995 and contains amendments to the duty arrangements on topped crude petroleum oils. These amendments complement the changes made to fuel oil in schedule 4. Since that amendment, the production of light fuel oil has dropped dramatically.

It has now come to the notice of the Australian Customs Service that production of topped crude petroleum oil has increased significantly since the first of July this year. Further, topped crude oil is being used as a substitute for diesel fuel. Again there exists the potential for a multi-million dollar loss in government revenue

The changes contained in this schedule have the same effect as those implemented for fuel oil. That is, the physical characteristics of fuel oil produced from topped crude petroleum oils are defined in additional note one to chapter twenty seven and a tariff split created for this category of fuel oil. Goods not meeting those specifications have a separate subheading and will attract the higher diesel fuel rate of duty.
Other changes contained in this bill are of an administrative or technical nature and have no duty implications.
Summaries of the amendments contained in this bill have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those of us who were here last week will remember that I had about one minute to commence the second reading debate on the Commonwealth Bank Sale Bill 1995. I made the point then that much of the detail associated with this bill will be dealt with by regulation and the Senate will be forced to play a guessing game in an effort to determine what the real intention of a lot of these critical clauses is. But I have no doubts that during the debate on this bill in the committee stages some of the concerns that have been raised in the other place and here will be clarified.

PARA.TAB: The sale of the Commonwealth Bank has created a lot of division amongst the Labor Party in particular, because the Commonwealth Bank was held up as one of the icons of the Labor Party. The government have taken this very opportunistic step to sell off the rest of the Commonwealth Bank to fill a hole in their budget.

If there was ever any doubt about the disastrous state of our economic position, this bill says it all. The Australia of today has one of the largest deficits in the world. Taxes have increased to unprecedented levels. We are the laughing stock of the world economy—our waterfront obviously is as well, given the criticism over the weekend by international shipping companies.

We know we are a country which has it all. We have got rich resources, natural beauty and skilled workers. Yet we are a country which has continued to slip back under this Labor government. The Treasurer (Mr Willis) has attempted to hoodwink the Australian people into believing that we were going to have a budget surplus of something like $718 million. The real position is that the budget shows a deficit of around $8.5 billion. So this sale of the Commonwealth Bank is a desperate sell-off of the family jewels in order to continue this charade.

The government's record in relation to assets sales mirrors its dismal performance on other counts. The Labor Party has only managed to achieve $5.8 billion, or 53 per cent, of a projected total of $11 billion in sales since 1987-88. We sit back this year and wonder how the government, which only managed to sell $55 million in asset sales last year, will make the quantum leap to sell $5.4 billion in the space of a year.

I have no doubt that this bill is not going to be the final act of deception and double dealing by this government. Make no mistake, this government has an agenda to once again turn its back on its principles, as it does so well. Its aim is to see Telstra and Australia Post both with `for sale' signs in their shopfront windows. The coalition has made it perfectly clear that we have no intention of selling Australia Post, but make no mistake, this government would sell its grandmother in order to stay in office.

I am sure we can all remember the letter which the Minister for Finance at the time, Mr Willis, included in the September 1993 prospectus for the Commonwealth Bank. He said, `The government has no intention of selling the Commonwealth Bank.' That was the assurance that this government gave all those mum and dad investors who were looking to invest their savings in the bank. I have to say that I was one of those people. I wish to declare an interest and say that I am one of the small shareholders who bought into the Commonwealth Bank at that time.
I believe that the government had no intention of selling the Commonwealth Bank, but today, two years later, we see a complete backflip by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —A false prospectus.

—Of course it was a false prospectus. I think that matter was raised at the time, but the minister was protected as a member of the government and nothing happened. I wonder sometimes whether Mr Willis had the same loss of memory that has inflicted other ministers in that other place.

PARA.TAB: Of course this is not the first time that the government has been dishonest. In 1986, when answering a question regarding our airlines, the then Minister for Aviation said:

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure the honourable member that the Government's policy is that both Qantas and Trans Australia Airlines will remain in full public ownership.
That was another Labor lie. It is evident that the minister's word once again meant nothing.

PARA.TAB: In 1991 the government had an electoral platform which promised to ensure that the Federal Airports Corporation remained in full public ownership. Only last week we were debating the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1995 and the Airports Bill 1995, which lay to rest another sacred cow of Labor Party philosophy.

Of course we do not have to think back too far to the sale of ANL. It has not happened yet. We have debated the bill. We procrastinated over it for so long that, instead of the taxpayers getting benefit from the sale, it looks like we are going to get a deficit. It is going to cost us money to sell ANL.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two million dollars a day.

—Thank you, Senator McGauran, $2 million a day. We know Mr Keating admitted on the Lateline program in June of 1994 that it makes no difference if Telstra is publicly or privately owned. There is a little inkling of what might happen further down the track if this Labor government is unfortunately returned to office. We could see Telstra lining up as well.

PARA.TAB: I have no problem whatsoever with the government adopting so willingly the policies of the coalition. We all know that the coalition policies have shown, in Victoria in particular, that asset sales, if properly conducted, can be of benefit in reducing the huge debts that the Labor Party has been running up in both the state of Victoria and also the Commonwealth. But you could argue, of course, that the government is at last starting to see some commonsense by privatising these public assets.

What needs to be remembered is that on every occasion to date that this government has made a firm commitment to do one thing their actions have been completely the opposite. What the government's actions show is that, more than ever, they cannot be trusted. Anyone in the Australian community who believes that the government is interested in, or indeed capable of, telling the truth really should take a long, hard look at the facts. Furthermore, when the government makes its election promises, people would do well to remember the great and long string of broken promises which have come out of the mouths of Labor ministers since the last election.

The reaction of the Commonwealth Bank to the government's plans has from the start been understandably cautious, particularly in relation to the buyback option which has been pushed by the government. The bank sought to ensure that as a precursor there would be an independent examination of shareholders' approvals, that there would be a special resolution under Corporations Law or the Australian Stock Exchange listing rules as considered necessary by the bank board to deal with matters such as any necessary approvals from regulatory authorities, any selective buyback and any necessary amendments to the bank's memorandum and articles of association which remove all special rights to the Commonwealth. The bank also wanted to ensure that there would be agreement on the transition arrangements for the Commonwealth guarantee of the bank's liabilities and that there would be agreement on the future of the Commonwealth Development Bank.

That has most certainly not occurred, and today we are in this chamber debating a bill and I do not believe any of us present can say with any surety what the exact future of the bank is going to be. That position is indefensible. It is indefensible for the government and it pays absolutely no regard whatsoever to those small investors like myself and others who are such a vital component of the bank's structure. The fact that the future of the Commonwealth Development Bank hangs in the balance without any certainty is perhaps the most glaring of the government's failings.

We know the Commonwealth Development Bank is not the bank of the high fliers or the multinationals; it is very much the bank of ordinary Australians, those in small business and those on the land. The importance of the Development Bank is recognised by a special charter in the Commonwealth Banks Act. The main role of this bank is to provide finance where it may not otherwise be available. It is a bank where what is important are cash flows and prospects rather than compulsory security. Its role is very much as its name would suggest, to aid in development.There are hundreds of thousands of farmers around Australia who have at one time or another been forced to use capital from the Commonwealth Development Bank and who still place a very important role on small business, as the minister at the table would know. So the future of the Commonwealth Development Bank is very important and is one of the major concerns that the coalition has.

Under the bill we are debating today, the charter which existed before will no longer be law. We will have to rely instead upon a memorandum of association, which is to be part of the new Commonwealth Development Bank Ltd. The coalition, which is always mindful of the need to support those in small business and on the land, considers the proposed arrangements to be less than satisfactory. Even the explanatory memorandum recognises this fault in the present legislation in that it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill does not define the future role of the Commonwealth Development Bank.
Our very genuine concerns are compounded because the memorandum further states:
The Commonwealth will continue to pay an annual subsidy to the Commonwealth Development Bank to undertake the banking activities defined in its charter.

We have absolutely no idea, however, what the level or type of this subsidy will be. All we have to go on is some vague notion relating to the shareholders agreement which is to be entered into by the Commonwealth and the bank before the transfer occurs.

PARA.TAB: None of this goes anywhere near meeting the requirements of the Commonwealth Bank Board. It may well be that we will see the end of the Commonwealth Development Bank as we know it, and the coalition believes that this will have very serious consequences in denying small business, and the rural community in particular, access to a source of funding which has been critical to their growth over the years. There is, in fact, no guarantee that it will survive because the Commonwealth Bank Board has made it very clear in the past that it relies on the Commonwealth subsidy to successfully carry out the charter—in other words, no subsidy, no development bank.

Item 29 of the schedule to the bill repeals section 85A of the Commonwealth Bank Act, which provides for the grant of financial assistance from the Commonwealth to the Commonwealth Development Bank. Some $41 million will be paid in subsidies by the end of the 1995-96 financial year. However, should that level of funding support be removed from the small business and rural sectors, obviously the effects would be very significant. It is ill conceived to deal with this bill before those matters are finalised.

Because the memorandum can be amended under the Corporations Law, the Commonwealth Development Bank will be left with no option but to put all its loans on a strict commercial basis to the detriment of its existing clients. Because the Commonwealth is now trapped into selling the Commonwealth Bank in order to save any semblance of its budget predictions in the lead-up to the election, it has hatched up a plan to unload onto a privatised Commonwealth Bank a development bank, without any guarantee of subsidy and which, as a result, will have no choice but to place development on a totally commercial basis.

At the end of the day, if the Commonwealth Bank decides to acquire the Commonwealth's shares in the Development Bank, it would be free to close down the operations of the Development Bank on the grounds that it did not consider the subsidy sufficient to meet its financial needs. In order to ensure that the future of the Development Bank is assured, the government must reveal before the parliament the full details of the proposed shareholders agreement and, in particular, it must be up front in regard to a commitment for future subsidies. Any terms associated with the shareholders agreement will also impact on any buyback of shares held by the Commonwealth before the balance of the shares go on sale to the public.

The Commonwealth Bank must inevitably have its funds depleted by the terms of the buyback, and those same funds may well come at the expense of the Development Bank. Such a figure could well approach $1 billion and, without a guarantee that the Commonwealth will continue to support the Development Bank, its future looks even more shaky.

As my colleague in the other place, the member for MacKellar, Mrs Bishop, pointed out, it is totally unsatisfactory that the only time this parliament will see the shareholders agreement is when it is signed—although I now understand that it may be made available before being signed. If that is the case, I will wait to hear the minister give an explanation for it during the committee stage of this bill.

The issue of foreign ownership also requires greater attention by the government. It is clear that the government has learnt little from the Qantas situation and as a result we continue to have in this bill a retrospective approach to dealing with a problem where the limit is exceeded. The coalition will not stand in the way of the second reading. I will move an amendment that raises the concerns that we have, but we certainly will not vote against the second reading. I want to make that clear right now.

The future of the Commonwealth Development Bank must be guaranteed but we must also ensure that it continues to undertake its present role in providing specialised assistance for rural communities and small business. We know that the small business of Australia looks to the coalition for support. A recent Yellow Pages survey shows that they do not trust the Keating government, and you can understand why.

When we discuss this particular development bank and the sale of the Commonwealth Bank we should also consider how the AIDC could be utilised in the role of providing assistance to small business and rural export producers. Greater attention needs to be given to the issue of retrospectivity in the regulations. Finally, there is a need to resolve the issue of the shareholders' meeting—the government was previously of the view that it could be all done by legislation.

Last week when we started debating this bill I distributed a second reading amendment to be moved on behalf of the coalition. As I said, we will not vote against the second reading. I know amendments will be put forward by the Democrats. I will speak to those further during the committee stages. I would like to make it quite clear at the outset that the coalition will not support those amendments purely and simply because we believe they give too much power back to the Treasurer.

After all is said and done, we are trying to sell the Commonwealth Bank into private ownership. Why would we want to then turn around and let the government, through the interference of the Treasurer, have the same degree of involvement in the Commonwealth Development Bank as it previously had in the Commonwealth Bank? I think that would defeat the purpose somewhat. As I said, we will support the bill. I commend our amendment to the house. I look forward to hearing comments from the minister during the committee stage to those queries that I have raised. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
", but that the Senate is of the opinion that:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the role of the Commonwealth Development Bank is ill-defined in the bill, and the Shareholders' Agreement between the Commonwealth Bank and the Commonwealth should be included as a Schedule to the bill; and

(b)the Government should give assurances that any acquisition of property that arises in consequence of the buy-back of shares foreshadowed in the bill will be on just terms under section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution; and

(c)since regulations under the bill, which may under subclause 19(3) have retrospective effect, are yet to be issued and are not clearly spelt out, the Government is once again legislating by regulation".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright Sen T.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few things about the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, although I am very conscious of the pressure of time that is being felt by government senators this week with the degree of government business that we wish to get through. I will be as brief as I can in my remarks.
—You're not the only one on the speakers list from the government.

—I am actually, Senator. You will have to look at the latest one. I think it is certainly time to sell the Commonwealth Bank. It was a very early Labor government which brought the Commonwealth Bank into being. It is entirely appropriate that it is this Labor government which finally pushes it out of the nest.

PARA.TAB: The first tranche of shares were put into the market in 1990. Since then we have also seen a very orderly market in the shares. We have also seen no intervention on the part of the government in the running of the bank. That is entirely appropriate because the bank has to compete on an equal basis with its competitors.

I think it is also worth the Senate remembering that the intervention by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on the subject of fees and charges for individual depositors has been very effective in recent weeks in changing the attitude not only of the Commonwealth Bank, which first proposed that those fees be raised, but also of other banks. I think it is indicative of the fact that in terms of regulation there is very little more that is now needed to ensure an efficient running of the banking system and also a banking system which meets the needs of the community and the needs of its customers.

I do at this juncture want to compare the government's attitude to the selling of the Commonwealth Bank with the opposition's attitude to the selling of Telstra. I think it really does show in stark contrast the difference between the two sides of this Senate on the question of privatisation. The Commonwealth Bank is a mature business in a very mature industry. It has really reached an appropriate level in its development where the amount of change it is going to face in the foreseeable future is far less than that which it has faced in the recent past. On the other hand, Telstra is a fast growing company in a very rapidly changing business sector. It is in the infant industry of communications. It is for that reason, I believe, the government wants to retain Telstra, despite the fact that the opposition wants to sell it.

If we look at what has happened to the Commonwealth Bank and, more particularly, the banking industry over the last few years, we see that the major regulatory changes are behind us. The 1980s were a period of very rapid deregulation in banking, not only in Australia but around the world. All the banks changed—they changed in their attitudes to their customers, they changed in their attitudes to the community in general and they certainly changed in the services they provided and the way in which they operated. The Commonwealth Bank changed with them. There were certainly some mistakes made during that period of change in the 1980s and many lessons were learnt.

I think it is often forgotten that the foreign banks which this government allowed to enter the market during the 1980s bore considerable losses as a result of the mistakes they made—the sort of losses which no Australian would be particularly enthusiastic about Australian banks bearing. But that was the price they were prepared to pay to come into the Australian market and embrace a completely new world.

We have also seen considerable benefits to consumers as a result of the changes of the 1980s. Borrowers have seen the end of the savings book account which paid one or two per cent interest, at the same time as borrowers were required to pay 12 or 13 per cent on their home loans. That gap between borrowing rates and deposit rates closed as a function of the deregulation that we saw in the 1980s.

We have also seen businesses have available to them products which were inconceivable 20 or 30 years ago, and certainly when the Commonwealth Bank was first thought of. These risk management products are based on derivative markets which have seen phenomenal growth. Again, I think we can say they have developed in an orderly fashion, they are at a mature stage now and they are available to all banks and all customers of those banks. The net result has been a Commonwealth Bank which is now more profitable than it has ever been, which is showing a better return on its capital than it ever has, and one which the stock market has given its approval to.

If you contrast that with the telecommunications industry, it is obvious that that industry and the major players in it are still evolving. The growth in that industry is absolute phenomenal. We can hardly imagine now what products will be available to consumers in 10 years or even 15 years time. The rate of change is absolutely extraordinary. At that point, and because of that change, there is still a public interest that has to be protected. To abandon Telstra now is really to say, `We don't really care about the rate of change, we don't care what the products might be and we don't care about the players in that market and what future they might have.'

If you look at what the opposition is doing, the opposition has ummed and ahed about its policy, but I can tell you now, Mr Acting Deputy President, what the opposition's policy is on telecommunications—it is to raise as much money as possible for the next election. The opposition simply wants to sell Telstra because it wants to outbid the government in the coming election campaign. It wants to have a huge sack of money on its side so that it can go into the marketplace and essentially bribe the electorate by saying, `We can outspend those on the other side because we have sold Telstra, and we will use that money for that purpose.'

I was quite elated when Senator Tierney said a policy had actually been announced on telecommunications by the opposition last week. With great enthusiasm I rushed to the faxes but, sadly, I found it only related to a two-line statement by Mr Howard in a speech to the National Farmers Federation. In fact, I can read this policy in its absolute entirety. It was far less than I had hoped for and, indeed, than the public deserves. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Today I announce that a Coalition Government will require Telstra to offer all of its customers who have lines connected to digital exchanges with access to ISDN as a standard service.
We will also require Telstra to substantially complete its FMO or digitisation of exchanges by 1 July 1997, instead of its current year 2000 target date.

How can you suddenly decide to sell Telstra—and, what is more, you are not going to sell Telstra because it is a mature business, you are not going to do it because you think Telstra will provide the best return to the public now, you will do it simply because you want to get as much money as you possibly can for the coming election campaign. The two things are completely contradictory. You cannot talk, as Senator Calvert did, about public interest, what banks should be doing and what the Commonwealth Development Bank might be doing and, in the same breath, say you are going to sell Telstra with the sole aim of getting as much money for it as you possibly can.

PARA.TAB: I think what the government is doing in selling the Commonwealth Bank now is redeploying in a responsible way Commonwealth funds—some $4 1/2 billion, if current share price values hold up—to reduce its borrowings and to maintain a sound fiscal policy. It stands in stark contrast when a government responsibly sees that a government owned entity is at the end of its life, it is in a mature phase and it can take its place in the private market. Compare that with Telstra. We cannot envisage its shape within five or even 10 years time. To sell that purely for the purposes of raising money to fund your election promises, I believe, is irresponsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the extraordinarily important bill which is before the Senate—the Commonwealth Bank Sale Bill. I look forward to voting on this bill with the government and Senator Wheelwright, Senator Carr, Senator Coates, Senator Schacht and all those who have complained over the years that maybe the coalition would sell the Commonwealth Bank. It is a day I look forward to. The sooner we vote on this bill, the better. I assume the Democrats will call for a division and then Senator Wheelwright and I can vote together on this important bill.

PARA.TAB: I heard Senator Wheelwright's complaints about the privatisation of Telstra. That took me back to the Ben Chifley speech given by former Prime Minister Mr Hawke not so long ago. He gave that speech in September 1987. Senator Wheelwright's speech reminded me of that Chifley lecture. Former Prime Minister Hawke said:

SPEECH.PARA: What in the name of reason is the justification for breaking up and selling off the great and efficient national assets, like the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom, TAA and Qantas? As the people of Australia come to realise the extent of the economic and social vandalism proposed by our opponents—

The vandalism that he was talking about included the vandalism of suing the Commonwealth Bank. I can understand why Senator Wheelwright, as a former stockbroker, recognises the potential advantages to a future government in selling Telstra. Most Telecoms around the world are privatised. I would have liked Senator Wheelwright to have addressed the issue of why it is in this great nation of ours that Telecom should remain exclusively in the public sector and not even have a proportion of its shares sold and why it is that other countries have effectively privatised their Telecoms. It would have been interesting if you had grappled with that argument.

PARA.TAB: We have had these scare tactics before. The trouble is that no-one believes you. In Victoria the Labor Party rails against Premier Kennett for this and that. In Canberra we find that the Labor Party is privatising this and that—and there are some big chunks that are being privatised. There was an extraordinary incident the other week when Senator Wheelwright was on our side of the chamber and I was on the opposite side of the chamber and he was voting for the privatisation of Sydney airport. Because of a difficulty, we did not vote together on that particular issue.

In view of his party's record, I would have thought Senator Wheelwright would have been more cautious when going on the record and saying what he did. Your party is a great privatiser despite what it says in elections. The Labor Party does not worry too much about what it says in elections. In the hugely unlikely circumstance that the Labor Party wins an election in the next 10 years or wins the next election, there is no question that the Labor Party would sell Telstra. We would stand up then and quote all the speeches you have made. You would be working out whether or not to come into the chamber and how to distinguish between what you would say then and what you have said now. The Labor Party has no credibility on this issue.

I remember Senator Evans in this chamber boasting. He said, `Now we have sold the Commonwealth Bank, there is nothing left for you to privatise.' He had gone through all of these things the Labor Party had privatised which they said before every election they would not privatise, and then they came back and decided they would.

Senator Wheelwright, I think it has to be said that the contributions you make to this chamber are actually more thoughtful than those of a lot of those made by your colleagues. I do not argue with that. I think your speeches are interesting typically, but on this one I would have to say that you fell dramatically. You should have at least, out of deference to the public interest, explained why the Labor Party had so totally reversed its position—economic vandalism from Mr Hawke one day; responsible government policy from Mr Keating the next. You might all refer to the former Prime Minister as Marcel Marceau, but at least he put that position. You have utterly changed course on it; you have backflipped. You have flipped onto the privatisation thing with a vengeance.

You did not explain to us why it was so important to Mr Hawke in his Chifley speech—and Senator Schacht undoubtedly went around in the 1990 election. I remember Commonwealth Bank officers saying, `Don't vote for Senator Kemp because he is going to privatise the Commonwealth Bank.' All your party did that—you probably did not do it because in a sense you were not on the campaign trail. But we are all aware of this history; we all know the immense baggage that the Labor Party carries on this. The great icon of the government enterprises was the Commonwealth Bank. You have sold that and you are about to sell more, so no-one believes you on these other issues now. Why should they, given the whole history?

I do not want to be ungenerous about this bill. I will be looking forward to voting with Senator Wheelwright on this bill. They have adopted our policy. They went into the Liberal Party supermarket and said, `We're bereft of policy initiatives, so what can we borrow from the Liberal Party?' They said, `It doesn't make sense in the modern world,'—and I think it is correct—`to have major banking facilities in the public sector.' So you adopted the Liberal Party policy ungraciously. There was no hint in your speech that you had done one almighty backflip, but because you got into the Telecom-Telstra issue, it did remind us of the Chifley speech and how far the Keating Labor Party has changed on privatisation.

I think it is extraordinary that the Socialist Left seems to be so accepting of all this. Someone said to me that in 13 years of government the Socialist Left has become more like the social left, and I think that probably is the case. I do not see Senator Carr speaking on this bill. It would have been interesting to hear him speak. He rails against privatisation in Victoria, but he comes to Canberra and he votes for it.

The public will have to judge the sincerity of that approach. It is no wonder the Labor Party is struggling. No-one knows what they stand for. In elections they are not going to privatise anything. After the election, it is Qantas out the door, and then the Commonwealth Bank is facing very big privatisation. As I said, I am not going to be ungracious about this important bill. The Labor Party has adopted, by and large, Liberal Party policy on these sorts of issues, and I look forward to voting with Senator Wheelwright when the bill is finalised in this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is often because we do have a great backlog of legislation facing the Senate, and perhaps because the major parties are supporting this Commonwealth Bank Sale Bill, that we are guilty of overlooking the significance of bills that pass through this place. But this bill really must have some status in the parliament as it is the final sale of the historic Commonwealth Bank. To that end, it is a discredit to the government that the best they could do was wheel in Senator Wheelwright as the only speaker on the government side. They could only muster up one new backbench senator to speak on behalf of the government's policy. Even then, he was apologetic for the time he was taking up in the Senate, and I think he was more embarrassed by the fact that he could not get any supporters to speak with him on this bill.

PARA.TAB: It is a credit to Senator Wheelwright that he made an attempt and he put together a relatively good argument for the government, but it is a discredit to those on the government side who did not contribute to this debate—in particular, as Senator Kemp pointed out, those senators from the Socialist Left who have for years feigned their support for the Commonwealth Bank; in fact, made it a cornerstone of their philosophy. It has been an integral part of the Socialist Left philosophy, and not one of them has even entered the chamber during this most important and significant debate.

The bank does have an important place in Australian history. Its worth has been quite significant in Australian history over those years and, in many respects, it has been a romanticised bank. This has much to do with the beginnings of the bank itself, which go back as far as 1912, when it was introduced by a Labor government via the Commonwealth Bank Act 1911. In his second reading speech, Andrew Fisher, the then Prime Minister, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This will be a bank belonging to the people, and directly managed by the people's own agents.
It will ultimately become the bank of banks rather than a mere money-lending institution.
Our chief aim is not to make profits, but to insure safety and security to depositors.

Of course, banking has come a long way from those lofty ideals, particularly `our chief aim is not to make profits'. At the very least, the perception of this bank has been fulfilled. Its role has been fulfilled in the community, at least by perception. It has always been a popular bank, particularly in many of the rural areas. It has had a very special affinity throughout its history in rural Australia. This was really borne out when the first allotment of shares were offered to the public. It is true to say that the shares were snapped up by the mums and dads market, way above their par value and much to the surprise of the markets and even more to the surprise of a very revenue hungry government.

PARA.TAB: We know the measure of how people in Australia really do attach themselves to banks. We saw this when the Victorian State Bank collapsed around 1990. Ironically, this bank was saved by the Commonwealth Bank.
