But the customers of that Victorian bank had such an affinity with the State Bank that it was quite obvious that they were going to discriminate in respect of what bank they would belong to. After the takeover of the Victorian State Bank, most of the customers moved across to the Bank of Melbourne, believing that they were keeping their money in their state. So customers or clients do discriminate against banks. Certain banks are more popular than others and it is true to say that the Commonwealth Bank has been a popular bank since its establishment in 1912.

Given this, it is incumbent upon the government to state clearly the fate of the equally vital Commonwealth Development Bank. This bank has had a very special and significant part to play for the National Party, in particular, because its history goes back to its establishment by the National Party leader, Artie Fadden. It was described by Fadden as a vehicle to `provide finance to assist primary production or the establishment of industrial undertakings in cases where the provision of finance is desirable and the finance would not otherwise be available on reasonable and suitable terms and conditions'. The charter of the Commonwealth Bank placed emphasis on small undertakings, even when the borrower's security did not meet the requirements of the other banks. The bank was established in January 1960.

As pointed out by Senator Calvert quite well, while the share capital of the Commonwealth Development Bank will continue to be 91.9 per cent owned by the Commonwealth Bank and 8.1 per cent owned by the Commonwealth, the explanatory memorandum states that the bill does not define the future of the Commonwealth Development Bank. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Bank Sale Bill 1995 does not define the annual subsidy arrangements for the Commonwealth Development Bank. These arrangements will be defined in the Shareholders Agreement (the agreement) to be entered into between the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth Bank before the transfer time.

It seems to be laying the foundations for the Commonwealth Bank to walk away from the subsidy arrangements and terminate the specialist lending facilities of the Commonwealth Development Bank. Those subsidy arrangements are critical to the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank.

PARA.TAB: The 1994 annual report records that the Commonwealth Development Bank received a subsidy of $20 million in the year ended 30 June 1994. The 1995-96 budget papers show that a similar sum of money was to be provided. More specifically, in the 1995 annual report the Commonwealth Bank states in relation to this vital subsidy:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to the outcome of the Government's review . . . Its $20 million subsidy remains subject to annual appropriation of the government.
So we can see the set-up. Buried in the same report is an even more telling comment entitled `Looking forward'. It really does tell the story. It says:
However, as noted at page 5, the future of the Development Bank is currently the subject of review by the Government.

It is doubtful that the Treasurer (Mr Willis) would tell us anything about the future of the Commonwealth Development Bank as he is given to misleading us over the very sale of the Commonwealth Bank. Back in September 1993, Mr Willis reaffirmed his very strong position taken in relation to the government's commitment never to reduce the Commonwealth's holding in the Commonwealth Bank. In a letter which was included in the prospectus for the sale of the second tranche of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Willis assured prospective investors:
The government has no intentions whatsoever of further reducing its shareholding.
Of course, it took only one budget after that for the government to put the bank up for sale. Nevertheless, we ask the government: what is the future of the Commonwealth Development Bank?

PARA.TAB: The last thing we want is for the government to do to the Commonwealth Development Bank what they have managed to do to the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The privatisation of the AIDC rivals the very fiasco of ANL, which we debated in this house just a week ago. As the parliament would be aware in relation to ANL, as each day goes by and an agreement is not achieved between the Commonwealth, P&O and, I suppose, the unions as the third party, taxpayers lose $2 million.

In relation to the AIDC, the government got halfway down the track to privatising it with the sale of some 20 per cent of shares to private hands when they announced a complete turnaround and attempted to renationalise the AIDC. Who knows what its future is. Clearly, those who purchased shares in the corporation at that time are the losers, particularly now that those minority shareholders are under pressure to accept an offer or see the government withdraw its guarantee by 1998.

It is very worth while to note that, while those minority shareholders look like being the losers in this debacle, the board and executives do not. After 1994, when the decision for the sale was certain, the board decided to hand out pay rises of up 200 per cent and more. In particular, the chief executive went from earning $320,000 to earning $1.8 million in one hop. There was a similar increase for other key staff.

Let me put that pay rise into perspective. I do not think this corporation has made a profit in the last five years. Are you aware of that, Senator Kernot? They would be lucky to have made a significant profit at all in the last five years. They certainly do not measure up to the major corporations such as the National Bank or Coles Myer.

The chief executive of the AIDC earns more than the chief executive of Coles Myer and the chief executive of the National Bank, by a long shot. The chief executive of the AIDC is the eighth highest paid executive in Australia, while the chief executive of the National Bank is nineteenth. That is the position of the chief executive of the AIDC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose skills are worth $1.8 million a year, anyway—whether it is the AIDC or the National Bank?
—That may be a debate for another occasion. It is a fiasco and a debacle. It is the shareholders who are the losers.

PARA.TAB: The parliament can see from that that the government has a very poor record when it comes to asset sales and privatisation. From 1991, when basically this privatisation program gathered its momentum, to 1994-95, they have never reached their targeted budget announcement. In 1991 they budgeted for $1 billion worth of asset sales. They achieved $162 million. In 1991-92 they budgeted for $625 million of asset sales. They reached half of that figure. In 1992-93 they budgeted for $1.6 billion worth of asset sales. They reached $800 million. In 1993-94 they budgeted for a very cautious $2.4 billion. They did not get close to that figure.

It is worth reminding the government that the sale of the Commonwealth Bank was used in the last budget as the deciding factor, late as it was, to bring the government's budget into surplus by some $718 million. That amount was always recognised as an attempt to gild the lily. The actuals are now in since that budget. The budget has not reached and will not reach its surplus.

We know that for a fact because in October the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport, Mr O'Keefe, introduced legislation to obtain the parliament's approval to appropriate additional moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenses additional to those already appropriated in 1995-96. They are already looking for some $917 million extra.

This amount is made up not only by a slower growth rate and therefore less revenue but also by the failure of the AIDC sale. Some $200 million has contributed to the government now not looking like it is going to get its $718 million surplus. It will probably be the reverse—a $718 million deficit.

The sale of the Commonwealth Bank was the key to the government's budget strategies. With the deregulation of the financial sector in the 1980s it was unavoidable that the bank would and should be privatised. We support that. It enters the market as one of Australia `s top four banks. Its financial position is such that it is set to take No. 2 after the National Bank, if it does not already hold that position. I believe that a competitive, efficient Commonwealth Bank, through privatisation, will further add to banking competition, to the long-term benefits of clients and shareholders alike.

Even with an unbridled Commonwealth Bank in the marketplace, it is critical that the banks are subject to the strongest competition. After the PSA had produced its bank charges report calling upon the banks to show some discipline in relation to client charges, within a very short time, less than a month, the Commonwealth Bank put up its charges. This did not give much hope for self-regulation. It was only because the parliament and the government had some control, some shares still left in the Commonwealth Bank, that they were able to pull them into line and reverse that decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's important.

—It is most important, therefore, that once we lose that control we have proper competition in the financial sector. That competition will come and must come from the regional banks, which are surely producing a great deal of competition for those larger banks.

PARA.TAB: One of the most tangible benefits of deregulation of the financial sector has been the rise of the smaller banks and the regional banks. The first major test in this sector came some months ago when Westpac made a takeover bid for Western Australia's Challenge Bank against the New South Wales smaller regional bank the St George Bank. To say the least, this caused ripples in the financial markets, as it was to set the stage, were that takeover to be unfettered, for the big four to take over all the regionals and therefore, without doubt, lessen competition in the financial sector.

The matter was referred to the Trade Practices Commission, now the ACCC, on the grounds of section 50: lessening competition. I am pleased to say that, while that particular takeover bid was given the green light, the Trade Practices Commission, or the ACCC as it is now, laid down future competition rules. This takeover gave them the opportunity to lay down future competition rules. Fundamentally, the decision was to protect the smaller regional banks, as they were seen to bring competition to the marketplace. At least one state must have one major regional bank. In my state it will be the Bank of Melbourne. On balance, the decision was good enough and it will keep the banking sector healthy and competitive.

That being the case, the coalition supports, as Senator Calvert said, the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. But, in the committee stage, we will vigorously pursue the matter of the Commonwealth Development Bank. I wish the Commonwealth Bank, its shareholders and its clients well as it enters a new era.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that today we are debating the last step in the government's total privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. I remember being here to see the lot of it. People have talked about the way in which the Labor government has changed its policy on this. What we are seeing here is another example of this government's bailing out of its responsibility in this area for short-term dollars.

PARA.TAB: There are often good reasons for supporting the sale of assets. The Australian Democrats cannot see too many good reasons for supporting the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. Most people seem to have caved in to the privatisation argument in this country. I am asked, `Why don't you just give in? Why do you continue to oppose some of these things?' Despite what Senator McGauran has said, I say the evidence is that the recent history of banking in this country has proven it to be non-competitive. The Reserve Bank said so itself.

The recent history of banking has highlighted the need for pro-active government intervention to improve competition. Senator McGauran tells us that competition will come. They told us that in 1983. They said, `Deregulate. Competition improves consumer services. It will all come.' It is 12 years down the track and we are still waiting.

The Democrats believe that in a non-competitive environment the government has a responsibility and a role in setting some standards. If we take the example of superannuation and its recent history in this country, we see that the only way the government could get the superannuation funds to deliver a fairer deal on fees was by threatening to use the Taxation Office as a competitor. That is one reason why we believe the government should not give up one of the few means of influence it has over banking in this country.

The politics of this bill are interesting. It was included in the 1995 budget—it seems, at the very last moment—to allow the Treasurer, Mr Willis, to announce the magic but deceptive and illusory surplus. I am told that it was included in the budget only after the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) gave a nudge and a wink behind the Speaker's chair, agreeing not to oppose it. The sale of one of this country's most important and influential assets was announced without ever being considered by the backbench of the government or, as I understand it, by the backbench of the Liberal and National parties.

When they vote for this today, I wonder whether Labor senators will reflect on the fact that they are dismantling one of Labor's proudest legacies—the legacy of Andrew Fisher and King O'Malley—the people's bank. I accept that times change. However, this bill represents a sanctioned watering down of ALP policy and breaches an undertaking given to earlier purchasers of Commonwealth Bank shares that government ownership would not be reduced. Those who vote for the sale of the Commonwealth Bank will be placing small business and farming finance in limbo by also agreeing to sell the Commonwealth Development Bank without its future role being resolved.

Those who vote for this bill will also be sanctioning the fact that it is okay for governments to give up scope for the possible influence of competition in the banking industry by allowing the Commonwealth Bank to run on lower margins, lower fees, with more innovative products and greater accountability to consumers. I recall during the last election campaign the very important commitment given by the ALP, in response to Fightback, that the ALP was not in the wholesale privatisation business. It is a bit hard to remember that when we have had the ANL and airports bills in the Senate over the last week.

It is true that the opposition has made no secret of its long-term plan to sell the Commonwealth Bank. The National Party has always expressed concern about what that could mean for the Commonwealth Development Bank, the farmer's friend, the lender of last resort to farming and small business communities. In the debate in the other place, one National Party frontbencher, Mr Bruce Scott, said that the sale:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will almost certainly have an impact on the nation's rural and small business people.
He went on:
. . . it represents another slap in the face for those people and their families who have plunged ever deeper into financial and social crisis—
over the last 13 years. But, guess what? He voted for it. I bet Senator McGauran does too, despite all the vigorous questioning he will undertake in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: I will tell you why the National Party will vote for the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, which includes the sale of the Commonwealth Development Bank. It is because they have to take the view that coalition stability is more important than the concerns of their constituents. The Democrats believe that the Commonwealth Development Bank is too important an institution to be trifled with.

The bill before us repeals the legislation governing the role of the Commonwealth Development Bank as the lender of last resort and the provisions underpinning the government's subsidy. We are told that these provisions will be subject to a memorandum between the bank and the government at a later stage. In the committee stage, Senator McGauran might like to pursue that line of questioning.

I wonder whether he has seen the Commonwealth Bank's 1995 report. I wonder whether he would agree with me that the bank does not seem to be terribly keen about being saddled with the low margin nature of the Commonwealth Development Bank's activities. The Commonwealth Bank's annual report notes that the Commonwealth Development Bank is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . currently the subject of a review by the Government. The Bank's objective remains to achieve a proper commercial balance between the consequences of the charter and the size of any subsidy received in support of it.

The message there is clear—it is clear to me—that the bank will be putting pressure on to maximise the subsidy and minimise the obligations to assist rural and small business operators. I wonder whether the National Party really wants to assist by acquiescing in what is clearly the first stage of the dismantling of the Commonwealth Development Bank as we know it.

PARA.TAB: I will give Senator McGauran an opportunity to vote for our amendment. With our proposal we want to guarantee the future role of the Commonwealth Development Bank. Under our amendment it would not be swinging in the breeze depending on bank management and the federal Treasurer holding their word on it. Rather, we would propose by our amendment that the role could not be changed without the approval of parliament itself and, through parliament, the input of affected rural and small business sectors. Let us see when the vote comes how genuinely concerned the National Party is about these sectors. Let us see whether it is a matter of mouthing platitudes and then voting differently and hoping that people out there in the bush will not notice.

This sale bill is also an opportunity to see how seriously we feel about corporate honesty and behaviour. There has been a lot of talk over the lifting of standards of corporate behaviour, particularly in relation to undertakings in prospectuses, et cetera. Here we have a majority shareholder—the government—selling its shares, going back deliberately on a commitment it gave just 20 months ago that it would not sell its share in the bank. Thousands of mum and dad investors all over Australia lined up to buy Commonwealth Bank shares in the knowledge that the government had given an ironclad guarantee that government majority ownership would be preserved, along with the guarantee.

Then finance minister, Ralph Willis, in a letter included in the prospectus, said, `The government has no intention whatsoever of further reducing its shareholding.' What a joke—20 months! This was confirmed in l-a-w law in the Commonwealth Banks Act, section 27L, which requires the government to remain the majority shareholder. But today, as I said, 20 months later, we are asked to repeal that section. We are asked to sanction Mr Willis's breach of an undertaking on which many shareholders probably acted in purchasing their shares.

A lot was said at the time. I remember Mr Peter Costello saying that, if Mr Willis were the director of a private company, he would be facing an Australian Securities Commission investigation and a possible five-year gaol sentence for a possible breach of section 996 of the Corporations Law for false and misleading statements in a prospectus. I am not a legal expert. While there is an argument that technically the government is not in breach of the Corporations Law or trade practices law, it remains the case that it is a very poor example to set for the private sector.

Company directors would be entitled to ask why it is that someone who is running the country does not have to comply with the kinds of laws that someone running a company has to. They would also want to know why the opposition, after making such a fuss, has backed down and decided to sanction this by voting for this sale bill. What sort of message does that send to the corporate sector—that it is okay to say anything in a prospectus?

As I said at the beginning of my speech, the Commonwealth Bank could play a significant role in forcing the pace of competition in the marketplace. A government controlled bank not required to maximise profits could set new benchmarks in terms of maximising service and value for money. In the past, with its commitment to housing finance, to promoting household savings, to maintaining a presence in country towns and to looking after small savers and small businesses, the Commonwealth Bank did fulfil this role. All over Australia people are asking who is going to do it now. With financial deregulation and corporatisation, the Commonwealth Bank has progressively shed this traditional role. The Democrats think that has been a tragedy.

To go to the economic arguments, the Commonwealth Bank is a very profitable institution. This year its after tax profit was just under $1 billion. In the previous four years it averaged an annual profit of over $600 million. That is an income stream that is owned by Australian taxpayers. In selling off the bank, the government chooses to deprive Australian taxpayers of that income stream.

What is worse, as Dr John Quiggin and Professor Bob Walker have pointed out, in privatisation decisions this government and other governments are forced to sell their assets for much less than their net present value to the government because of the different taxation and borrowing status of would-be private investors. Not only do we sell it off and lose the income stream; we sell it at a lower price than it is worth, losing a second income stream.

In selling the Commonwealth Bank, we lose the potential to influence the behaviour of our banking market. Why shouldn't we be worried about that? We lose the potential to keep the biggest and most popular personal banking house in this country from exposing itself to corporate and merchant banking in an inappropriate way. We lose the potential income stream. We kick sand in the eyes of rural and small business borrowers. And we sanction what some people have called the most massive deception of shareholders acting on a prospectus in recent Australian corporate history.

For the Democrats, they are some very good reasons for voting down this bill. As I say, I urge National Party senators who have voiced concerns about this, I urge those who are interested in public finance and corporate governance, I urge those who are interested in improving the competitiveness of our banking sector to join with the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine in voting this bill down.

On the opposition's second reading amendment, I make the following few comments. On part (a), that the role of the Commonwealth Development Bank is ill-defined and it should be included as a schedule, the Democrats share the concern of the opposition in that respect but we believe the Senate should go further than a mere second reading amendment and legislate to ensure that the Commonwealth Development Bank cannot be watered down by the bank itself or by a future federal Treasurer. It does not take long to learn in this place that treasurers do not keep their commitments on things to do with the Commonwealth Bank; for example, in this case a commitment kept for not more than 20 months. If the Treasurer had kept his word, this bill would not be before us today. While sympathetic with part (a), I do not believe it goes far enough.

With regard to part (b), I wonder whether this is a misunderstanding. Senator Calvert is not here, but no doubt he can tell me. As I understand it, the probable buyback will require the approval of 75 per cent of shareholders. I think this hardly places it in the category of compulsory acquisition. Therefore, I do not think the case for part (b) of this amendment has been satisfactorily made out.

On part (c), the potentially retrospective nature of the regulation making power in this bill has already been the subject of a report by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The Democrats do not accept the government's argument that the government wants to grant this power to ensure that, if it makes mistakes because it has cut so many corners on the sale processes already, it can retrospectively fix them. I do not think it is appropriate. It sets a bad precedent, even if the regulation is disallowable. I wonder why the opposition wishes to proceed with this item as a second reading amendment rather than as a bone fide amendment, as suggested by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

So the Democrats cannot support this second reading amendment in its present form, particularly part (b). However, I reiterate that, irrespective of a successful second reading amendment, we should not be voting for the sale of the Commonwealth Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Bank was founded in very different times from those today. It was founded at a time when it was thought appropriate to have a government run bank, and there was a lot of merit in that proposition. But what was appropriate in the 1930s faces grave difficulties when confronted by the realities of the 1990s. It is a reality that the financial world is becoming increasingly internationalised. Be it for good or for ill, those are the facts.

PARA.TAB: The suggestion that we could somehow return to a situation where the Commonwealth could print money, as some people advocate to me in letters, or that we should have a bank run by the Commonwealth which somehow sits apart from the mainstream banking world whilst still being a broad based retail bank is, unfortunately, an untenable proposition. The fact is that we have to recognise the change in the international financial situation. In the same way as it is impossible these days to defend fixed rates of exchange, so too is it unrealistic for us to say that we believe the Commonwealth Bank should somehow remain as some protected fiefdom, whilst all around it banks are changing, growing and becoming more powerful.

One of the grave dangers is that, if we take the view that the Commonwealth Bank should be kept as a government run entity, we run the very real risk of one of our major Australian retail banks failing to have the opportunities to develop overseas in the way that other Australian banks are doing at the moment. If we look at the recent purchase by the National Australia Bank of a $2 billion banking operation in the United States, we can see how the opportunities existing in the private sector have resulted in more power, more leverage not only for that bank but for the Australian banking sector overseas. In an international world, that is necessary.

There are sound reasons why the coalition supports the general thrust of the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank, but there are points that should also be made about it. When the government first floated its stake in the Commonwealth Bank, it gave undertakings that it would not float a further stake—and then that undertaking was broken. That undertaking has been broken to the detriment of shareholders who went into the first tranche.

Given that, I think there is a very clear message in terms of the manner in which the privatisation should proceed. When the rest of the government stake in the Commonwealth Bank is sold, it must quite clearly be sold as one tranche and not as two. Why do I say that? Very simply, the role that the government should place on whichever bank does the privatisation must be a very clear one: so far as is possible, it must be to maximise the sale proceeds for the Commonwealth and also for the Australian taxpayer.

If you sell it as two tranches, then demand for the first tranche will be depressed because every buyer who goes into that first tranche will know that there is a further tranche in the wings, that there will be additional supply. Therefore, institutional demand for the first tranche of shares will be lower. It is quite reasonable to say that, by selling in two tranches, you could well end up with the result of five to 10 per cent less than would have been achieved if it had been sold as one tranche.

That is based on an assumption that it is possible to sell all of the remaining stake in one tranche. But if one looks at the market around the world for privatisations at the moment—which is ferocious; there is a voracious appetite out there for stakes in newly privatised government business entities—it is perfectly reasonable to say that it is achievable for us to sell the remaining equity in one tranche.Certainly, I know from my contacts in the banking industry that that is a view that many banks have—that it should be sold as one tranche. That is something that the government should take into consideration.

But I want to make a point about the timing of this sale. Last week those of us in the opposition were treated to an extraordinary display from the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook. He rose to tell the Senate that the opposition was financially and fiscally profligate—and this is what he said—for the simple reason, he claimed, that the opposition would hold up the sale of the airports and, therefore, damage the bottom line position of this year's budget.

It was Senator Cook's assertion that the coalition would damage the budget outcome for 1995-96. Fortunately, my friend Senator Short rose and corrected Senator Cook and pointed out that in fact the sale of the airports is not scheduled to occur until 1996-97. In other words, there was no damage being done to the bottom line of the budget. Of course, we all know the sale of the airports can go ahead as soon as the government wishes to meet the concerns that we in the opposition have. We are not blocking it; we are merely saying it is appropriate for the parliament to place some conditions on these things.

I want to point out what was said by the government a couple of weeks ago to those banks that made presentations in relation to this privatisation. Mr Willis had all the banks lined up here in Canberra. They all came and made their presentations, suggesting how they believed this privatisation should take place. In the process, those banks were told by the Treasurer when they asked about the timing of the float that it would not occur until after the election irrespective of when that election was held.

On the assumption that the earliest date the election could be held is now somewhere around about March and given the election could now be as late as May because the government has already said it will put off the budget until August, it is blatantly obvious to anybody who makes the slightest inquiry that the sale of the Commonwealth Bank will not happen this financial year. Why is that important? I will tell you why that is important.

In the budget that was delivered in May, the government relied on selling at least one tranche of the Commonwealth Bank in this current financial year. The estimates of the value of the remaining equity in the Commonwealth Bank range from $4 billion to $5 billion. Assuming the first tranche was less than the second tranche, which is one of the things we will probably have to do in order to maximise the overall return on the assets, it is very clear that by the government's own delay this budget will have between $1.6 billion and $2 billion punched out of it because the sale of the first tranche of the Commonwealth Bank will not occur this financial year.

I want all of the scribes in the press gallery to take note of the fact that this government's budget will be in deficit not because of anything the coalition has done but because the government itself was incapable of proceeding with the remaining privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank as it planned. I predict quite confidently that the budget deficit outcome for this financial year will exceed $2 billion because of the additional spending pledges that have been made by the Prime Minister and because of the fact that just a couple of weeks ago the Treasurer told the banks bidding for this privatisation it would not occur until after the election.

It is totally impossible to expect that even a portion, even the first tranche of the remaining Commonwealth equity in the Commonwealth Bank, could be sold in three months. Assuming an election was held in March, the new government would be in office by the beginning of April. But that would only give them April, May and June in which to not only plan and implement the sale strategy but also bring that money into the Commonwealth coffers. It is quite obvious that this government, through its own ineptitude, has now punched a $1.6 billion to $2 billion hole in the Commonwealth's government budget position. I believe that is a fact that Australians should be made aware of.

There is a reason why this government has delayed this sale. That reason is simply this: the government had no intention of bringing that money into the budget this year. The government's intention always was that it would occur in the next financial year. Hence, the statement it will be sold in two tranches—one this financial year and one next financial year. It was always the intention that that stake would be sold in the next financial year. It was always the government's intention to include in the budget estimates money that the government knew it would never get in, so it could say to the Australian people, `We have produced this year a budget surplus.'

But it was a surplus in estimate only and a dishonest estimate at that because the facts are that it will not happen. Next financial year the government was rather hoping it would be elected so it could bring the same sale proceeds into the budget twice and say in the next financial year, `Aren't we wonderful financial managers; we have achieved such a great turnaround on the 1995-96 result'—which, of course, was always going to be a deficit.

That is the reason why the government has done it the way it has. That is the reason why the Commonwealth was unwilling to put an actual estimate on the value to the budget this year of the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. They did not want to put an accurate figure on it because they knew it would then be possible for the opposition to quantify the amount of money that would be lost from the bottom-line position before we got to the election. It was always intended to be an exercise in deception. But from a government which has excelled at deception, what should surprise us about that? So we see this lovely little fiscal charade from the government where they pretend to privatise something this year, privatise it the following year, bring the figures into the budget twice, and make themselves look like angels when we know they are far from angels when it comes to fiscal management. That has been the strategy of the government.

There is one other factor which has been behind the government's thinking on this. It is quite simply that the government knows that amongst its voters, amongst its heartland, the sale of the Commonwealth Bank is a very, very contentious issue. There are many people who form the view that the Commonwealth Bank is rather like the family silver—that you should not sell it. So, rather than having an unseemly factional brawl in the ALP in the lead-up to the election, what did this strong, powerful government that was going to exercise national leadership in the interests of all Australians do? It put it off because it was the easy thing to do. Rather than making the tough decisions, rather than seeing that privatisation occur this financial year, rather than seeing it happen before the budget, the government decided, `We will put it off.' It helped them dodgy up the figures for the budget and it helps them avoid contention in their own party and amongst their own supporters because of what they are doing to the Commonwealth Bank.

That exposes the duplicity and the dishonesty of this government—that they are unwilling to tell the Australian people what they are doing, they are unwilling to be honest in their budget estimates and they are unwilling to make the tough decisions necessary for the future of this nation.

One of the things that greatly disappoints me is that this government has so far squandered the proceeds of asset sales in recurrent spending. In other words, assets that have been built up through taxpayer contributions, through investment by government, assets that have been built up, put away and saved, have been wantonly squandered to pay for government election promises, to pay for recurrent spending—not to pay for infrastructure, not to be reinvested in new assets, but used to fund this or that government scheme so that they can run around, wring their hands and say they are concerned about Australians.

If this government has a sense of conscience, the real concern for Australia should be shown and achieved by reinvesting the sale proceeds, as the coalition is committed to doing, or by paying off government debt, not squandering it on a political holiday, which is what we are seeing at the moment. The future of this nation is such that Australia's fate is in the balance. A continuation of the fiscal profligacy of the Labor Party can only result in one thing—a lower standard of living for all Australians.

The Commonwealth Bank sale, just like the sale of the airports, is proof that Australia needs sound financial management. Instead of seeing a wanton, wilful and wasteful Labor government, Australia needs a coalition government now more than at any time in the past, a coalition government that will make the right decisions for the benefit of all Australians, not just for the benefit of the Labor Party's factional disputes. That is what we need. That is why this government is shameful and wasteful, and that is why they must be thrown out at the next election.
Debate interrupted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Further to the arrangements announced on 14 November, I inform the Senate that Senator McMullan will remain overseas on official government business until 28 November and will therefore be absent from question time today and tomorrow. He is visiting Washington to participate in discussions with agricultural leaders and to lobby for Australia's interests during the finalisation of the new farm bill. In his absence from question time today and tomorrow, I will continue to take questions on trade, Senator Collins will represent the Minister for Communications and the Arts and Senator Bolkus will represent the Minister for Administrative Services.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the fact that in the last few days two of Australia's most respected business leaders have given the Keating government the thumbs down. First, retiring Woolworths chairman, Paul Simons, said that the economy is fragile, and yesterday the ANZ Bank chief, Don Mercer, attacked the government on its superannuation and micro-economic reform policies and its inability to deliver a responsible budget surplus. Why should the Australian community not believe Mr Mercer when he says that the government's failed policies are likely to cause a rise in interest rates next year?

—Of course the government does not speculate on interest rates and Senator Short knows that. This is a provocative question. He is playing politics once again. It has nothing to do with real information.

PARA.TAB: Don Mercer did say a few things about the Australian economy yesterday. If the opposition, as it sometimes does, describes the Australian economy as highly vulnerable, then I wonder how they would rate an economy with an average growth over five years of 2 1/2 per cent and inflation of 10 per cent. How would they rate an economy of that sort? That is what their leader, Mr Howard, achieved when he was Treasurer. Under his economic stewardship, the average real economic growth rate was 2 1/2 per cent and the average inflation rate was 10 per cent.

Later this week the Australian Bureau of Statistics will release the latest national accounts data. After four years of continuous economic growth, this data is expected to show that the economy has chalked up yet another quarter of economic growth. All the signs are that the economy is set to continue growing not just for several more quarters but indeed for several more years. It should be noted that, even with the recent moderation in growth, Australia still has one of the fastest growing economies in the whole OECD.

The transition to long-term sustainable growth is now being reflected in the economic data. The data show activity moderating in some sectors, such as in the housing industry, and in some regions. However, one of the hallmarks of sustainable growth is that those parts of the economy with moderating levels of activity are matched by others in which activity is growing strongly.

For instance, as housing construction started to decline last year non-dwelling construction began to pick up and is now growing strongly. Robust exports and the rural recovery are also showing important sources of strength to the economy. The transition earlier this year from extremely high unsustainable levels of growth to more moderate but still strong levels of growth is only now being reflected in the labour force data. That is because employment, as a lagging indicator, provides a better measure of where the economy has been in the recent past rather than where the economy is now or where it will be in the future.

In this question Senator Short also referred to superannuation, and Mr Mercer made some remarks about superannuation in his Business Sunday interview yesterday. What should be remembered is that Mr Mercer was speaking for the banks. The banks have an obligation to their shareholders to make a profit and distribute the profit to their shareholders; superannuation funds—to whom he was not so kind—have an obligation not to make a profit and, through their trustees, to distribute the advantages to their members. That is an important distinction when one goes into the debate about whether banks should have a bigger role in superannuation, as opposed to industry funds.

The position of industry funds in the superannuation industry must also be kept in perspective. Data from the ISC showed that total superannuation assets currently are around $190 billion and that industry funds have assets of around $9 billion.

I conclude, in answer to this facetious question, by saying that yesterday we had Mr Howard saying that there is not much fat in the economy to cut out in terms of the budget because the fat that existed 10 to 15 years or so ago has gone. I remind the Senate: who was Treasurer 10 to 15 years ago—John Howard. Who cut it out? We did. That is why there is not much fat now. Yet at the same time, in contradistinction to his leader, we have Mr Costello running around Australia making flagrant promises of new expenditure while opposing over the last four years $11 billion-plus in terms of budget income. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note from that further blustering attempt to hide the issues and gild the lily that Senator Cook has again failed to provide any substantive answer to the questions that are put to him. I note in particular that the minister has not denied Mr Mercer's contention that, on the government's present policies, interest rates are likely to rise next week, despite the fact that they are already amongst the highest in the Western world. I repeat the question to him; I will give him another chance at it: how is the government going to achieve an underlying economic policy framework that will avoid interest rate increases inevitably occurring next year, as will be the case under its present policy stance?

—Nice try. Same question; different clothing but the same intent. You know that every responsible government minister will not engage in speculation about the direction of interest rates, and for every commentator who says one thing in the community—Don Mercer being among them—other commentators say another thing. I can point you to a body of different commentary, none of which I endorse because I am not going to be drawn on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The question is: who are the better economic managers? We have the coalition lying to the Australian community about how they will balance their budget by saying they will not cut anything; nonetheless giving away billions of dollars of special pleadings to interest groups while at the same time blocking $11 billion-plus of income to the budget. How have you worked that out? Mandrake could not solve that problem and no serious economic commentator in this country regards you as having any credentials at all on economic management. Every time your leader, Mr Howard, is asked about what his economic policies are, all he does is launch another truck. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, Senator Crowley. Minister, I understand a study conducted in the United Kingdom has found that Australia has one of the best and fairest systems of family assistance in the world. What information are you able to provide about the report and its findings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am very pleased to be able to tell the Senate about a very interesting and very timely piece of research coming out of the University of York in the United Kingdom which is very good news for this government's policies and programs for families. The findings, written in particular by Dr Peter Whiteford, are reported in the latest issue of the Social Security Journal, published by the Department of Social Security. If anyone wants to skim over what this report is about, then they can read Ross Gittins's article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday. He has actually had a very close look at it and he concludes:

PARA.TAB: And our system does more to direct assistance to low-income families than any other system examined.

ANSWER.PARA: The other systems examined included studies of Australia, New Zealand, Japan, the United States, Norway, Sweden and the 12 countries of the European Union. Unlike a lot of other studies that we have seen recently, this study included a whole variety of benefits, including all cash payments, tax allowances for children, assistance with housing costs, assistance with child-care costs and the impact of the spending on health.

PARA.TAB: This study shows that the package of cash benefits for low income families in Australia was 47 per cent above the average for those 18 countries. It also found that low income working families in Australia pay the lowest level of direct taxes—that is, income taxes and social security contributions—of any of those countries. So it is very encouraging and a very big tick in favour of this government's policies of targeting and directing its payments and its assistance to those most in need.

As a comparison of tax burdens, a family with two children earning half average weekly earnings and paying only four per cent of their income in tax in 1992 paid about half the level of taxes of a similar family in the United States, one-third the level of Japan or the United Kingdom, one-fifth the level of New Zealand, France or Germany and less than one-seventh of the level in Denmark and the Netherlands. It is a very important and useful article.

The article by Ross Gittins goes on to point out that it should be a very big challenge—he does not say this, but I do, concluding from what he says—for the opposition's policies. It is a very big challenge because in the Lyons Forum document there are recommendations for how it would be best to proceed on behalf of the opposition in terms of family policies, including a case made for the French quotient system. This article points out that that is a sleight of hand and the opposition seems to have bought it—that is, because the taxes are low, the social security payments are—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's just wrong.

—No, this is exactly what is so good about this article, Senator Abetz. You should go and read the article because it allows you to conclude that although French families on average earnings pay no income tax, they do have to pay hefty social security contributions. Were we to introduce a quotient system, the loss of income tax revenue would be so great that we would have to introduce a GST to pay for it. In other words, the overall impact would be purely cosmetic. The article goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: Even so, we could make our system more generous to high-income families—but only by making it less generous to low-income families.

ANSWER.PARA: That does not make sense to Ross Gittins, and does not make sense to the government, but it does apparently make sense to the opposition—to redistribute away from the low income targeted payments this government has along with income splitting proposals. Senator Hill knows that those opposite are looking at income splitting and also the French alternative under the Lyons Forum. This article is absolute confirmation that the way the government is doing it is the best and it is particularly advantageous for low income families in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the South Australian United Trades and Labour Council document leaked last week that let the cat out of the bag on Labor's intended fear and loathing campaign, consistent with the WA union blockade and Jennie George's stated intent to maintain industrial action up to the election and, of course, followed by the national strikes last week. How can the ALP support a campaign of industrial relations disruption at great cost to innocent parties as justified for political gain? Doesn't a campaign of fear and loathing to frighten voters debase Australian politics? Why doesn't the Prime Minister show some national leadership and contest the issues rather than scare voters into submission, or it is that Labor has run out of ideas and all that you are left with is the option of a scare campaign?

—I sense a certain wistfulness on Senator Hill's part when he talks about this campaign because it is well known that Senator Hill could not inject fear and loathing into even a rabbit or a sheep, or a lamb, or a kitten in the community. You couldn't leave a mark on a soft cushion in terms of your record so far. I can understand the degree of difficulty you would have in an aggressive campaign by anyone about anything. I can understand that that causes you a bit of psychological difficulty confronting that possibility.
—He knocks you down every day, you fool.
—I see; that's another Macdonald—a big, steaming Macdonald.
—Order! Just withdraw that, will you? I have made a comment on that before and I ask you to withdraw it.
—Steam was coming out his ears and it was Senator Macdonald, but in deference to you I withdraw.
—Order! I sugest that you answer the question rather than heaping abuse on the person who asked the question.

—It was a silly, empty, opportunistic question and it deserves an appropriate answer. The kind of campaign that was mooted in that document, as Senator Hill describes—and I have not seen it—is a fairly routine kind of an exercise so far as the trade union movement is concerned. It is perfectly understandable that trade unions, feeling themselves to be potentially under siege by Tory governments both at home in South Australia and potentially here—although God knows why they should assume there is any prospect of that nationally—would want to act to preserve their position, just as the ACTU did and the relevant unions in the mining industry in Queensland have wanted to do.

PARA.TAB: The trade union movement is perfectly entitled to defend its position. It is appropriate that it do so by time-honoured methods—not methods that are at odds with larger community values or which cause havoc and disruption on a larger scale than is necessary to make the point. There will always be differences of opinion about that. A little bit of rhetoric, a little bit of hyperbole, is to be expected in these situations. It was no more than that, I am sure, in this situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the minister to various claims about the problem of youth unemployment and alternative approaches to address this problem. I ask: can the minister provide details of how the government is developing measures to alleviate youth unemployment?

—First of all, the government has always put on record that it believes unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, in Australia is unacceptably high. However, we want to put down some of the remarks made around the place, particularly by members opposite, about the level of youth unemployment in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The full-time teenage unemployment rate being 29 per cent does not mean that 29 per cent of Australian teenagers are unemployed. That is because only 25 per cent of teenagers were available for full-time work in October. Fifty-five per cent were in school and 13 per cent were in full-time post-school education. What we should focus on is the 95,600 teenagers looking for full-time work, which is 7.3 per cent of the teenage population.

It is worth noting that we have in government reduced this number from John Howard's 158,000 in 1983, which amounted to over 12 per cent of the total teenage population being unemployed. I think it is time that the public understood that there is quite a difference, and understood the way the opposition has been making misleading comments on unemployment. Through our Working Nation policies, the number of long-term unemployed young people fell by 10 per cent over the year to October 1995. However, we do want to bring that number down even further, and that is the thrust of the Working Nation initiatives.

Last week Minister Crean released the results of discussions around the country with 700 young people about employment and labour market programs. These consultations showed that young people want more traineeships in growth areas, more options for vocational education and training at schools and better service from the CES. The minister has indicated that he is looking at all of these things to improve further how we can address these issues raised by young people.

Minister Crean has already expressed a willingness to encourage the use of schools more effectively to provide pathways to work. We are expanding the options for years 11 and 12 students to pursue more vocational streams of education. We are increasing the opportunities for school leavers to go to university or TAFE or have structured training in a job. Last financial year 69,500 trainees and apprentices commenced work—nearly five per cent more than in 1993-94. Since Labor took office school retention rates have been increased from 40 per cent to 75 per cent, and university places have been increased by 64 per cent.

The point we make is that we have not heard once from the opposition, though they are greatly critical of Working Nation, what they would replace it with and what they would do to create youth employment. The last policy we have had announced by the opposition is that they would reduce the youth wage to $3 an hour. That is the last time we have heard any policy initiative in over three years from the opposition about what they would do for youth employment in Australia.

The last effort they made was a youth bus a couple of months ago heading north, with the young boys from the Liberal Party on the bus—Chris Pyne and Senator Campbell. Now we have the youth truck wandering around Australia, again putting forth this misleading information that 29 per cent of all teenagers in Australia are unemployed. In fact, it is only 7 per cent of all teenagers in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Evans, as Leader of the Government in the Senate. How valid is the claim that the Comalco dispute has been settled, when the picket at Weipa continues to be in place? Is it not a fact that the unions have now ignored three commission recommendations that they disband the picket and return to work? Does the government condemn this defiance of the commission by the trade union movement? Furthermore, doesn't this represent the dramatic failure of your industrial relations policy and further proof of the determination of Jennie George and the ACTU to stage an ongoing industrial campaign designed to bring the country to its knees, industry by industry?

—Of course we would wish that the striking workers—Senator Abetz is not even interested in the reply—would return to work as soon as possible, in accordance with the commission's decision. Of course it is the government's position that they should do so.

PARA.TAB: My understanding of the ACTU position, contrary to yours, as stated by Mr Kelty, is that the striking miners have decided not to return to work until the ACTU disputes committee reconvenes early this week. Jennie George, the ACTU president-elect, is expected to speak to them at Weipa on Wednesday to try to convince them to return to work. That is utterly at odds with the imputation contained in Senator Abetz's question that the ACTU was, in fact, determined, concerned or keen to keep this dispute going. That is not the case. The ACTU is committed to getting them back to work. We obviously want the issue resolved, as does the ACTU, before the commission. Of course the commission's orders and directives should be respected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Leader of the Government in the Senate can recall the words of Bill Kelty that the dispute at Weipa was about the heart, soul and purpose of the trade union movement in this country. Given that the government has an accord with the ACTU, how much input does the government have to the ACTU's policy in relation to the dispute at Weipa?

—Yes, I do recall those words being used. Of course it was about the heart and soul of the union movement, as perceived by the union movement and, to some extent, as far as the government was concerned, to the extent that what was done at Weipa was an exercise in trying to basically deunionise a mine work force and to reduce over time a capacity for collective bargaining to take place at all in circumstances described by the business press as entitling the workers to be concerned about the long-term implications of what was going on. Of course it was a legitimate issue for the trade union movement to respond to, as was the associated issue of equal pay for work of equal value. They are the issues that are being resolved before the commission at the moment.

PARA.TAB: That principle has been accepted by the commission. The ACTU has won the case already so far as the basic issues of principle are concerned. All that remains to happen now is for the issue to be resolved in terms of the dollars and cents and the particular situation of the particular work force. The ACTU has made clear its willingness to try its best to ensure that they get back to work as soon as possible. Ms George will be speaking to them with that in mind on Wednesday of this week, as I made clear in answer to the first part of the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Evans. I refer you to the undertaking the Prime Minister has given to protect forests of high conservation value. I ask: are you aware that many of these areas, the most valuable areas in East Gippsland, are outside all existing reserve systems? If you look at all of far East Gippsland and plot the remaining rainforest, most of it is outside the reserves. If you then plot on top of that the endangered species habitat and line up the coupes scheduled for logging this year, you will find that they all correspond. In other words, are you aware that the Victorian government has scheduled many areas of very high conservation value for logging this year? Finally, will the federal government prevent the clearfelling and woodchipping of any more rainforest in East Gippsland?

—Senator Lees will appreciate that these matters are being considered by cabinet right now and it is a little inappropriate under those circumstances to respond specifically to any particular question about any particular areas and the maps and the regimes that may be associated with them. All I can say generally is that, as she will be aware, the public consultation phase in relation to the deferred forest assessment exercise in Victoria finished on 3 November. During that phase Commonwealth and Victorian officials held consultation meetings with conservation, industry and community groups on the draft DFA report. Those meetings were held, I am told, in a very good atmosphere: constructive and cooperative.

PARA.TAB: A number of submissions have been received, some of which are quite detailed. The relevant officials have now started preparing a final DFA report addressing those issues. Stakeholders have been given more detailed maps and arrangements have been put in place for similar maps to occur in the final DFA report.

On the endangered species issue, which Senator Lees is obviously particularly concerned about, I am advised that, as one would expect, a number of these issues have arisen during the consultation period I have just referred to. In Victoria the issues have involved and will involve further consideration on the adequacy of prescriptions for species such as Leadbeater's possum, the long-footed potoroo, the spotted tree frog, the regent honeyeater and the swift parrot. Three species—the vulnerable variegated pygmy perch, the vulnerable Yarra pygmy perch and the endangered pink-tailed legless lizard—were not specifically referred to in the DFA report and they are being—
Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Several members of the opposition could well satisfy that description, particularly late at night and in some cases after lunch. They are not specifically referred to in the DFA report and they are being checked to confirm whether their habitat would be impacted on by forest operations.

PARA.TAB: There are other things I could tell you about the conservation reserves and the Commonwealth proposed criteria, including the fact of course that they adopt the Commonwealth's criteria, vary from the technical working group position, and that they adopt the general benchmark of 15 per cent rather than 10 per cent and they set specific targets for percentage reservation of old-growth and wilderness. You ought to be familiar with that.

In any event it does not go, other than indirectly, to the immediate point of your question; but I do not think it is really possible to give you a complete answer until after the present decision process is complete. Senator Faulkner will no doubt be delighted to give you an answer in parliament some time next week on that subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind you, Minister, that we will not be sitting next week, but I do look forward to seeing the results of the deliberations. I was not asking you for the results, however; I was more looking for information as to whether you in particular, as a senator for Victoria, had had the opportunity to look at what is actually happening in East Gippsland. Have you seen the results of rainforest logging in East Gippsland? In particular, if you have not, would you be prepared to do so during the Christmas break?

—No, I have not done that for many years. In fact what I have just said more than exhausts my knowledge of the present situation with the forests in eastern Victoria. It is an excellent suggestion of Senator Lees in that respect and I would be only too happy to find an early opportunity to do so when the electors of Holt allow me to escape from their restrictions for time enough to address these larger policy issues.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Minister, how do you respond to the comments made by General John Grey, your former army chief, who has said that Australia could not defend itself against a prolonged attack because of funding shortfalls and warped priorities? In that it is not only our army that is having trouble, what priority are you giving to resolving the crisis in the air force over the loss of its air traffic controllers? What are you going to do to stop the continuing haemorrhage of experienced air traffic controllers from the RAAF? Will you be asking the Singaporean air force to bring its own air traffic controllers to RAAF Pearce so that Australia can keep its air force in the air?

—In terms of General Grey, you cannot please all the ex-generals all the time. In regard to air traffic controllers, the greatest thing that is going to affect the air force's air traffic controllers is a requirement by CASA for 400 new air traffic controllers by 1998. The differential in salary between the air force and this body after they have been through their ab initio training is between $7,000 and $20,000 a year. Therefore there is nothing we can do, in a legal sense, to prevent people transferring from the air force to CASA. However, I have had extensive discussions with both the Minister for Transport and the executive head of this particular body to see if we can cooperate in such a way that those sorts of deficiencies that will be caused by that recruiting will not harm the air force.

PARA.TAB: The first way we responded was to increase the number of basic recruits coming into the system. By next year we will be taking in something like 48 recruits a year, which is quite up on what was done in the past. It would be cost ineffective if we just did that and lost them. The second thing we talked to CASA about is that, even if they recruit them, they return those people to cover the areas they are currently servicing until the need arises in 1998 for them actually to go to that body. That will do a lot to relieve the strain. It is interesting that you asked whether Singapore would bring its air traffic controllers. They are having the same retention problems as the Australian Air Force—the same difficulties, if not more exacerbated than we have here in Australia.

The answer to the particular problem, because you raised a specific problem, is cooperation between the air force and CASA to make sure they have the planned needs of all round Australia. There is no advantage to CASA in the long run in taking away air force traffic controllers who control skies around Townsville, sector 8 around Sydney and whatever around Darwin because, if we cannot supply air traffic controllers, they will need to do that themselves.

The final point that we are looking at—we have not ruled out a retention bonus even though, as a principle, I prefer not to get into that area; I do not think it has ever been wildly successful in the past—is to restructure the career paths that people take. That may well have three streams over the future. The first is uniformed, across to civilian but staying within the air force, which would give more stability as a posting. That is, starting in uniform but eventually going to serve the air force under civilian conditions. The second stream may well be to go into the air force and eventually go into the CASA operation. The third stream will be those who want to stay in uniform all the way through their careers and provide the future leadership.

Those sorts of specialist areas will present a challenge to Defence as long as we remain one of the great training institutions in this country. Some of the other institutions in this country will have to learn to do more of the training themselves than they have in the past rather than trying to poach off the air force or some other military unit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer but, of course, he does not address the loss of experience, simply the need to recruit more people which, of course, does not give him experience levels. I ask the minister by way of supplementary question: is it correct that the number of air traffic controllers lost to the RAAF is in the order of 60 to 70 and that not all of them have gone into air traffic control jobs in the civilian sector? Is it also correct that sector 8 based at Sydney, which controls Richmond, should have 11 people but currently has only five? Is it also correct that RAAF Pearce should have more than a dozen approach controllers for its day shift and may be down to just two by the middle of next year? Is this the magnitude of the problem? Does the minister have any sense of urgency about it? I did not see any indication of that from his laid-back answer.

—It is rather ironical that we get the more substantive questions as supplementaries—five questions to be answered in a minute. In terms of sector 8 et cetera, the action we have taken is to sit down with CASA to make sure that these areas will not be deprived if people move out.

PARA.TAB: You are right to suggest that some people have moved out of air traffic control completely into other careers but that is natural. They are doing that in the civilian and the military areas. People do change careers. Not everyone will stay in the same career all their lives. That is the trend of modern society. There was nothing in my answer that was intended to mislead by saying they were all going to CASA. Some just go out and create a new career.

The point that you have made—that it is not just a matter of the overall numbers but the loss of some of the more experienced people—is right. It is crucial that you do not lose your most experienced people, those who will be training and developing those new recruits through. That is where our efforts are being concentrated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans. I refer to the announcement yesterday of the Prime Minister's initiative for a nuclear weapons free world. Whilst I welcome Mr Keating's apparent conversion to the peace cause, I ask: do the comments in relation to the cessation of the production of fissile material outlined in yesterday's media package indicate that the government is prepared to reconsider its position in relation to uranium exports? Does the minister agree that the quid pro quo in the nuclear non-proliferation treaty with respect to the provision of uranium and nuclear technology to NPT signatories actually provides for the potential for a non-weapons state to quickly move to nuclear weapons capability and that this reality will require the Canberra Commission to totally reassess the effectiveness of the NPT as a vehicle for the elimination of nuclear weapons?

—I am glad that Senator Margetts supports the Canberra Commission on the Elimination of Nuclear Weapons. We even had a grudging acknowledgment of its utility from Alexander Downer, which is a world first, and I thank him for that. I thank Senator Margetts for her support.

PARA.TAB: I think it is potentially one of the most important initiatives that Australia has ever taken in the sense that, if we can craft an agenda for the step-by-step reduction of nuclear weapons—presently, there are 50,000 warheads at large in the world—maintaining security as we go and creating a situation ultimately of zero, and hopefully sooner rather than later, then we will have made a massive contribution to making this world a safer and saner place. I believe that that objective is not only desirable but attainable. I hope very much, and I expect, that this commission, comprising an array of extraordinarily highly qualified people, will make a major contribution to setting that agenda moving forward.

As to the implications of all of this for the production of fissile material and other matters, including the export of uranium, certainly one of the things that it is hoped the commission will consider is the virtues of a convention for the cut-off on the production of fissile material, thus ensuring that no further such material is produced in the future. That should not be too hard a convention to actually negotiate—and preliminary steps are being taken toward that at the moment—because the truth of the matter is that none of the existing declared nuclear weapon states, including France, are presently engaged in the production of fissile material.

That consideration ought to put at rest a concern that was expressed again, I think, last week by a number of members and senators about the possibility of Australia's—or anyone else's, for that matter—uranium notwithstanding the safeguards system, ending up in the production of military fissile material. The truth of the matter is that there are no grounds for concern about that because existing stockpiles, unhappily, are so extensive that, as far as I know—and certainly this is true for France because it has been publicly confirmed—no such material is being produced nor has it been since 1992.

So, under those circumstances, there does not seem to be any case at all for concern about the way in which the IAEA safeguards system is working under the existing nuclear non-proliferation treaty. The NPT, whichever way you look at it, will go on being an absolutely crucial element in the total equation if we are ever to achieve a nuclear weapons free world, as I certainly hope we can.

The notion that there is somehow something not very helpful about the NPT, which seems to run through a lot of questions that come out of the Greens and others in the community, really does quite fundamentally miss the point. As I have said on many previous occasions, without it I think we would have been looking at a world with 25 or 30 nuclear weapons possessors at the moment rather than the five declared states that we have at the moment plus, of course, a small number of threshold or twilight zone states.

As unsatisfactory as the present situation may be from a number of different points of view—and I do not think anyone could be totally comfortable with all aspects of it, in particular the attitude of some of the nuclear weapons powers—nonetheless, it is far and away the best system that we have. It was crucially important that the NPT be extended indefinitely, as it was in April, and that is one of the foundation stones on which, undoubtedly, the Canberra Commission will be building as it erects its plan for achieving a nuclear free world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Don't count your chickens, Minister. Despite statements to indicate that the government believes nuclear weapons are illegal under international law, the proposed terms of reference of the Canberra Commission specifically call for the `maintenance of stable deterrence'. Won't the nuclear weapons states and the threshold states perceive that Australia is once again dancing to the tune of the nuclear weapons states?

—As I have exceedingly patiently sought to explain on previous occasions, those propositions are not inconsistent. If you are talking about deterrence into the hereafter, or strengthened deterrence, as Monsieur Chirac and Mr Major were in their joint communique a few weeks ago, you would have much to complain about. But if you are talking about maintaining a system of balanced deterrence while the world moves back to zero, ensuring that in the process there is no great disparity between the nuclear weaponry available to the major powers, you are simply talking good sense.

PARA.TAB: In the submission that I made to the World Court arguing for the illegality of weapons here and now, it was a corollary to that submission that the court make a finding, make a direction, that in achieving the reduction of nuclear weapons it was not an obligation for any state that could do so to do it overnight but, in honouring its commitment required by customary international law, we argued, to zero, it could sensibly get there step by step and it should sensibly get there in an environment where the balanced deterrence principle was maintained. They are not incompatible propositions and I think that is very well understood. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to statements on Friday by Labor Party politician Mr Graham Campbell in which he said the real Australian was Anglo-Celtic, that a racist was someone who won an argument with a multiculturalist and that Australia was about to be overwhelmed by Asian migration. He also asked Australians Against Further Immigration to direct their preferences to the Labor Party. Will the Prime Minister now ensure that Mr Campbell is disendorsed as the Labor candidate for Kalgoorlie at the next election?

—How the Labor Party treats its own is none of your business, Senator O'Chee, nor will it ever be. How we react publicly to statements of this kind is, however, something that should be put on the public record and I say frankly I react to them with nothing short of disgust. They are utterly at odds with the principles that have been articulated by the Labor Party over many years. They are absolutely at odds with the current policy of the party and no doubt this is an issue that will be further considered by the party in the light of what I have just said.

—On a supplementary question: earlier this year the Prime Minister accused the Leader of the Opposition of being weak because he did not sack a coalition senator fast enough. Given that we know that the Prime Minister lacks the courage and the strength to sack Mr Campbell, and it is now quite obvious that the Prime Minister would rather tolerate Mr Campbell within the federal parliamentary Labor Party than take a stand against bigotry, I ask: what credibility can the Prime Minister's statement on multiculturalism have this coming Friday? Why should anybody believe a party that has such blatant double standards on racial tolerance and discrimination?

—The senator to which you are referring was, as I understand it, an office holder within the party. That is not the case for Mr Campbell. He is unlikely to ever hold an office of any significance within the parliamentary party or within the parliament, I think. Under those circumstances, the options available to the Prime Minister are extremely limited. He can only operate within the parameters of the party institutions, namely the National Executive of the party. No doubt that is an issue that will be further considered by the National Executive, as it has been in the past.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. Minister, I recall that in August this year at the meeting of agricultural ministers you launched the rural partnership program. I know this program gives rural communities the opportunity to put together proposals for change which reflect the key issues that they face. Can you inform the Senate of the progress of this program and which communities are now benefiting from this approach?

—Certainly. I would be glad to provide the Senate with that information. Perhaps Senator McGauran can tell us what he is doing over there in providing us with some information. Are you going to launch those, Jules?
—They are Senator Brownhill's.
