—Oh, they are Senator Brownhill's papers—it is very distracting. The rural partnership program was designed to transform the way governments do business with rural Australia. It provides an opportunity for communities to put their collective knowledge, skills and experience together to deliver sustainable development in their regions. The program has been developed cooperatively through ARMCANZ—that is, with all of the other ministers for primary industry, regardless of their political affiliations—and it is designed to address nationally significant agricultural and resource management, social and environmental issues.

PARA.TAB: Its most fundamental element is a recognition that people who are living and working in rural areas know more about what should be done to guarantee a sustainable future for that region than anyone else. It follows that these people are best placed to develop future strategies in cooperation and with sometimes the necessary support that governments can provide.

Partnership proposals are actively being negotiated at the moment, or have actually been implemented, in south-west Queensland, the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia, the central west and western divisions of New South Wales, the Gascoyne-Murchison region of Western Australia, and the Sunraysia and Myrtleford regions in Victoria. I am pleased to advise the Senate that today I have approved a federal government contribution to the Atherton tablelands region to begin work on restructuring and development of that region in light of the decline in the tobacco industry there.

It is useful, I think, to highlight the real effort that this government is making to demonstrate its commitment to regional development because it stands in stark contrast to the policy alternatives that are being provided by the federal coalition—and, of course, most succinctly in that now infamous document produced by the shadow minister for regional development, Senator Ian Macdonald. That had as its bottom line that the coalition will make commitments giving them the `flexibility of announcing a lot of major long-term visionary matters', but without committing the coalition to actually proceeding with them.

In light of this policy document from Senator Ian Macdonald, I must say that I was intrigued to receive a question on notice from Senator Macdonald recently in respect of another regional initiative, which this government is providing substantial funds for—and that is the Wimmera Mallee pipeline.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you answered his question?
—I will answer the question.
—Have you answered it?

—I will answer his question. But it was an intriguing question, the first one I have got in this sort of style. The question asked—question on notice No. 2539—`Could the Wimmera Mallee pipeline be completed without federal government assistance?' One assumes that this project will go to the top of the policy mirage created by Senator Macdonald for regional Australia. This, of course, stands in stark contrast to the actual funding of this pipeline by this government. It would appear that Senator Macdonald now wants the government, through questions on notice—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think it is abundantly clear that we are not getting an answer to the question here. Senator Collins has virtually conceded that he will get back to answering the question when he is ready. If you are going to assert any authority on the matter, I would have thought this a perfect opportunity to do it. Let us have answers to questions, and not opportunities for ministers to simply put things on the table which are utterly irrelevant.
—Order! As I have indicated before, the minister has already answered the question. He is entitled to develop his answer if he wishes to, provided he keeps within the broad area.

—I will conclude by saying that it now appears that Senator Macdonald wants the government, through questions on notice, to identify regional development initiatives that meet the coalition's criteria for announcements. (Time expired)

—I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Noting the minister's self-righteous concern in alleging conflict of interest for practising journalists working for senior politicians, I ask: is it a fact that Mr Hendrik Gout, Editor of the Public Sector Review, has been in Canberra working for Senator Bolkus while still working for the Public Sector Review? Will the minister provide the details of Mr Gout's current employment in his office? Did Mr Gout inform his review readership of his current dual role as editor of the paper and with the minister?

—I will very gladly make available whatever details of the working relationship I have with Hendrik Gout or he has with me. In respect of his activities with the union movement, he and I share a very solid and strong defence of the public sector and that brings us together on this particular issue. In terms of any ongoing relationship with that magazine, I think it is something he is working out. I am sure he will be putting forward the facts of that as he defines that relationship. In terms of my working relationship with Hendrik Gout, I will come very much to the fore and I will not be forging any overtime documents on his behalf.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to the City Link tollway project backed by the Kennett Victorian government. I ask: Minister, do you agree that a project with significant environmental consequences and which will attract up to $600 million in federal government tax concessions should be the subject of an environmental impact statement under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974? Has the Treasurer or the Development Allowance Authority approached your department to request that an environmental impact statement on the project be prepared under that act? As the minister responsible for that act, will you be insisting that a proper assessment is done before any federal government money is sunk into this project—a project which the Victorian government has exempted from much of its own environmental protection and town planning requirements?

—In July 1994, the Victorian government announced details about the Melbourne City Link proposal. At that stage the project included the construction of a southern bypass connecting the Westgate freeway to the south eastern arterial and a western bypass connecting the Tullamarine freeway to the Westgate freeway. The state government later decided to upgrade and widen the Tullamarine freeway between Flemington Road and Bulla Road as part of the proposal.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act has not been triggered in relation to the Tullamarine freeway project. I understand that legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department to the Development Allowance Authority is that the EPIP Act does not apply to decisions by the authority in relation to the granting of infrastructure bonds or to development allowance.

In the event that a Commonwealth decision or action is required that is in fact subject to the act, the action minister must decide whether a proposal is likely to be environmentally significant and, if so, to refer it to the Environment Protection Agency. The Environment Protection Agency would then provide advice to me so that I could make a decision about the level of environmental assessment that was warranted if in fact environmental assessment was warranted.

Any such determination would take account of the potential environmental impacts and the adequacy of any state assessment processes that had been undertaken. At this stage of course I cannot speculate on Commonwealth environmental assessment requirements because of the situation that I have outlined.

The general principle that you raise is an important one. I think you have seen a very strong commitment on the part of this government and me, as the environment minister, to ensure that proposals or developments that are environmentally significant are subject to the appropriate level of environmental assessment. That is a position I will not be resiling from, nor will the government. The situation in relation to the triggering of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act is as I have outlined. It is a matter that is absolutely appropriate for the Victorian government to progress to full and thorough assessment of the environmental implications of the project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you say the Attorney-General has given you advice that EPIP is not triggered. Are you aware of the legal advice obtained by some of your Labor Party colleagues and quoted in the Sunday Age which indicates that if the federal government grants tax concessions it does become legally involved in the project and is required by law to fully examine the environmental impacts of the project? Are you aware of that advice? Why is it inferior to the Attorney-General's advice? Which advice are you going to act on?

—I certainly am aware of the very strong level of concern there is amongst members of the federal Labor caucus and the Labor Party more generally in relation to this proposal. There are very significant concerns. I have indicated to you what the situation is in relation to the advice of the Attorney-General's Department to the Development Allowance Authority. As far as my role is concerned as the environment minister, it is appropriate for me to act if and when this matter is designated.
—Why is there conflicting advice from your colleagues?

—I think most people understand that that is the situation, Senator, but I can assure you that the very strong level of commitment that my colleagues and I have in relation to a proper and adequate level of environmental assessment for this important project is not diminished regardless of the fact that the first and primary responsibility for that assessment lies with the Victorian government. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the government's latest cruel hoax—a report to be released by the employment minister suggesting that the government's five per cent unemployment target by the year 2000 will require economic growth of 3.5 per cent a year throughout the decade of the 1990s. Given that this government has only managed to average about 2.5 per cent a year economic growth over the first half of the decade and that you are busy slowing the economy down, isn't it simply preposterous to suggest the government has a snowflake's hope in hell of achieving the necessary 4.5 per cent a year average growth over the second half of this decade?

—For a snowflake in hell, we are not doing a real bad job, according to the Economist this week, where Australia was forecast to be the fastest growing economy of the major 15 OECD countries in 1996. That, of course, would be a continuation of the record that we have been able to achieve so far. Employment will continue to grow during the rest of 1995 and 1996 and thereafter because the outlook for economic growth remains very robust indeed.

PARA.TAB: We see the recent levelling off in employment as only a temporary pause, reflecting a lag response, as Senator Cook has already said today, in the labour market to the slowing in economic growth to a more sustainable rate since late 1994. We are not trying to slow the economy down any further than we did. We did, of course, take the view it was unsustainable at six per cent plus. That view, I think, was universally shared. It had to come back to about the 3 1/2 to four per cent range. That is where we hope to have it and to keep it.

Employment growth in 1995-96 is still expected to be broadly in line with the budget forecast of three per cent, with the unemployment rate being expected to fall throughout the rest of 1995-96. The job vacancy rate still remains at a high level by historic standards. That is a key indicator of continuing employment growth.

We have got, in accord VIII, a specific union commitment on employment growth. Under the new accord the government and the ACTU are committed to creating in excess of 600,000 jobs by March 1999. We have a strong endorsement for the Working Nation objective from the accord. Throughout the last period, and particularly since the last election, the track record of this government has been extraordinarily strong on employment. We fully expect that process to continue in the future and the unemployment figures to come out in the way we have forecast as being perfectly possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume Senator Evans is referring to the same Economist magazine that reports Australia as having the highest inflation in the world, the third highest interest rates in the world and the fifth highest youth unemployment rate in the world. I refer him to the Business Review Weekly, which last week showed, in a survey done by Access Economics, that out of all the OECD nations, only two had unemployment that was actually rising. Bearing in mind that Australia's teen jobless rate is 29 per cent, which is much higher than it was when the Working Nation policies were first introduced, I ask the minister: don't all of these indicators simply prove beyond any doubt whatsoever that your government has no answers for Australia's employment woes or economic woes and that it really is time for a change of government?

—It is simply not the case that unemployment is rising. One quarter's figures do not a total story tell. The overall trends are what are important. The unemployment rate of 8.7 per cent in October was well below the peak of 11.1 per cent in October 1993. The unemployment rate fell by 0.4 in the 12 months to October 1995. The number of unemployed in October was 18.2 per cent below the peak that was recorded in October 1993. Most importantly of all in that litany, the unemployment rate is expected to fall further to eight per cent by the June quarter next year.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 November, Senator Campbell asked me as the Minister representing the Prime Minister a question without notice about the release of a prime ministerial youth statement on youth unemployment and youth suicide. I undertook to obtain an answer for Senator Campbell. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

This Government has a very strong commitment to the youth of Australia. Throughout the term of this Government we have given high priority to issues affecting young people and have put in place key initiatives in areas like education, training, employment, social justice and civics. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has recently completed Working Nation consultations with young people throughout Australia to determine their attitudes on a whole range of youth employment issues and we will pay close attention to the results.
Although I have given no undertaking to deliver a Youth Statement, the Government will continue to develop policies which address the needs and concerns of young Australians.

In terms of Senator Campbell's claim that youth unemployment is 29%, this is the rate for 15-19 year olds looking for full-time work (seasonally adjusted). The official unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds, as measured by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, is 19.6% (October 1995, original data). In May 1994, when the Government announced Working Nation, the full-time unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds was 32.6% (seasonally adjusted), while the unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds was 23.2% (original data).

With regard to Senator Campbell's reference to the rate of youth suicide, the Government is committed to addressing this issue and has provided some $13m in the 1995-96 Budget for the Youth Suicide Prevention Strategy over four years. This is the first national response to this serious problem. Pilot projects have also been initiated, with the aim of reducing the rate of youth suicides. These target young people within the high risk category, and aim to make services more responsive to the needs of young people in social and emotional crisis. Best practice in youth suicide prevention is also being merged into mainstream health care.

However, we should not exaggerate the problem. Figures in the 1995 Department of Human Services and Health monograph Youth Suicide in Australia indicate that between 1979 and 1993 the male youth suicide rate has climbed by almost 50 per cent—not doubled as asserted by the Senator. The female youth suicide rate and the overall Australian rate for the same period has remained stable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —After question time on 23 November Senators Harradine and Herron invited me to reconsider a ruling which I made during the course of question time to the effect that the use of the name of a senator or a member of the House of Representatives with the implication that a senator was a liar is contrary to standing order 193. I have reconsidered my ruling and I believe that I was correct to intervene in the way that I did. Standing order 193 prohibits offensive words, imputations of improper motives and personal reflections in relation to senators, members of other houses and certain other office holders.

PARA.TAB: My predecessors have consistently ruled that it is contrary to standing order 193 to make any suggestion that a senator has lied—that is, deliberately and knowingly made untrue statements. Past Presidents' rulings have pointed out that it is not out of order to state that a senator's statements are untrue or misleading. The offence is constituted not by contradiction of another senator's statement, but the implication that a senator has deliberately or knowingly made untrue statements. As one of my predecessors ruled:

SPEECH.PARA: It is for the chair to judge whether this implication is present in any particular instance.

Past rulings have pointed out that expressions which may otherwise be acceptable are disorderly when, in their context, they carry the offensive implication that a senator has lied. The rulings to which I have referred are listed at page 232 of the printed version of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, the 7th edition.

PARA.TAB: During question time on 23 November, Senator Ian Macdonald interjected to Senator Cook: `You will just do a Carmen on it'. It was clear from the context of this remark that the senator was using the name of a member as a substitute for a direct accusation that Senator Cook would deliberately make false statements. Subsequently, I required Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Bob Collins to withdraw expressions in which they sought to use the name of Senator Ian Macdonald in the same way.

I emphasise that the offence against standing order 193 that was contained in these expressions was the implication that senators told lies. Where that implication is present, the expression is disorderly regardless of what substitute words are used. Senators have often used substitute expressions to try to get around the prohibition on accusations of lying.

It is obvious that the chair must intervene when this device is used because otherwise the prohibition could be more or less openly flouted. In order to uphold the standing orders and the standard of debate, I will continue to intervene when it is clear that a substitute expression is being used to subvert the prohibition and to make the forbidden implication that senators are lying.

In the course of question time, Senator Ian Macdonald referred to an answer to a question by Senator Gareth Evans as `coming from the leader of the party that is seen as the greatest mob of liars in history'. As that remark clearly implied that Senator Evans and his colleagues in the Senate are liars, I required Senator Macdonald to withdraw the remark. In the noise which followed, interjections by Senator Macdonald and others, most of which are not recorded in Hansard, persuaded me that Senator Macdonald had not said what in fact he had said and is recorded in Hansard. I therefore did not persist with the requirement for a withdrawal. Senator Macdonald's expression, however, was clearly disorderly.

Rulings of my predecessors have made it quite clear that words which are offensive when used against a particular senator are equally as offensive, if not more offensive, when used against a group of senators. Again, the past rulings are recorded at page 232 of Odgers.

In concluding this statement, I observe that the Senate has been extremely unruly during question time in recent weeks, and it has not been possible for the chair, in the general disorder, to censure every disorderly expression. I simply say to senators, as I have said on previous occasions, that the recent behaviour of some of them during question time is bringing both those senators and the institution into disrepute. I again appeal for appropriate standards of debate and conduct to be restored to our proceedings.

Few senators have not complained at some time about the low standing in which MPs and senators are held by the public, yet in the one hour of question time each day the activities of a few senators—and I mean only a few—does more to diminish that standing than most other activities at other times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I would like to ask a question of you to amplify the meaning of your statement. Does it mean that your statement, in fact, means that you regard the word `Carmen' as synonymous with `lying'?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that is quite clearly no, and it is obviously no.
—Therefore, it is not an offensive use of the language?
—I have made it quite clear. I suggest you go away and read the statement. It will be quite clear to you, Senator.
—I listened to it very carefully. That is the reason for the question, Mr President.
—It is a nonsense question. Let me tell you that.
—Thank you, Mr President.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As I recall it, why we took exception last week to your statement was that you said that a reference to a senator would be construed in a particular manner. If you had gone on and said `a reference which contains an adverse inference or imputation—
—Not even a bush lawyer can save her!

—This is very important, because I have heard this President on a number of occasions get to his feet and lecture us about politicians being held in very low esteem. I simply want to say this: if you want a real understanding of why that might be the case, you ought to reflect on the fact that we are like any other citizens. When an issue is put to us which we think is exaggerated or where we think the logic does not follow or where we take a point of order and we ask for a ruling, we would normally expect that there will be some logic in the answer.

PARA.TAB: You cannot simply say in answer to a point of order on relevance, `I rule that that is not relevant,' or, `I put down your point of order,' without giving any reasons and without in a sense engaging the questioner, as your two predecessors have done in this place—and I have served under both Senators Doug McClelland and Kerry Sibraa. Each of those Presidents were conspicuous by their willingness to respond constructively to points of order. We did not expect them to give us 51 per cent and the other side 49—indeed, we would probably have settled for 70-30—but what I do say is that they were able to control this chamber because of their willingness to provide answers that made some sense.

If you are simply going to dismissively ignore points of order or give answers to questions which suggest that you are not serious about the content of your answers, then you will get what others would expect. I simply say to you: this was yet another example of a situation in which the words you used were so general that they invited people to take issue with them. If you now, on reflection, appreciate what I am putting to you, what you should have said and what you should say now is that, where it is clear from the use of an expression that it is simply a subterfuge for inferring improper conduct, we can appreciate that proposition. But that is not what you said the other day, and you ought to think carefully about the way in which you respond to points of order on this side of the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, when you have made, as you have, a perfectly simple, straightforward and self-evidently compelling statement, you should not have to defend yourself from that sort of second-rate attack which would be out of place in Senator Alston's more natural forum, the Bundoora Magistrates Court, or wherever it is that he cut his teeth and where he still ought to be cutting them if that is the quality of his performance.

PARA.TAB: The point, Mr President, as you are acutely aware and as was perfectly evident in the terms of your statement, is that everything that is said in this place has a context. What determines whether or not it is colourable or unparliamentary is the context. When you responded as you did the other day you were responding to someone's name being used in a particular context which unequivocally conveyed imputations of an unhappy kind which were manifestly unparliamentary. It was in that context that you responded at the time. It is not necessary to spell out every detail of an innuendo and imputation when it is supremely self-evident to all those within your hearing as to what that innuendo or imputation is. You did not do so on that occasion because it was unnecessary.

In the terms of the statement you have just put down you have made it perfectly clear that it is the context that counts. You have said that very clearly in that statement. I am one of the persons who bore your wrath the other day when I joined in the debate using exactly the same utterly adolescent and discredited technique which was initiated on the other side, and you slapped me down accordingly. It was perfectly appropriate for you to do so. The terms of your statement are perfectly clear. Let us have no more of this nonsense. You do not need to defend yourself. It is a self-evidently compelling statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish in part to ask you a question and I also in part wish to make an observation. My understanding is that your ruling was not based on a particular name or an inference that that particular person has a reputation for telling untruths. It is a set of words used in the context of challenging somebody else's veracity that leads you to the conclusion that they are implying that the name used is the substitution for telling the truth or claiming an untruth. For instance, it is not a question of somebody having a reputation for telling untruths. There are people in the chamber, in my view, who do not have a reputation for telling untruths but deserve one. It might well be that the name `Carmen' could be substituted for `Sue'. But I take it that you are saying that no name is quarantined from your ruling. You are simply saying that if a name in the context is put in such a way as to draw the conclusion in the mind of a reasonable person that the inference is that a lie is to be told, that is to be ruled out of order. If that is what you are saying, I thoroughly agree.

PARA.TAB: I have never supported the use of the word `lie' in any context, notwithstanding the precedence set by my dear friend Bill Snedden in the other place when stared down by the then shadow minister for industrial relations, R.G. Hawke, later to be Prime Minister. I have always taken the view that it is unparliamentary language and ought not be allowed and there ought to be no way that any word which implies or implicitly suggests a lie ought to be accepted. I hope I say that in the context that I have had my share of criticism from my own side for being fair and impartial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, during the debate that has taken place I have had the opportunity to read page 232 of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, to which you referred. You are quite correct and, indeed, Senator Crichton-Browne is quite correct—that is, it is for the chair to judge whether that implication is present in any particular instance. Might I suggest to you, Mr President, that you create a very dangerous precedent for yourself and the other chairs in this Senate. For example, if during the course of an answer or a debate a minister or person on the other side is having difficulty recalling, for example, and somebody on this side were to suggest that that is akin to Carmen Lawrence, people in the chair may well feel that they have to rule that out of order. As soon as you suggest that a name becomes synonymous with a lie, you take away the possibility of using that name in the context of somebody having a bad memory or somebody being unable to recall.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I agree with the general thrust of your ruling as to the general implication, as soon as you make that ruling, you and all the other people that occupy the chair in this chamber will have to exercise their mind on every single occasion as to whether or not the name `Carmen Lawrence' is unparliamentary in that particular circumstance. Therefore, it is not appropriate to say that the use of `Carmen Lawrence' as an interjection is disorderly. It has to be in context.

As a result, the chair will now have to consider on each and every occasion whether or not whatever name is being used is reflective of a lie, of bad memory or of an incapacity to recall. I suggest to you that that creates a very difficult precedent for you, your successors and those who temporarily take the position of chair in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I thank you for your response to my letter. I do not believe that it answers the question that I posed in the letter. I will be studying your response carefully. I expect to be writing to you again for further reconsideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I should speak on the motion to take note or make these points in some other way. However, I have not read your statement. Unfortunately, I was not aware you were going to make it. My staff tells me that my name appeared perhaps more frequently than any other in your statement. That seems to be part of something that has been happening in this chamber in recent times.

PARA.TAB: I have not had the opportunity of fully reading what you have said, but I did hear, as I got back to my office, you say something in relation to my comment—and I have just had a look at the Hansard, where I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . coming from the leader of the party that is seen as the greatest mob of liars in history, that is a bit rich.

You said, `Order! Withdraw that.' The Hansard records me then saying, `What did I say?' According to the Hansard, you said, `Unless I misheard you, you called the other side of the house liars,' and I am recorded as saying, `What I said is allowed.'

PARA.TAB: As I recall your statement, and you might correct me if I am wrong, you then said that there was a great deal of noise coming from this side which Senator Macdonald was part of and most of it is not recorded. If you did say that, Mr President, that is totally untruthful and I demand from you an apology.

You might recall that I was standing on my feet trying to ask my supplementary question. There was noise. It was not from me. I am not being sensitive about this, but your statement does mention me so many times that I get the feeling that perhaps I should be a little sensitive about these things. I was not speaking at that time; I was standing here. There may have been other noise.

The imputation in your statement, as I recall what you said—I have not had the opportunity of reading it because it has not been published and, as I say, I was not told that you were going to be making this statement—was that I was shouting at that particular time. I may have been shouting at you at other times, but on that time I was not so that is incorrect. If that was the imputation in your statement, I ask you to apologise and correct it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly in response, I did quite clearly define the reasons last week for the decision that I had taken. I repeated that definition, having considered it, in the statement that I just made. I suggest that all senators read it.

PARA.TAB: On Senator Abetz's point, it is not a problem, in my opinion. Senator, your contribution was constructive but I do not think it is a problem. The context is the thing that is important. It is quite clear to me that some contexts are breaking rule 193 when they substitute for the word `liar' the name of a person and that substitution is clearly designed to flout the standing order. There are others where it is equally clearly not the case. As in all things, context is important and the judgment of the chair must come to bear.
On Senator Macdonald's point: the statement I did make was:

SPEECH.PARA: In the noise which followed, interjections by Senator Macdonald and others, most of which are not recorded in Hansard, persuaded me that Senator Macdonald had not said what in fact he said and is recorded in Hansard. I therefore did not persist with the requirement for a withdrawal.

There were a number of interjections trying to clarify the issue of what you had said. As for picking you out, I deny that. I suggest that you look carefully at your own record. That might settle things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you say `interjections by Senator Macdonald and others, most of which—
—You have already spoken to this statement.
—You are stopping me speaking?
—No. If you want to seek leave, seek leave.
—Mr President, I seek leave to query the statement you have just made.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying `interjections by Senator Macdonald and others'. That suggested that I was interjecting quite a lot while you were speaking. I am saying to you that that is simply not correct. If you get a copy of the television tape, you will see that that is correct. I do not know what it shows. I was standing here, trying to ask a question. I am not unduly sensitive about this—
—Or about anything else.

—Thank you, Gary. Mr President, what I have said, which you might call an interjection, is recorded in Hansard. The suggestion you make is, I think, unfair. I do not accuse you of this, but there is an orchestrated campaign by Gary and the rest of his team. I would hate you to be drawn into that campaign by the way you responded here.
—In direct response: it was my clear recollection, and the recollection of the clerks who advised me.

—Mr President, on a point of order: in the course of Senator Macdonald's remarks he said quite clearly that he was taking exception to your criticism of him on that occasion. He went on to say, `I might have been guilty of loud interjections on other occasions, but I was not on this occasion.' That was the thrust of his remarks. He invited you to respond to that.

PARA.TAB: Your response to it was, effectively: look at your own track record. I interpret that as meaning, `I am not prepared even to argue about what you said or did on this occasion, but because of other events you are therefore guilty on this occasion.' That is precisely the faulty logic that causes us to erupt.

If you want to say to him, `You are wrong. I have a clear recollection, and I disagree with you,' or, `Let's agree to disagree,' or, `I cannot remember, but that is how it seemed to me,' I would understand. When he goes out of his way to say, `I might have on other occasions but I did not here,' and you are effectively saying, `I do not care what you did on this occasion. You have done it in the past,' that breaks all the norms of presumptions of innocence or the way in which people respond to arguments.

That is why we have difficulties with your rulings. You do not address the issues. You very quickly resort to ad hominem attacks, as that was. You rely on what you call the context of an answer to justify meandering and irrelevant answers on many occasions, in our view. You never deal with the issues themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —In brief response to that: I made it clear that it was my clear understanding that Senator Macdonald, along with others, was interjecting. That was the recollection of the clerks. I will go back and look at it. The more general comment was in relation to the more general concern that Senator Macdonald had. I made that with no malice, and I do not bear any malice to anybody.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Can you just clarify for us whether the taking note of your answer is proposed to be taken out of the 30 minutes or not?
—No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) this day, relating to industrial relations in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The substance of that question was to get a response from the government with regard to the fear and loathing campaign which is outlined in a document, which fell off the back of a truck last week, from the South Australian United Trades and Labour Council. What has just occurred in this place highlights the types of tactics being used now in the parliamentary scene that are emanating from the Labor Party which create a situation whereby there is a reaction from this side of politics to the dishonesty that is being perpetrated in politics today.

PARA.TAB: We read through this particular document and we find such comments as, `There are a range of specific federal campaigns which unions, the ACTU, the UTLC are involved in.' They mention Western Australia, CRA and others. Going further into this particular document we find that it also makes reference to running a `fear and loathing campaign on individual contracts. That we must define the scope of the message very clearly and stick to it'.

It has nothing to do with the merit of the case that the Labor Party might have to run or the merit of the case that we might have to run; it is to totally run a deliberately dishonest campaign with regard to what exists. We look further into the document and find that it says that the initial idea is to play on the mood of `tide of change' and `uncertain et cetera'. It says, `Hidden cameras in boss's office has boss threatening workers with new contracts or else; details of contract are out of focus.' That is what is in this particular document.

It makes one wonder about the answer from Senator Gareth Evans to my question last week. He said that the problem with CRA was that they offer too large a carrot. His exact words were, `Initially through the offering of large sized carrots.' That is what the minister said last week. On that occasion Senator Evans was absolutely accurate. But we are being confronted with this fear and loathing campaign which is based on the total misrepresentation of what the truths are and what the fact of a particular matter is.

It is quite shameful what the South Australian Trades and Labour Council is doing, or what the Western Australian Labour Council is doing or the backing that is coming from this particular government in terms of that campaign. It is time they came clean on their particular campaigns—more honest about what the situations were and not have this fear and loathing campaign which exists.

I hope some of them had a look yesterday at the Sunday program and the interviews that were done up at Hamersley, a subsidiary of CRA. I want to quote what people said; they are not their exact words. They spoke to a contract worker. What did he say? He said, `No longer do we leave our brains on the gate post as we go to work.' They spoke to a unionist. He said, `It has been good for us. No strikes, record free injury time and more money.' That was from a unionist who said, `We do not want to go onto the contract, but we work here and it is good for us.'

As we work through this whole process of what is happening in this campaign—first of all in Western Australia—we see in today's Newcastle Herald that the coal strikers reached 105 days at Vickery. One has to put to the government: how many times has the AIRC ordered them back to work? As Senator Evans, sitting across there, knows, on a significant number of times. But the government has been absolutely quiet. There has not been a squeak out of them in terms of saying, `Hey, boys, it's about time you obeyed the rules of the particular umpire.' So I am bringing this point to the attention of the Senate.

I conclude by saying that I think this is probably the lowest the Labor Party, in conjunction with the union movement, has stooped in terms of dealing with a particular political situation. This proposed campaign should be condemned totally outright and it is about time the Labor Party became a little bit honest about what they are doing and got back to dealing with issues on their merit.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Chee this day, relating to comments made by the Member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) concerning immigration.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that the member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, is a member of the government that gave us the Racial Hatred Bill, that Mr Campbell is a member of the government which has berated the opposition, that Mr Campbell is a member of the same government which, on Thursday, in an appalling stunt, attempted to rewrite history over the white Australia policy that their party invented. Mr Campbell is somebody who has consistently and wilfully singled out different ethnic groups in this country to receive his bile, bigotry and hatred. It is about time, in the 1990s, that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) showed the tiniest touch of leadership about the way in which the Australian Labor Party is run.

PARA.TAB: In answer to my question today, Senator Gareth Evans said, `How we deal with these things is none of your business.' It is our business. Mr Campbell went to Australians Against Further Immigration to spread not only bigotry and hatred but also to ask for their preferences to be directed to the Labor Party. What did Mr Campbell say to Australians Against Further Immigration? He said, `There are other people in the Labor Party just like me; that is why you should give us your preferences.'

TALK.START.PARA: —One or two.
—Who are the others?
—In the entire membership of the party.

—No, in the federal parliamentary party. The bigotry of the other side on these matters is thoroughly unacceptable. It is our business that the standards that people expect of members of parliament are adhered to. It is the business of every single member of the parliament to fight against hatred and intolerance. That is what we on this side of the chamber seek to do.

PARA.TAB: What Mr Campbell did was an insult to every ethnic Greek, ethnic Italian, ethnic Chinese, ethnic Indian, ethnic Yugoslav in this country—an insult to everybody who is not Anglo-Celtic—because, in Mr Campbell's view of the world, you are not a real Australian unless you are Anglo-Celtic.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am Anglo-Saxon.

—`Anglo-Celtic' is what he said, Senator Bell. What that says to probably half the population of this country is that they can never truly be Australian. It has always been my understanding that being Australian was a thing that was inclusive not exclusive. A person was a good Australian based on the quality of their character, not the colour of their skin. Yet Mr Campbell wishes to continue with this idea and the Prime Minister, through his silence, gives tacit support to Mr Campbell's bigotry.

PARA.TAB: That is what disturbs me. It is our business. I do not care what the Prime Minister says to Mr Campbell behind closed doors. Australians demand that the Prime Minister stand up in public against intolerance, against hatred and against Mr Campbell. But the Prime Minister is too weak and too cowardly to do it. The Prime Minister will not make a stand—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think you should withdraw that imputation.

—I withdraw. The Prime Minister is too weak and too lacking in moral fortitude to stand up against Mr Campbell and his ilk. The Prime Minister is quite happy for Mr Campbell to canvass preferences for the Labor Party but he will not stand up against him on a matter of principle. It is quite clear that Mr Keating would rather tolerate Mr Campbell's presence in the parliamentary Labor Party than stand up for what is right and decent in this country. That is why Mr Campbell should go. If Mr Campbell does not go, Mr Keating should tender his own resignation to the Australian people as somebody unfit to hold the high office which he currently occupies.

—I would also like to address this matter. I was very disappointed to hear the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, say what he did last Saturday in Sydney. The point I really want to take up is one which Senator O'Chee mentioned, and that is Mr Campbell's saying that the real Australia was Anglo-Celtic. I take exceptional offence to that. Perhaps Mr Campbell would be right in saying that Australia was Anglo-Celtic—`was,' past tense—but it certainly is not now.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the Italian community, between the first, second and third generations it could have up to a 15 per cent influence in Australia. Even if the number is less, it still has that great an influence in industries such as building and farming, and even in politics these days. I am not talking just about myself. There is an Italian in Perth who is a member of the Western Australian parliament and a minister. There are others around the country who, I believe, have also contributed to the nation. By Senator Campbell's definition, probably even Senator Schacht is not a real Australian, so he should berate Mr Campbell for his comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know whether four generations count or not.

—Fourth generation Germans might have half the influence the Italians have. The point is this: Senator Evans was asked why the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has not called for the disendorsement of Mr Campbell as the Labor candidate for the next election. I am sure that the Prime Minister will not call for Mr Campbell's disendorsement because he knows that Mr Campbell would probably still win as an Independent. There would be a greater chance for the Liberal Party should Mr Campbell be disendorsed, but he would have a fair chance of being re-elected as an Independent and the Prime Minister would not take that chance.

PARA.TAB: But I am wondering whether the agenda goes beyond that. I could be wrong in saying what I am about to say but I wonder if the government is not happy to have Mr Campbell letting the media call him irrelevant or whatever else they like to think about him. I do not think that he is irrelevant in Kalgoorlie, I am afraid to say. I live in the electorate of Kalgoorlie and I do not think that Mr Campbell is irrelevant there. But I am wondering whether the government is not happy to have Mr Campbell there to canvas these issues. If there were some Australians who think that Labor's immigration policy is not what they want, they would see Mr Campbell as their saviour. Perhaps that is why the Prime Minister is not prepared to call for Mr Campbell's disendorsement.

I hasten to say again that I hope that I am wrong in that assessment. But Mr Campbell is there and Mr Keating has not yet said anything about him, to my knowledge. I heard what Senator Evans said at question time but, to my knowledge, the Prime Minister has said nothing. Perhaps he is happy to leave Mr Campbell there. He did ask for preferences from Australians Against Further Immigration. It is now up to the Prime Minister to rule out what I have suggested is the case and to do something about Mr Campbell.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator West this day, relating to family assistance payments.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the second occasion on which Senator Crowley has used a question from the Labor Party to try to demonise the Lyons Forum. I simply want to set the record straight—it is unfortunate that we need to set the record straight—by outlining, yet again, what the Lyons Forum is all about. It is a group of members and senators of the federal Liberal and National parties who have adopted the following statement as its motto: the foundation of a nation's greatness is in the homes of its people. That sentiment is accepted by me and all other members of the Lyons Forum.

PARA.TAB: As its contribution to the International Year of the Family, the Lyons Forum embarked upon hearings throughout the Commonwealth of Australia. Such luminaries as now Senator Jacinta Collins, who was representing the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees' Association, made contributions to the hearing. What the document Empowering Australian Families, published by the Lyons Forum, did was to set out in summary form a whole host of submissions put to them.

The only submissions the forum adopted are shown on page vii under the heading `Executive summary'. There is no mention whatsoever in the Lyons Forum recommendations of a French quotient system, to which Senator Crowley referred. The French quotient system, to which Senator Crowley referred, is part of a section in this report entitled `Macroeconomic reform'. There were some other things mentioned under that heading, such as Julian Disney's comment:

SPEECH.PARA: There can be little doubt that, at present, many one-income families are treated unfairly under the taxation system by comparison with two-income families.

This is after a decade or more of Labor government having control of the tax system and the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, having his hands on the economic levers. Under the heading the `Family unit taxation system' the following example was mentioned:

Our current taxation system is one which is based on the income of the individual, and it does not recognise the differences in individuals' capacities to pay tax. For example, a single person with no dependants, earning $30,000 p.a. pays the same amount of tax as a married person who is the sole breadwinner for a family with two children who earns $30,000 p.a. This system is of clear disadvantage to the person who is married with two children, as that person has three dependants, compared with the individual who supports only her/himself. The married person with the children has a different capacity to pay tax, which the individual-based taxation system fails to recognise.

The report then, in dealing with that problem, outlines some proposals. One which was put before the Lyons Forum was the French quotient system. Nowhere in the report does the Lyons Forum adopt the French quotient system. I must say from reading it, it sounds a very nice and fair system. But, given our current economic structure and taxation burden, I doubt that we could implement that system in Australia.

PARA.TAB: One thing that has to be recognised is that at least the Lyons Forum has acknowledged the very real disadvantage of single-income families where the need of children and spouse are required to be met, something that Senator Crowley never seems to accept. This government after 13 years in office has not addressed those very real problems that are hurting the battlers within the community.

Can I say to Senator Crowley, possibly more in sorrow than in anger: instead of trying to develop maps for men to find their way around supermarkets, you ought to try to find a map to show you the way to the truth.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Campbell this day, relating to youth unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I am incredulous at the response not only to my question today from Senator Gareth Evans, representing the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this place, but also to the answer he provided to a question on 22 November 1995 where I also asked him about youth unemployment and youth suicide and this government's not just lack of attention but lack of action on these matters. Senator Evans said in this chamber on 22 November that he did not have any information on that and he would get me an instant answer.

PARA.TAB: I will put that in context. Whenever you ask this government about youth issues and whenever they make a statement about youth issues publicly, they say these are a matter of incredible moment for the government. They are giving the highest level of consideration to these matters. When the Prime Minister's representative in the Senate is asked a question about youth unemployment or youth suicide, he is unable to answer. He does not have a brief. I put it to you that that is an incredible indictment upon this government.

We have an enormously high rate of youth unemployment—29 per cent. You find that, when Senator Schacht answered a question on this matter today—virtually word for word giving the information that Senator Evans has given to me in his subsequent answer—he went through the statistical reasons why it is 29 per cent and almost said that it is not a bad thing. He did not say that, but I will quote what Senator Evans said in answer to my question. If you check it against the Hansard, you will find it is virtually verbatim from the brief Senator Schacht was reading from during question time today. Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of Senator Campbell's claim that youth unemployment is 29%, this is the rate for 15-19 year olds looking for full-time work (seasonally adjusted).
That is what the youth unemployment rate is. I continue to quote:

The official unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds, as measured by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, is 19.6% (October 1995, original data). In May 1994, when the Government announced Working Nation, the full-time unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds was 32.6% (seasonally adjusted), while the unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds was 23.2% (original data).

I read that statement particularly for the benefit of younger people who are listening to this debate at the moment. What does that mean to you? I bet most of them have no contemplation. The reality is that Australia has a youth unemployment crisis, yet this government contents itself to say, `Look, we've got Working Nation. We're very concerned about it.' But the reality is very different. The youth unemployment rate is going up.

PARA.TAB: I will now look at general unemployment. I was reading a Business Review Weekly article on Thursday night on the aeroplane—and this relates to the question I asked today—and saw that they did an analysis of all of the unemployment rates in most of the Western nations, the OECD nations. Only two nations had unemployment rates that were going up—Australia and Germany. Every other nation in the Western world has unemployment going down. We have got it going up.

The point I was trying to get to in my question to the Leader of the Government, who clearly did not want to answer the question, is how are we going to achieve a five per cent unemployment rate by the year 2000 unless there is a change of policies or unless there is a change of government? He did not indicate any policy changes, he just said, `We will go along the way we are going. We will have high interest rates and high inflation, but somehow, miraculously, we will have this reduction in unemployment from close to nine per cent down to five per cent.'

I think the most remarkable thing that has happened today is in this report that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Simon Crean, has brought out. They are now predicting that unemployment in the year 2005 will be four per cent. So, just as unemployment starts going up, they have said, `Yes, we will still achieve five per cent in the year 2000 even though growth has gone down. But don't worry, in the year 2005, it will be even better. It will only be four per cent.' I put it to the minister, the next time unemployment goes up, he is likely to say, `In the year 2010 it will only be three per cent.'

I tell you what, by the time we get to the year 2020 it is going to be nirvana. You kids in the gallery, look forward to the year 2020, because there will be negative two per cent unemployment on the way this government is going, on its reports and on what it says to the people, `We are really looking good on unemployment. Even though it is going up at the moment, even though the trend for the Labor government is increasing levels of unemployment, don't worry, in the year 2010, she'll be right.'
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brownhill (from 117 citizens) and Senator Childs (from 107 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Public Service: Higher Duties
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned federal Public Servants respectfully submit that:

The introduction of a Public Service Act regulation removing appeals against higher duties of 12 months or less has the potential to undermine the principle of selection on merit and the principle of an apolitical public service and lead to staffing decisions based on patronage and favouritism.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Disallow the Public Service Act regulation removing the aforesaid appeal right.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Denman (from 67 citizens) and Senator Reynolds (from 71 citizens).

PARA.TAB: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

There is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate Federal Government intervention, to comply with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory, and protect the remaining high conservation value forest areas which support flora and fauna unique to Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
immediately implement the moratorium clause in the 1992 National Forest Policy Statement, and cease all logging activities in high conservation value forests;

permanently protect in reserves, all old growth, wilderness, and other high conservation value forest areas, under the custodianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in cooperation with local communities, conservation and scientific organisations;
reap only what is sown by utilising readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and compensation if necessary for affected workers and contractors;
restructure the paper and fibre board industries to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp, cane etc.

create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture-style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands, and encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous forest products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oils, and other nutritional and medicinal resources.
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry, in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain students of Southern Cross University at Lismore, Coffs Harbour and Port Macquarie draws to the attention of the Senate the decision of the President of the Republic of France to resume testing of nuclear armaments on Mururoa Atoll.
Your petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
(1) actively support all United Nations resolutions that support the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty;
(2) seek all military cooperation and commercial military activity with France, including the overflying of all Australian Territory by any French military aircraft;
(3) cease all uranium (yellow cake) exports to France;
(4) to call upon Canada and South Africa to also cease all uranium exports to France.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to protect Australia's native forests.
Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to abuse the agreement that the Senate has granted me to introduce this bill, but I would just make a brief statement, before seeking to incorporate the full speech in Hansard. This bill follows on the extensive work of the conservation movement in preparing the necessary criteria to protect forests of high conservation value. The government has overwhelming public support to act to save the forests. There is no doubt that the Commonwealth has the necessary constitutional power to protect our forests—and the only impediment is political.

PARA.TAB: This bill sets out to amend the Export Control Act in such a way that would phase out the export of woodchips from native forests, prohibit logging in definite categories of native forests on public land immediately, prohibit the export of woodchips from defined categories of native forests immediately, and implement a transitional strategy for the wood products industry. This bill is step 1 in a positive, pro-active holistic strategy to save our wonderful, precious native forests. The onus is now on the government to act. I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This is a bill for the future; the future of our native forests, the future of workers in the industry and the future of all our children. This bill gives a voice to people in the community who want to see a clear show of political will on the part of the government to end the destruction of our native forests.

The Native Forest Protection Bill seeks to provide immediate protection for high conservation value forests from logging. It legislates for a phase out of export woodchipping in native forests by 1998. It also provides for an industry transition strategy, to protect workers and secure their future through a transition to the extensive plantation base within Australia currently available.

This bill gives a voice to a section of the community which has been demanding action from the government. The major impetus for the bill came from the Australian Greens in consultation with the environment movement and all involved deserve acknowledgment for their tremendous work.

The Greens (WA) are committed to an holistic approach to protecting our magnificent forests. We recognise that there are many other issues to be addressed such as Aboriginal land rights, environmentally sensitive plantations, mining, minimal impact use and ecologically sensitive tourism. Obviously a purely legislative approach on its own cannot protect Australia's forests, but it is an important piece in the jigsaw. We hope that this bill is the start of an holistic approach, not the end point.

This bill will not satisfy everyone. The forests debate in this country is a complex and evolving one. However, this bill will play an important political role at this critical time for our forests. We also hope that in the future we can expand its application, incorporating concerns and suggestions.
The Greens have been asked to introduce because the government hasn't.

This bill represents commitments given within Labor Party and government policy. I challenge the government to deny that they are committed to protecting high conservation value forests, to phasing out export woodchipping and to providing a future for forest industry workers.

This bill has a very narrow focus, with a very specific aim. It is being introduced in the lead up to the announcement on the Deferred Forest Assessment process and the consideration of export woodchip licences. The bill forms a benchmark by which to judge the commitment of the government and the Coalition to forests. I call on all parliamentarians and political parties to make their position clear on this bill.
As a community we stand at the edge of a solution to the forest debate. We have all the pieces of the jigsaw.

Native forests are cherished by the Australian community. We have learnt from indigenous Australians that forests have many values; biological, cultural and spiritual and that we must honour these values. We understand the scientific values of the plants and animals that make up our native forests. We recognise that the native forests based industry is in decline and in the process is hurting workers and their families. We know that it is woodchipping, not the smaller sawn timber sector, which is driving the destruction of our forests, for negligible economic gain to Australia. We know there are alternatives. We can start with a timber industry based on our rich plantation resource, with down stream processing using clean technology. There must be recognition of the social and economic benefits of the non-timber values of forests, such as habitat for plants and animals, water quality, recreation, research and tourism.

These aspects are the pieces of the jigsaw, which joined together offer an holistic solution to the forests debate; conservation of our natural and cultural heritage, protection of workers and their families and a viable, value adding plantation based industry of the future.

The economic failure of the industry is now well documented. The industry is a job shedding one, not job creating. Employment in the industry has fallen from around 55 000 in the early 1970s to approximately 32 000 at present. There is nothing to suggest that this decline will not continue. The concentration of industry ownership, substitution from plantations and mechanisation have been the primary causes of these job losses.

The net economic benefit to the country is further curtailed by the involvement of foreign owned corporations in the industry. The lack of down stream processing and export of woodchips for processing overseas further strips Australia economic benefit.

In addition to job losses and profit leaching for the domestic economy the public purse continues to subsidise native forests logging operations. Infrastructure, such as roading is provided and excessively low royalties are charged. The Federal Resource Assessment Commission in its Forest and Timber Inquiry Report found that expenditure had outweighed revenue since at least the 1920s. in every state forest service, except South Australia.
Why do we continue to publicly support an uncompetitive, job shedding, non-value adding, largely foreign owned industry? It seems inexplicable.

While the native forest based industry is our history, plantations offer a future. This is something that both the plantation based timber sector and the environment movement have been saying for a long time.

The continued reliance on a native forest resource base flies in the face of worldwide industry trends. Other countries have invested heavily in plantations. Plantations in Chile, Brazil and the Pacific rim are already becoming the preferred resource for international buyers. Their extensive plantation resources and lower labour costs have the potential to undermine Australia's domestic plantation industry. Australian governments must affirm the importance of plantations to the future of the industry as a whole and actively support their development.

Australia has an abundant plantation based timber resources which can supply Australia's needs. A report by the resource economist, Dr Judy Clark, entitled "Softwood Plantation Sawlog Stockpile", details this. I quote

"Australia has approximately 88 000 hectares of softwood plantations past their harvest age of 30 years. These plantations contain an estimated 24 million m3 stockpile of sawlogs. This is six times the annual native forest cut five times the annual plantation sawlog cut.

For plantation owners, predominantly State governments, this stockpile holds unrealised revenues of up to $830 million. Processing the sawlog stockpile would generate an estimated $3 billion in sawn timber sales by Australian industry."

The fate of timber industry workers and their families is a vital concern in this debate. The wood products industry, industry bodies and foreign corporations have used timber workers as pawns. This is unacceptable. Protection of our forests and protection of timber workers are inextricable linked.

It is clear that the future of the industry and workers is in plantations. However, it would be simplistic to pretend that all workers can seamlessly move from one job to another or from one place to another. The complete mobility of skills and labour is another economic rationalist myth. That is why a extensive transition strategy is vital. I acknowledge that the government has begun to look at this issue through the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy. However, a strategy must be established speedily, in close consultation with affected local communities and with a meaningful degree of assistance, not a token one.

At the heart of this debate, for me, is that forests are inseparable from our own humanity. Their cultural, spiritual and recreational values are enormous. I would like to quote from the statement on forests by the New South Wales Ecumenical Council, The Uniting Church of Australia, The Sydney Anglican Social Issues Committee and The Catholic Church.

"There is a spiritual dimension to the forests, as well as a biological, social and economic one. The political agenda must take this spirituality on board: we must value God's creation appropriately. Forests are a vital part of this creation and of its ongoing sustainability.

The inter relatedness of healthy forests and life—including human life—on this planet is testimony to the fact that forests are more than gifts from God for human beings to exploit. Our God-given human calling is to work responsibly with the rest of creation for human well being. But human well being in the long term is integrally related to the correct, sustainable use of God given forest resources."

It is clear that the community wants to preserve Australia's native forests for their many values. It is clear that we can supply our wood requirements from plantations. It is clear that we must also address the needs of workers in the native forest based industry and assist their adjustment to an ecologically sustainable approach.

So why is the government failing to protect native forests and why is the Opposition, by it silence, consenting to this act of environmental vandalism. Every day that native forests continue to be logged and woodchipped, the government is responsible for bringing endangered species closer to extinction. It is responsible for deliberately authorising the destruction of thousands of hectares of rainforest, old growth forest and wilderness. It is responsible for the wanton destruction of world heritage.

The commonwealth has the powers, and indeed the responsibility, to bring these pieces together. This bill clearly shows where the commonwealth's power lies. Protection of high conservation value forests is an implementation of the Convention on Biological Diversity, signed using the external affairs power. Protecting these areas from the actions of domestic and foreign corporations is covered by the corporations power. The commonwealth's ability to phase out export woodchipping is unchallenged. This is a clear use of power which the commonwealth exercises each year to renew export woodchip licences.

So it remains the case that the government has the means but not the will. It has made commitments, but these have not been honoured. This bill is a benchmark. The major parties will be judged by the community on their response to it and the fundamental principles it embodies. Neither party can afford to fail this test.

As representatives of your constituents, honourable Senators must each take personal responsibility for the fate of our forests. You must be prepared to explain your decision to your children and to your children's children. Will you support escalating the destruction of their inheritance?

In concluding I must come back to the very core of the issue and that is the inherent value of forests for forests sake. To deny their fundamental importance to the world in which we live is to deny our own humanity. I would like to finish with a quote from The Courier by Jacques Brosse.

All over the world, there lingers on the memory of a giant tree, the primal tree, rising from the centre of the Earth to the heavens and ordering the universe around it. It united the three worlds: its roots plunged down into subterranean abysses, its loftiest branches touched the empyrean. Thanks to the Tree, it became possible to breathe the air; to all the creatures that then appeared on earth it dispensed its fruit, ripened by the sun and nourished by the water which drew from soil. From the sky it attracted the lightening from which man made fire and, beckoning skyward, where clouds gathered around its crown, it bade the life-giving rains to fall. The Tree was the source of all life, and all regeneration."
I commend the bill to the Senate
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
