DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Capital and External Territories Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories, I present the report of the committee on Draft Amendment No. 14 (Broadacre Areas) to the National Capital Plan, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to present this report to the Senate. It came about when on 10 November 1994 the Hon. Brian Howe MP, the then Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Housing and Regional Development, invited the committee to inquire into and report on what is known as draft amendment No. 14 to the national capital plan.

PARA.TAB: This seeks to expand the range of permitted land uses from the current `offensive and hazardous industries' to just the more general `industries'. Covering four sites identified as A, B, C and D, the area lies within broadacre areas of the national capital plan. It is bound by Oaks Estate, the ACT/New South Wales border, Canberra Avenue and the Molonglo River corridor. It in fact includes the sites currently occupied by the Canberra Abattoir and the Canberra Tannery.

The committee conducted an on-site inspection of the area on 27 February 1995, took evidence from key interested parties at public hearings on 27 February and 6 March and written submissions were also received and considered by the committee. It all took somewhat longer than anticipated and, for the first time that I can recall, there is a dissenting report associated with this. The matter was debated at great length, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President Colston, by the committee and a number of contentious issues were discussed.

The inquiry highlighted some of the difficulties in looking at land use purposes operating under two planning regimes in the national capital. In the ACT, both Commonwealth and ACT legislation operates. There are two plans known as the national capital plan and the territory plan, which are the responsibility of the National Capital Planning Authority and the ACT Planning Authority respectively. I guess it is inevitable that from time to time there will be differences in the plans and there will be issues that will need to be considered.

I note that just recently the chief minister of the ACT government and the minister, Mr Howe, established a committee to jointly look at aspects relating to planning. I have not seen the specific terms of reference but I think anyone who has been involved in this area would recognise the areas that would be looked at and discussed.

The reason that the committee received this reference was that there was an anomaly between the national capital plan and the territory plan. The national capital plan only permitted `hazardous and offensive industries' on the sites while the territory plan permitted `industries' for all but one site within the draft amendment area. However, the territory plan has no effect if it is inconsistent with the national capital plan.

The impetus for draft amendment No. 14 was an application by the proprietor of the Canberra Abattoir to vary its lease in that he wished to close the abattoir and seek to redevelop some of the land into an industrial estate, comprising I think some 50 blocks. Draft amendment No. 14 does not, in itself, result in an automatic change in land use on the abattoir site as there are mandatory processes also required by the ACT government before any change in land use or any development application can be approved.

The amendment raised several important issues which are dealt with in the report, and the committee considered the extent of the area of the sites A, B, C and D. Some of the issues were the impact on nearby residents, the need for an adequate buffer zone to allow screening from any development in the area and Canberra Avenue, the concerns of the Queanbeyan City Council, and the need to reduce anomalies between the national capital plan and the territory plan. It led the committee to conclude that it was appropriate to vary the plan in relation to sites A, B and D but excluding site C. Consequently, the committee recommends that draft amendment No. 14, as originally proposed, be not agreed to but that the variation relate to sites A, B and D. Reasons for this are set out in the report.

I wish to thank the staff involved with this inquiry, which, as I said, took much longer than expected, in particular, Meg Crooks, the secretary to the committee, and all others who have worked with us. It is necessary also to comment a little on the arguments that took place and the reasons some members of the committee came to a different point of view.

It is my view that what we have done enables a lessee to be innovative, to show initiative, to show some entrepreneurship in relation to their activities in the Australian Capital Territory. It is my view that the alternate proposal, which other members of the committee preferred, would in fact lead to a situation of stifling initiative, stifling entrepreneurship and discouraging business from being involved in the ACT. I believe any person has the right to consider redeveloping, reassess what they are doing and enter some other activity.

To suggest that a person who has a lease in Canberra, if they did not wish to proceed with what they were doing at the present time, should only be able to get rid of it by surrendering it I think would have quite a devastating effect on the morale of the business community and people generally in the Australian Capital Territory. There is no doubt that there is a betterment tax paid if you seek to change the purpose of the lease which you occupy and want to do something else. It will be assessed and taxed at an appropriate rate and that tax will be paid. I understand that that is also a matter being reviewed by the ACT government.

But to suggest that the only course this particular company could follow would be to give back the abattoir to the ACT government and hope to be recompensed for it and that any further development might be done by somebody else or by the ACT government is not the sort of society I would want to live in; it is not the message I would want to give to people here. I would hope that we would live in a society where people would be innovative and show entrepreneurship to develop and to create other jobs and other opportunities, rather than send a message that that is not the way we do things in the ACT.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Colston for putting those points on the record with regard to the way in which the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories operated. As Senator Colston said, that is a clear majority of the committee members who participated in the matter.

PARA.TAB: I am still upset about the whole issue. It is not just a matter of a slight difference of opinion; it goes to the very basic issues that were concerned with this reference. I also urge the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe) to take particular note of the alternative recommendations of the five committee members who signed the dissenting report. It is a brief dissent of only two pages but it sets out the issues.

I wish to correct something Senator Reid said. I think she said this was the first dissenting report of this committee. That is not so, because I put in a dissenting report in relation to the transport problems of Christmas, Cocos and Norfolk islands. I make that point to emphasise there is a difference between one member of a committee putting a point of view to indicate an ideological difference and such a significant number of committee members dissenting, as occurred in this case.

In answer to Senator Reid's point about entrepreneurship and people having the right to seek a change of use for their lease, we are not talking about a minor change of use. We are not talking about somebody having a lease over a normal block in Canberra and seeking to change it from a car yard to some other industry, or even a change from one residence to four. We are talking about changing a substantial area that was set up as an abattoir. Originally, it was a Commonwealth abattoir; it has been a private abattoir for some years. The proposal is to change it so that it is effectively a new industrial suburb of Canberra.

My point of view is that if that is to happen, it ought to be done by the proper planning processes. This proposal was not dealt with in the normal course of planning processes. It only arose because the current lessee, the Mulligan company, which runs the abattoir, wanted to close it down and concentrate its activities at another abattoir in Cowra. It sought to profit from the remainder of its lease term and any renewal by developing and subdividing the site as an industrial estate.

On the planning issue, quite apart from the correctness of the process, it may be that there is a need for a new industrial suburb in Canberra. It may even be that this is the best place for it, although I have my doubts because of its closeness to the border and to Queanbeyan. But if this is to happen, it ought to happen by the normal processes of looking at the overall planning of Canberra and saying, `Fyshwick, Mitchell and so on don't have enough room and we need a new industrial suburb.' It should not be done in this ad hoc way. To illustrate the point, I will read part of the dissenting report:

SPEECH.PARA: We also accept that in such circumstances a lessee should be able to seek to have its lease terminated and that there is value to the lessee in the remainder of its lease term.

The company thought this was the only way that it could get value out of the remainder of its lease term. They were under a misapprehension about their entitlement for the lease to be terminated and for them to get compensation. That was not so. We went on to say:

However, we believe that the fairest way in which the lessee's needs and rights should be satisfied, while ensuring that the community's rights are protected, is for the lease to be terminated and the lessee to be appropriately compensated for the value of the remainder of the term of the lease based on its current use.
We were not suggesting they should lose any remaining value they had in that lease. The dissenting report continues:

While recognising that there would be risks in its proposed investment as a developer, and acknowledging that betterment would be payable to the ACT Government, there is no justification for the present lessee potentially to profit from such a substantial change of use, nor for it automatically to become the developer of what would be effectively a new industrial suburb without competing for that right.

I guess that is why I am a bit surprised at the opposition's attitude to this matter. I would have thought the fair way of ensuring that if there was to be this development it was done in a competitive way would be by calling for tenders and not just letting it be given to the lessee who happened to have had it for an entirely different reason. The dissenting report goes on:

If, in the proper planning processes, it is determined that the area in question is the appropriate place for a new industrial suburb for the ACT, then that planning, subdivision and development should be by the ACT Government and not by a private developer, unless—
and I acknowledge that this is an option—
the Government decided to contract out all or part of the process, and called tenders for this task in the proper way.
That is not what is being proposed. The dissenting report continues:

The decision-making about whether there should be a new industrial suburb, whether it should be in this area or elsewhere in the ACT-Queanbeyan area, the size and nature of the industrial estate, its relationship to Queanbeyan and Oaks Estate, and other planning requirements, would thereby be fully in the community's hands and not those of a single private company which happened to hold a lease for a quite different purpose, and one which it no longer wished to pursue.
We reiterate that the lessee should be treated fairly, and that it should not suffer a loss in respect of the properly assessed valve of the rest of its lease term.
Then we go on to make a recommendation which states:
.that the amendment as proposed not be approved, and that it not be approved in the suggested modified form.
We recommend further:
.that the company be advised that, if it surrenders its lease or if the lease is compulsorily acquired, the company can be fairly compensated under ACT legislation—
that was something we found out late in the inquiry—
.that the ACT Government be requested to consider all the issues raised in this Report, and in particular in this dissent, . . . and advise the Commonwealth of its preferred use . . .
.that, if then necessary, the Minister could refer an appropriate amendment to the Committee for consideration.

I emphasise that this is an issue of proper planning for the ACT and a question of proper process in terms of whether or not the existing lessee has the right to such a substantial change in the use of the land and the right to potentially profit from developing a new industrial suburb. I once again express my anger about the whole issue. If the majority report were to be adopted, I think it would be outrageous. I urge the minister to take particular note of the serious issues involved and to adopt the alternative recommendations of the five committee members who signed this dissenting report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Neal, I present the report of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities on section 1316 of the Corporations Law, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.

One of the Joint Committee's tasks since its formation in 1991 has been monitoring the investigation and prosecution of breaches of corporate law in the 1980's, with a particular concern about delay in resolving these matters.
These events and the investigations resulting from them are now up to 8 years old, with a number still to be brought before the Courts.

For example, the decision of the Attorney-General pursuant to section 1316 of the Corporations Law to consent to the commencement of proceedings against Mr Bond, Mr Oates and Mr Mitchell in relation to a Bell Resources matter is a reminder that matters of great complexity requiring very considerable application of the resources of the Australian Securities Commission, the Director of Public Prosecutions and the courts are still to be resolved.

In October 1993 the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Alan Cameron, commented publicly `that Section 1316 of the Corporations Law may impede the prosecution of corporate crime, particularly in complex cases.'
The Committee raised this issue with Mr Cameron when he appeared before a public hearing of the Committee in April 1994. Mr Cameron said

The difficulty is that any such decision is itself capable of being reviewed. . . . The only thing that is certain is that an aggressive defendant's first ploy will be to tie us up, potentially for years, in administrative review of the Attorney-General's decision to extend the time. That is the reason we are not sure why there needs to be a special rule for corporate crime.
Options considered by the Committee in its inquiry included
repealing the present limitation period in relation to indictable offences
increasing the limitation period from 5 years to 7 years, or retaining the Attorney-General's discretion, with the removal of any right of review of the exercise of the discretion, or
no change

Evidence before the Committee focused on the distinction between indictable offences (subject to no general limitation period under the Crimes Act 1914) and summary offences (which are subject to a 12 months limitation period under the Crimes Act).
Arguments favouring abolition of the Attorney-General's consent under section 1316 were
(a) it will put corporate criminal prosecutions on the same basis as the general criminal law, and
(b) it is not an appropriate role for the Attorney-General under the current independent prosecution processes

Arguments advanced advocating retention of section 1316, stressed that the limitation period should apply to indictable offences under the Corporations Law as limitation periods in general act as a discipline on agencies to ensure expeditious investigatory and prosecuting processes.

The Committee found that there should be no limitation period for serious or indictable offences under the Corporations Law, and that section 1316 of the Corporations Law should be amended accordingly.

In the case of summary offences, the Committee decided that these offences should be subject to a limitation period of 5 years but without any capacity on the part of the Attorney-General to extend. The Committee found that the Crimes Act limitation period of 12 months would not allow proper investigation of summary offences under the Corporations Law, some of which involve quite serious breaches of corporate behaviour. I draw the attention of the House to the opinion tabled in respect of this matter by Senator Cooney.

A central point in the submissions advocating retention of a limitation period and a discretion in the Attorney-General was that such a discretion provided enhanced accountability for the exercise of the already wide powers of the ASC and the DPP.

Contrary arguments to the Committee stressed two important remedies to this situation: judicial or administrative review of a prosecution decision; and, the courts limiting the commencement of prosecutions due to abuse of process.
Recent decisions indicate that suspect proceedings will not easily escape the Courts' scrutiny.
The Committee does not agree that the addition of a discretion in the Attorney-General to allow an extended period for prosecution will enhance this protection.

The Committee concludes that the current discretion allowed to the Attorney-General does not significantly add to the proper and desirable level of protection of persons accused under various provisions of the Corporations Law.

As well since the creation of the office of the DPP, a statutory independent prosecuting authority, it would be anomalous for the Attorney-General to retain an effective prosecutorial discretion such as that currently contained in section 1316. The Committee believes that corporate criminal law should be on the same basis as serious general criminal offences.

The Committee does, however, believe that the ASC and the DPP should include extra information in their annual reports to provide some better information on the DPP's decisions in relation to corporate offences.

The Committee is concerned that in future a clear picture be presented each year of the number of current matters in the hands of the DPP, the time that has elapsed since the alleged commission of offences that may be involved in each matter; and, the state each matter has reached in the investigation, assessment and prosecution process.

The Committee believes that such a picture will allow the responsible Minister and the Parliament to better ensure that there is appropriate public information on the ASC and the DPPs administration of this area of their responsibilities.

The Committee has formally recommended in its report that future annual reports of the Australian Securities Commission and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions provide detailed information showing the time that has elapsed since the commission of alleged offences under the Corporations Law and the time that has elapsed since the commencement of active investigative and prosecutorial processes.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the third report of the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund relating to the committee exchange with New Zealand in August 1995.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to table this report on behalf of the chairman of the committee, Senator Chris Evans, who unfortunately is unable to be here because he is attending to a very important matter—an expected addition to his family.

PARA.TAB: This report relates to a delegation to New Zealand by the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title. The visit was conducted from 7 August to 10 August this year. The members who visited New Zealand were Senator Chris Evans, the chairman; Senator Chamarette; Mr Harry Quick; the committee secretary, Peter Grundy; and me. At the outset, I wish to place on record the committee's thanks to Mr Peter Grundy for his excellent work and the valuable assistance he rendered to committee members during the course of the visit. The committee worked very well together and in fact enjoyed each other's contributions to the subject in question.

The visit occurred at the invitation of the Speaker of the New Zealand House of Representatives, the Hon. Mr Peter Tapsell, and it took place under the committee exchange program which exists between the two countries. This program involves a visit to Canberra each year by a committee of the New Zealand parliament and a return visit later the same year by a committee of the Commonwealth parliament.

By convention, the Presiding Officers of the dispatching parliament determine the topic and the committee to participate in each exchange, and this decision is usually taken in consultation. This year is the Maori Language Year, and the Hon. Mr Peter Tapsell indicated that indigenous land rights would be an appropriate topic. Accordingly, the Presiding Officers of the Commonwealth parliament agreed that the joint committee should participate in the exchange.

The committee is grateful that, in a compact visit program over 3 1/2 days, there were several meetings with Maori. The visit began at Hamilton for that purpose. Our understanding of the settlement process in New Zealand was much enhanced through meeting with the Tainui and, subsequently, with the Ngai Tahu representatives.
It should be recorded that the visit was very successful as an exchange between the Australian and New Zealand parliaments. The exchange was cordial, informative and stimulating.

I might add that there are some aspects dealing with indigenous land rights which vary between New Zealand and Australia; in fact, markedly so. The first point is the significant proportion of Maori in the New Zealand population. Those who identify as Maori make up 13 per cent of the New Zealand population—a figure expected to increase to 15 per cent over the next 40 years. By the year 2031, the Maori population is projected to number about 672,000—54 per cent larger than in 1991. This contrasts, both in absolute figures and as a proportion, with the Australian indigenous community, which is believed to be less than 300,000 or, in percentage terms, 1.6 per cent of the population.

Another aspect which was of interest in comparison was the concept of native title itself. In New Zealand, native title survived colonisation. Maori land, however, was significantly reduced over time through illegal confiscation and land sales. Importantly, New Zealand land rights have long been litigated on the basis of the 1840 Treaty of Waitangi. In Australia, native title was recognised for the first time in 1992 by the High Court and has survived colonisation only where it was not extinguished by land grants. Litigation on the basis of the Native Title Act has proceeded only since 1994. Therefore, New Zealand has had over 100 years more experience, you might say, in this area than Australia.

The courts have often found in favour of Maori claims about breaches of the treaty, and successful petitions have been made to the Privy Council. New Zealand Maori are in a strong position to assert their land rights as a consequence of the protection afforded by that treaty. The recent Tainui settlement had such a basis. By comparison, it was recognised by the Australian parliament in debating the Native Title Act that indigenous Australians would have only limited scope for the recognition of native title. The land fund was accordingly devised to ensure a more satisfactory level of restitution, particularly for those members of the indigenous community who could not make any successful claim under native title.

The options for litigation over the Waitangi Treaty depend in part on the fact that the treaty was negotiated with the British Crown. Under the Treaty of Waitangi Act, action concerning breaches of the treaty result in claims against the Crown. Private property is not subject to such claims, and claims cannot be brought against private individuals or organisations. The principle adopted in New Zealand is that past wrongs cannot be corrected by further unjust acts.

This situation contrasts with that prevailing in Australia where, except in those cases where native title has been extinguished by an inconsistent grant, native title may continue. Types of holdings that are subject to a valid claim remain to be determined by the courts, but nonetheless a variety of land holdings could be subject to native title claim, and it is not just the Crown against whom those claims are made.

Another aspect which was of some interest was the fact that under the Native Title Act indigenous Australians seek to establish ongoing connection with their country justifying determinations of native title. The National Native Title Tribunal attempts to mediate agreements between the parties. If agreement cannot be reached, the matter is referred to the Federal Court for determination. In New Zealand, emphasis is placed on the breaches of the rights under the Waitangi Treaty. The Waitangi Tribunal issues recommendatory reports. They can be utilised by the Office of Treaty Settlements which then negotiates settlements for the Crown. I might say that the committee had a most interesting meeting with the Chief Judge of the Waitangi Tribunal, Chief Judge Edward Durie—an outstanding man who is not only a credit to his people but also to his country. I think the committee learnt a great deal from him.

Another aspect which was of interest was that New Zealand Maori placed very considerable significance on their insistence that the Crown apologise for breach of the treaty. The recent Tainui Deed of Settlement expressed the Crown's profound regret and apology and provided the recognition of the Waikato's principles: firstly, that as land was taken, land should be returned; and, secondly, that money is the acknowledgment by the Crown of its misdeed.

Finally, in relation to compensation, in Australia no limit has been placed on the amount of compensation that may be payable to indigenous people for the past extinguishment of native title. However, Australia has set up a land fund of some $1.4 billion, which will release $45 million per year through the Indigenous Land Corporation. In New Zealand, a fixed amount, $1 billion, has been identified by the present government as the envelope within which all treaty claims should be settled. That contrasts quite significantly in relation to the Australian situation.

I would like to record the thanks of the committee to the Speaker of the New Zealand House of Representatives for introducing the committee to the house and inviting it to the chamber for question time. I also wish to pay tribute to the hospitality of the Maori Affairs Committee and, in particular, its chairman, Mr Koro Wetere, who looked after us very well indeed and, in fact, was a source of great information to the committee. In fact, without Koro Wetere, I think the committee would have been at a distinct disadvantage, and I am sure Senator Chamarette would agree with me in that regard. All in all it was a most successful visit, and I would commend to the Senate the report in question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I rise to associate myself with the sentiments that have just been expressed by Senator Ellison in relation to the report of the native title committee exchange with New Zealand of August 1995. I was delighted to be able to be part of that visit. I want to stress that, as part of the role of the ongoing Joint Committee on Native Title and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund of this parliament, it is very vital that such visits occur. Not only was this New Zealand visit very important: so too will be an examination of the progress on indigenous rights and native title issues in other countries, such as Canada and the United States.

PARA.TAB: From a comparative point of view, it was very useful to have meetings with both the committee and members of the New Zealand parliament and also to be out in the countryside looking at some of the issues that are very relevant and very important to the Maoris. In looking at the range of issues in relation to native title, I found that New Zealand seems to be very much ahead of Australia in quite a few areas, particularly with the Treaty of Waitangi, making it indisputable that Maori have rights in their own country and that those rights deserve recognition. However, similar problems exist for them. No doubt they are experienced in all parts of the world, particularly here in Australia. There seems to be a similar failure or delay and slowness of the government to recognise the rights that are indisputable by handing over crown land. There were indications that instead of them being handed over to Maori they were actually given to overseas interests. In some cases, national park status was granted as a way of eroding the rights of their ancestral land.

The wonderful highlights of the visit were the traditional welcomes at the beginning of almost every interview or engagement and the respect for Maori culture that was expressed by pakeha. The bilingual, if not bi-cultural, aspects of discussions were very impressive. It stands as an indictment of non-Aboriginal Australia that we have not been able to offer the same kind of respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities when we meet in their areas. It was an extremely salutary experience to share in that acknowledgment of indigenous rights by the bi-cultural way in which issues were discussed and the use of language which underwrote that as well.

I will close these brief comments by referring to something which I believe was one of the most impressive things about the visit to New Zealand. The words at the beginning of the third report of the joint parliamentary committee on native title summarise this issue. I refer to a quote from Lord Normanby's instructions to Lieutenant-Governor Hobson on 14 August 1839. I wish that we could endorse the sentiments that were written here and fulfil them in our own approach to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: All dealings with the Aborigines for their Lands must be conducted on the same principles of sincerity, justice and good faith as must govern your transactions with them for the recognition of Her Majesty's Sovereignty in the Islands. Nor is this all. They must not be permitted to enter into any Contracts in which they might be the ignorant and unintentional authors of injuries to themselves. You will not, for example, purchase from them any Territory the retention of which by them would be essential, or highly conducive, to their own comfort, safety or subsistence. The acquisition of Land by the Crown for the future Settlement of British Subjects must be confined to such Districts as the Natives can alienate without distress or serious inconvenience to themselves. To secure the observance of this rule will be one of the first duties of their official protector . . .

Just as those words stand as an indictment of all the dealings that have happened since 1839 in New Zealand, they stand as an indictment of people all around the world in relation to the indigenous rights of the people of their own countries.

PARA.TAB: This visit to New Zealand was very useful in continuing an exchange between the two countries that will be of certain benefit to us. I would be very pleased to see that committee come over and share with us in some of the struggles that we have in honouring the kinds of commitments that are illustrated in that quote.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Community Affairs Legislation Committee

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO SLOVENIA AND THE 94TH INTER-PARLIAMENTARY CONFERENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Slovenia and the 94th Inter-Parliamentary Conference, to move a motion and to make a short statement in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Slovenia and the 94th Inter-Parliamentary Conference which was held in Bucharest between 1 October and 15 October 1995. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The bilateral visit to Slovenia was headed by Mr Leo McLeay, the government whip and former Speaker, along with Senator Denman, Senator Woods and me. The secretary to the delegation was Mr Peter Keele. We were part of a short delegation which made a bilateral visit to Slovenia. Honourable senators might ask where Slovenia is. Slovenia is a very beautiful country, about one-third of the size of Tasmania, with a population of two million people. It was part of former Yugoslavia. It is bordered by Italy, Austria, Croatia and Hungary and it has a small portion bordering on the Adriatic Sea.

PARA.TAB: Before we left here we had a meeting with the charge d'affaires in Canberra, Mr Aljaz Gosnar, who painted in glowing terms to us what he believed we would enjoy of this beautiful little country. Everything he said was underrated. In fact, I think he did not really paint the true picture. He gave us a very mild view of what this particular country was about.

We do have a reasonable but significantly growing trade with Slovenia. Our two-way trade amounts to $48.7 million. We have about 30,000 Slovenian people living in Australia. So it was important that this first ever parliamentary delegation to Slovenia occurred. We were very pleased to know that Slovenia supports our candidature for the Security Council in the UN. On the other hand, we were one of the first countries to recognise Slovenia when it became a new nation after the disintegration of former Yugoslavia. Slovenia is currently caring for some 17,000 Muslim refugees from the war in former Yugoslavia.

We were all impressed with the work ethic in Slovenia. It really is a very small bustling country—a Western European type country that I highly recommend anybody to visit. In fact, the delegation formed the view that it would be a very good jumping off spot into central, northern and eastern Europe because it is centrally placed. It is still part of the Eastern Bloc; it is not yet part of the European Union.

We were most impressed with the port of Koper, on the Adriatic, which is very close to Trieste. Koper, which is only an hour from Venice, is a very strategically located port. An Australian of Slovenian descent is organising a very well established duty-free trade zone called Toncity, which I believe would have very big advantages for business people coming out of Australia and wanting to enter Europe through a shorter and easier route.

As far as tourism is concerned, it was said to us on more than one occasion that Slovenia is the best kept secret—I know this expression very well because it also could be said of Senator Denman's and my state—in Europe, just like Tasmania is the best kept secret in Australia. That phrase was often used as we moved around the small country. It certainly is a well kept secret. The capital, Ljubljana, is a very beautiful city. Before I went to Ljubljana, Senator Burns mentioned to me that he had been there. It is the home of an international wine show. Its architecture is very European. Piran and Portoroz, a couple of port cities or fishing villages on the Adriatic, are very Venetian in their outlook and are very colourful.

We as a delegation believe that Slovenia can look forward to a very lucrative tourist industry. I believe the relations that we made with members of government and that followed through to the conference in Romania were very fruitful as far as Australia is concerned. As I said, we were there for only a short time.

We moved on to the Inter-Parliamentary Conference in Bucharest in Romania, where we met up with our Speaker, who led the delegation.The Inter-Parliamentary Conference was a very important one. I suppose from Australia's point of view the most important part was the supplementary item that was co-sponsored by Chile and New Zealand. That related to the adoption of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty and its implications for continued nuclear tests.

The conference consisted of some 130-odd countries with almost 1,000 people involved. It is interesting to note that we had very little problem being accommodated because the headquarters for the conference was the former palace of executed Ceaucescu, former dictator of Romania. I remember Senator Burns describing to me the size of this building but, unless you have seen it, it is very hard to realise just how huge this place is. It is the second biggest building in the world, second only to the Pentagon, and is totally constructed out of marble. Its opulence is unbelievable to behold. There are something like 6,000 rooms in this place. Any one of them is bigger than the Great Hall here in Parliament House. We ran out of fingers when counting the chandeliers. There were literally hundreds of chandeliers throughout every building.

A lot of the palace is not finished. It took 20 years to build. It took two million people to build and 25 per cent of the GDP of Romania for 20-odd years. For all that time, there was no food in the shops and the people were struggling. So it is really no wonder that the Romanians took hold of their leader and executed him on TV along with his wife.

No doubt this building will go down in years to come as one of the wonders of the world, like the pyramids and so on. It looks as though the parliament will be moving into it, along with probably quite a few other important things. A part of the whole complex is a great Champs Elysees type promenade that stretches from the building to as far as the eye can see, although it does get lost in the smog in lower Bucharest. At the other end is almost a carbon copy of the Arc de Triomphe. They call Bucharest the Paris of the east. I think Ceaucescu tried to make it look like that but, in typical European fashion, a lot of the buildings are run down and a lot of things do not work, including the plumbing that was in my room.

Getting back to the important matter of nuclear testing: the Senate would be pleased to know that the final text of the adoption of the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty and its implications for continued tests was finally carried, with 933 affirmative votes, 65 negative votes and 356 abstentions. It was quite interesting that the leader of the French delegation made the point that these were old tests, that they should have been carried out four years previously. He concluded by saying that he had swum in the lagoon where the tests took place, that the last time was only two weeks previously and that he had not become radioactive. We thought that was quite unusual. Three other items of note were debated during the conference. I commend this report to those people who are interested in it. They certainly will find it very interesting reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate myself with the comprehensive report given by Senator Calvert on the parliamentary delegation to Slovenia and the 94th Inter-Parliamentary Conference in Bucharest. This was my first experience in this delegation. I do not know what I expected. I thought it was going to be a bit of a holiday, but it was not. We worked long hours, and we worked hard. The delegation worked well together as a group. It was good.

PARA.TAB: I was impressed with the dedication of the group to the things that we had to do. We cooperated well. There was no friction between us as a group. The tasks that we were given included supporting in Bucharest the New Zealand supplementary item on nuclear testing along with Chile. We supported them, and that item got up. It was a privilege to be part of the drafting committee when the issue of nuclear testing in the Pacific arose. There was greater elation when that issue got up as an item on the agenda.

Because of the commitments of the conference, I did not have any time to see anything of Romania. But I would like to very briefly share with the Senate two things that I did do. One was that I visited an orphanage caring for children from birth to four years. In this orphanage there were 84 children. The children were cared for in groups of nine or 10 in three rooms per group. The orphanage was doing a superb job under very difficult circumstances. The rooms were brightly painted. One room was a bedroom, and two rooms were used as playrooms. The children were happy and they related well to the people looking after them. Because of difficulties due to the circumstances, the things that I saw there are a credit to the people of Romania.

The second visit I made was to a hospital caring for babies born with AIDS. My interest in that was to see what the Romanian people were doing about educating the people of their country with regard to safe sex, needle exchange and the AIDS problem generally. They have not by any means made an impact, but they have tried and are trying. They have very limited resources. Therefore, they are not able to get the message across to those who are most at risk. The ward I saw was sponsored by the Americans, so the equipment in that was probably superior to any other in the hospitals in Bucharest, and even that was very basic. That was a very moving experience. I feel privileged to have been able to do that.
I say thank you to the other delegates in the delegation—it was a tremendous experience for me—and a particular thanks to Peter Keele, the secretary.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee for inquiry and report on or before the last sitting day in June 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: The management of gold mine effluent in Australia, with particular emphasis on the engineering, management and practice of tailings dam functions and the effect these have on wildlife, ground water, soil salinity levels and human health. In particular, the committee will draw information and expertise from industry and relevant bodies, including State and federal agencies, local government and environment and community groups, with the aim of ascertaining:

PARA.TAB: (a)the nature of current field practice in gold mine effluent management in Australia and of Australian companies overseas;

(b)the depth of knowledge of industry, government and community groups of the latest technological advances and best practice innovations in gold mine engineering and management which effectively minimise the ecological and social effects of gold mine effluent;

(c)the ecological and social ramifications of discrepancies between current field practice and latest best practice, and between the intention and result of environmental impact statement (EIS) recommendations and works approval conditions under an EIS; and
(d)recommendations on how to implement best practice most effectively, on a government and industry level, to facilitate prevention of negative ecological and social ramifications.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is coming up for debate now due to an inadvertent error on my part. Today the opposition gave notice of a motion that seemed to me to contradict this motion. Therefore, I did not seek to have it declared formal earlier today. As it has come up now, I would be delighted if we could vote to support it. I suggest that we do not debate it at length.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are the Democrats supporting it?
—Yes. The Democrats and the government are supporting it. The opposition is not.

The committee accepted the reference in principle but disagreed with the time to report. This motion will not interfere with the opposition's plan to go ahead with the motion that they gave notice of this morning. This motion will stay on the Notice Paper, as will the opposition's motion. The date was changed to give the committee ample time to report.
