Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Bank Sale Bill is another asset sell off. It seems like I am speaking against these shoddy budget fiddling measures all the time these days. I do not imagine that the situation will continue, because there is very little left to sell, besides the physical infrastructure. However, we are already moving towards the sale of our national highways.

PARA.TAB: I note that this bill led the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, to make statements to the effect that any negative mention of this sale of the Commonwealth Bank by the opposition was purely spite because the Labor Party did it and now there is almost nothing to distinguish the Labor Party from the coalition. That was a more extreme statement than Senator Evans would have made in a reflective moment, but he was on a roll and it sounded like a good political point at the time. Unfortunately, it probably has more truth in it than most people would wish to acknowledge.

Why bother about the Commonwealth Bank anyway? It is, after all, just another big bank that puts the same nasty fees on pensioners and so on. The reason we oppose the sale is primarily on principle; and, secondly, because the Commonwealth Bank, in spite of its hard nosed corporate image, still has some obligations to the community. These will disappear. Unlike the airports act, there are no stipulations for community service obligations in this sale bill.

The Commonwealth Bank was established in 1912, although the legislative basis was created the year before. It was an outgrowth of both the basic social philosophy of much of the labour movement and the specific economic disasters in private banking during the last decade of the 1800s. During that time a policy of non-prudential lending, coupled with speculation, led to the collapse of many banks and an even greater number which closed their doors for some period.

It was also a basic plank of the international labour social movement that the people should, through government, be directly able to control those activities in their lives which established the parameters under which they lived and where the nature of social infrastructure made it a natural monopoly. In particular, energy, water, communications, transport and banking were seen as essential areas to have under public control.

In regard to banking in Australia, the Commonwealth Bank always operated on the principle that it was a public presence in a private banking environment, except for the brief period during the Chifley government when an attempt was made to nationalise all banks. Much of the push for nationalisation at that time was an outcome of the Great Depression. The speculation and non-prudential lending of the post-war 1920s led not only to the Great Depression but ultimately to attempts to regulate much of the financial sector, including through the establishment of the International Monetary Fund which originally was designed to combat speculation and regulate currency—a function almost opposite to what it does today.

The Commonwealth Bank has been conceived as an agency to give a measure of stability to the financial sector, to ensure certain practices and services are available and to promote the sort of development government, as representatives of polity, believed to be of value to Australia. It has actually performed many of these functions. It helped form the commodity pools, the wheat and wool boards, at a time when there was extreme uncertainty in the agricultural sector. The Commonwealth Development Bank provided financing for agricultural and industrial projects which otherwise may have gone unfunded.

Here I digress to point out that the Japanese and other Asian tigers have also followed a program of intentionally and aggressively promoting certain types of development through direct intervention rather than relying on market forces which would have kept them as low wage, high labour content nations. The Reserve Bank was also formed out of the Commonwealth Bank.

The Commonwealth Bank has also been directly involved in providing service to communities. Senators who have spent much time in rural areas will realise, if they think about it for a moment, how many small communities have only one bank—the Commonwealth Bank—even if it is only a passport agency at the local post office. There is a commitment to the community there that every community should have access to banking at some level. What other bank has such a commitment? A few of the state banks spring to mind as possible examples. But of course state banks have virtually disappeared, with the decision to sell the Rural and Industry Bank of Western Australia—now called Bank West in a tribute to Professor Spooner—to the Scots.

Unfortunately, since the 1950s there has been a steady erosion of both the concept and the practice of public banks as agents of development, regulation or social equity provision. We have seen the banks restructured, corporatised, turned into government business enterprises and turned into private companies in which government simply has majority share. At each step of this process the banks become less accountable to the public and there is an increasing onus placed on government not to interfere with the normal commercial operations of these companies. This means that any ability to promote social goals is reduced, while the ability of government to manage in the absence of regulation also disappears. Effectively, banks are turned from an agent of development and social service into just an investment of public money.

As unfortunate, in my opinion, as the recent trend has been, it does not alter the principle that the people should have the collective ability to directly affect issues of finance, banking and fund provisions. For that reason alone we would not support selling off the Commonwealth Bank. The fact that it is operating as just another bank—imposing the same bad interest rates and the same fees and charges on small savers and following the same kind of investment policy—does not mean that the people, through government, should lose all ability to reclaim this asset as a functional tool of social reform and financial stability. That is what selling off the bank would mean.

While it is difficult for anyone in either big party to imagine not selling the bank, it is entirely inconceivable that there would be a party in power in the near future who would establish a new government owned national bank. The decision to sell is therefore functionally an irrevocable abandonment of the public right and power to directly participate in banking. It is far more than the simple sale of an asset. In principle, we cannot support it.

In practice, the sale raises a number of questions. As I have noted, many rural communities are too small to attract any commercial bank to establish an outlet. So far they have been serviced because either the state banks or the Commonwealth Bank have a social commitment to provide such services. There are examples of synergy here that I have noted before. Where the cost of establishing any government agency or presence in a community may require substantial subsidy of its own, the common practice of multiple use—the original one-stop shop—has allowed a post office to act as agent for a range of services, including banking. Government departments can work together on the basis that they are owned and serve the people, so can engage in cost savings and ensure public access across departments.

The question that arises from the sale is: what will happen in relation to these small communities? Will a private Commonwealth Bank spend money to ensure rural communities have access to banking? Will it put in the capital for very long distance computer lines or satellite down links in order to service a handful of customers? How will the maintenance of these facilities be justified when the profit margins on an automatic teller machine in the city core, or urban business services, are so much better?

My guess is that rural banking will go the way of so many other rural services: they will be shifted to regional centres, requiring huge unproductive and inefficient inputs of time, money and energy for rural people in order to raise the `productivity and efficiency' of the banks. Of course, maybe everyone will join the Internet, sponsored by Telstra and Bill Gates, and will do their banking on-line. And maybe trickle-down economics will make the world's rich poor. I doubt it. But I look forward to seeing what the changes will be for this service.

It will also be interesting to see what happens in relation to postal agencies. All postal agencies in rural areas still act as agencies for the Commonwealth Bank. Will the post offices continue to act as agents for the privatised Commonwealth Bank? Will they have a policy to act as agents for any bank that asks? Will this be a special sweetener in the Commonwealth Bank sale? Will they stop the service? What will they charge? Competitive rates?

Who is going to buy the Commonwealth Bank? My guess is that there are several major international banks that would love to establish a presence in Australia but have been constrained by the difficulty of breaking into such a market from scratch. But, if they could take over or gain a controlling share of the Commonwealth Bank, they would be in. But whose interests and decisions would their policies reflect?

I note with some concern that when we propose to privatise even management of airports there is a whole large bill setting out some of the regulations, obligations and so on that the private sector must operate under. Where we privatise the Commonwealth Bank there is nothing—no community service obligations, nothing. It is seen as inappropriate to impose those on a single bank. So any social function the Commonwealth Bank continues to perform is simply written off as collateral damage—as expendable and unimportant in the push for privatisation. For this reason, as well as the principle, we cannot support the bill.

Privatisation, like any asset, is always put forward as a huge win—a massive windfall for government and government revenue. Economically this is quite incorrect. An asset is just that: an asset—something good we have; something we have put money into, usually for a purpose other than pure investment. The money from such a sale is not new money. It is, hopefully, at least the current market value of that asset. It is not a gain at all. As an asset, the value may also rise in value. A business, as a form of asset, will also generate income. This is aside from the more obvious use value of a government owned service provider. That income will be forgone. Just a few years down the track we will be down in our budget figures because of this sale. No, the Greens will not support this bill. We believe the sale of the Commonwealth Bank will be a sad day for the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Bank sale marks the end of an historic era. In the 19th century governments saw the establishment of savings banks and the promotion of thrift as means for promoting the development of Australian colonies and ensuring that working people could build up a safety net against financial vicissitudes. Thus the Savings Bank of New South Wales was established in 1832. Government savings banks were actually operated through the post office. Some of us are old enough to remember that. It is perhaps a sign of the times that not only the Commonwealth Bank is being sold but also the beautiful Savings Bank of New South Wales building in Barrack Street.

PARA.TAB: Some will say that habits of thrift and prudence are old-fashioned and that we have no need of a government bank. I do not agree. At a time when Australia is `dissaving' as never before, when we are running record current account deficits and Australian domestic savings have plummeted to almost nil, I think we should reconsider the virtues of a past era when governments thought they had a public duty to build for the future rather than to spend for the present.

The sale of the Commonwealth Bank is both a symbol and the reality of what is wrong with much of this government's economic policy. We are engaged in a sell-off and a sell-out—a sell-off of the family silver, a sell-out of traditional Labor Party and labour movement policies, and a sell-out of principle.

When Andrew Fisher's Labor government established the Commonwealth Bank just before the First World War—I think it was in 1912—it was an action of a Labor government that believed in the dignity of the working man and woman. Labor governments of those times believed in thrift and self-improvement. They believed that working people should be encouraged to lift themselves up and not be turned into state welfare dependents. They valued cooperative and mutual self-help. Thus they believed in tax exemptions for credit unions, friendly societies and trustee savings banks.

But this government's philosophies are different. It does not believe in fostering collective self-help by working people. It has increased the tax on credit unions and friendly societies. It is introducing tax legislation which will facilitate the demutualisation of life assurance societies so that these repositories of people's savings will no longer be under the control of the worker and member policy holders. This government did nothing to defend the interests of members who were presented with a misleading and deceptive attempt to demutualise the NRMA in New South Wales. It is introducing penalties on friendly societies in the new deeming rules for social security.

This government, apparently, does not believe that working people should be empowered to save; they should be forced to save and have no say where their savings go. I do not see any virtue in this government's claim that working people should be forced to save when it is selling off assets in the greatest case of asset stripping since the disposal of crown lands by the colonies in the 19th century. How can the government lecture working people on the need to save when it has taxed them into the ground and stripped them of any surplus income out of which they might have saved? How can this government talk about savings when it is investing so little in infrastructure that it has invented a new payroll tax, called the superannuation levy, designed to create a new pool of money to make up for its failure to invest in infrastructure.

I do not favour this bill. It seems to have been conceived as a last minute, headline grabbing exercise to claim a budget surplus in the last budget speech of the Treasurer (Mr Willis). This sale does nothing to generate a real budget surplus. About the only thing to be said for it is that the bank will be rid of a shareholder that no longer believes in investing in anything.

This bill is an epitaph marking a loss of national vision. It tells us that we no longer have a government that believes in nation building, in saving for the future or in economy in government, which will sell anything to pay for promises that it cannot keep, and which believes that massaging the media on budget night is more important than genuinely good government.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I say these things with some feeling. As you know, I was concerned very strongly by the attempt to castrate the Commonwealth Bank many years ago—an attempt that was proposed by a conservative government. You can call me sentimental, if you like, and say that I am not facing up to the real economic world. You might say that I have failed to recognise that the Commonwealth Bank is operating as just another bank. I do not fail to recognise that but I had hoped that whilst ever the Commonwealth was the majority shareholder in this enterprise the principles upon which the bank was founded by Andrew Fisher might have been enforced upon the bank and might have prevailed. It is obvious that the representatives of the major shareholder, the Commonwealth, have not pursued these principles for a long time.

Finally, I make mention of something that has just occurred to me. I understood at the time of the sale of Commonwealth Bank shares that the government undertook to retain the majority shareholding in the bank. That undertaking is being undermined by this legislation. What of the people who have invested on the basis of that undertaking? Where are they? Was that a false prospectus?

I suppose I should apologise, particularly to the government, for some of the things that I have said because I said them with feeling. I tend not to criticise in those terms generally but I feel very strongly about this matter and everything I have said I believe to be accurate. I oppose most strongly the sale of the Commonwealth Bank.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate on the Commonwealth Bank Sale Bill 1995. The various positions that senators and their parties are taking have been well canvassed in the media. It is the government's strong intention to proceed with the sale of its 50.4 per cent shareholding in the Commonwealth Bank as announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 9 May 1995.

PARA.TAB: The government envisages the first of possibly two public share offers, and a possible CBA buy-back of government shares, before 30 June 1996. The passage of this bill without amendment is fundamental to that process. The task force on asset sales is responsible for the physical sale process. The sale process issues are still being looked at by the task force. If the bill passes through this chamber without amendment, the process will continue without hindrance.
The sale of the Commonwealth's 50.4 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank shareholding will not have an adverse impact on financial services in rural areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't believe you are reading a handwritten speech at the last minute. You have 50 more staff than we have.
—With all due respect, Senator Kernot, the advisers take notes of what various speakers contribute through the debate, so it is not possible to run out—
—But you did not look at it until after you stood up.
—They were still making notes and I was listening to the contribution made by Senator Harradine, who made an impassioned plea for the retention of the bank that went back to 1912.
—Your delivery is suffering. The appearance of what you are saying is suffering.

—I apologise if you feel offended by that. There is a wide range of delivery mechanisms for financial services in rural areas, including EFTPOS facilities. Overall, the government believes that this obviously is an important measure. We do want this bill carried before the end of this week unamended. We do note that the opposition is supporting it and that the major parties are opposing it. I believe there are amendments being proposed by the Democrats.
—I think half of your party are opposing it too.

—There may have been in the past. It has been debated in the party, that is very true. We do not hide the fact that there is a range of opinion. But the majority of the parliamentary Labor Party overwhelmingly supported this measure for the sale of the Commonwealth Bank.

PARA.TAB: I have to say as the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, seeing many of the complaints in the small business community about the problems of access to finance, access to borrowings and access to equity—and I over the last two and three-quarter years as a minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are selling off the Development Bank. You are selling it off.
—I have to say that, even with the Commonwealth Development Bank, I have raised on innumerable occasions issues on behalf of small business who have approached me—
—We won't be able to raise many more, will we?

—Because the Commonwealth Development Bank was a subsidiary of the Commonwealth Bank, two things started to occur. Firstly, the other commercial banks would not refer business to the Commonwealth Development Bank because, in the end, they believed that would mean that the Commonwealth Trading Bank would have an advantage in gathering business and clients. In discussions with the private banks, in one way or the other they basically conceded that point. So the Commonwealth Development Bank was not having referred to it applications from people who had failed in the commercial sector. Those commercial banks were not referring them. People had to go off and make their own arrangements to approach the Commonwealth Development Bank.

PARA.TAB: In many cases the Commonwealth Development Bank found that, once the Commonwealth Bank's shares were listed, they themselves were under pressure to perform and not unnecessarily affect the bottom line of the bank. So those issues, if you are talking about effect in the small business community in the lending area—

TALK.START.PARA: —So you stuffed up on privatisation.

—No. All I can say is, over a long period of time—apart from the Commonwealth Development Bank, which was consistently, overwhelmingly, looking at funding in the farming area, in the rural area—as far as funding for the broader based small business community, there were complaints that they were not providing the level of capital that people wanted, which I do not in many way blame the officers of the Commonwealth Development Bank for.

PARA.TAB: Overwhelming, on the trading side, the Commonwealth Bank had long since moved away, before any sale of the shares first took place a few years ago, from any notion of the description that Senator Harradine has put here—others have also mentioned it, including Senator Margetts—going back to the vision of King O'Malley in 1911 and 1912.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with the people's bank? What is wrong with the concept of the people's bank?

—I have to say, Senator, you then have to take a major decision that the government will intervene and underwrite those applications for loans that are considered more risky, because they will not get them from the private sector. I have to say, coming from the state of South Australia that when banks in South Australia or Victoria were allowed to go out during the 1980s, they made a number of catastrophic decisions, for which, in the end, the taxpayer had to pick up the loss. In my state it was to the tune of over $3 billion. That was all done by an independent board, appointed in accordance with the legislation, which said that the then State Bank had to be at arms-length from the government. So it was at arms-length, but in the end, when they made bad decisions on investment, the bottom line was the taxpayers of South Australia had to bail out the State Bank of South Australia to the tune of $3 billion.
—It might have had something to do with inadequate monitoring processes on the way through?

—In South Australia we were damned if we did and we were damned if we didn't. If there had been an attempt by Treasury and the state Treasurer to run the State Bank of South Australia closely, there would have been indications of government interference, political interference in the lending processes of that bank. The bank's legislation was established to make sure that that did not occur. So the bank had an independent board and it went off and did what it did. When it lost a large amount of money, the government still got the blame for it.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Bank did suffer some losses during the late 1980s but, fortunately, nowhere near the losses of the other commercial banks. Thank goodness it did not, because the taxpayers in one form of another may well have been asked to pick up the losses and guarantee the losses. At that stage there would have been a lot of uncomfortable people in this parliament.

When people talk in this chamber and in the parliament about the need for the Commonwealth Bank to be there to provide assistance as a people's bank in the internationally competitive economy that we now have in Australia, which is not just a closed economy, and when the Commonwealth Bank is not just providing housing loans and is a lot more than a variation of a sophisticated housing society, then you are in a quite different world. The government believes that the process we are going through is quite reasonable. It was debated vigorously in the Labor Party and in the community, but the government did decide to take these measures. We commend the bill to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule, page 15, item 28, after proposed subsection 74B(2), insert the following subsections:
"`(2A) Prior to the transfer date, a shareholders' agreement is to be entered into between the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth Bank stating, at least in general terms:

PARA.TAB: (a)the charter conditions under which the Commonwealth Development Bank (the Development Bank) is to operate and generally reflecting sections 72, 73 and 74 of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 as in force prior to the commencement of the Commonwealth Bank Sale Act 1995; and

TAB.TAB: (b)the annual subsidy determination and review arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: `(2B) The memorandum and articles of the Development Bank are to include a provision that the charter conditions of the Development Bank must not be amended unless the proposed amendment has been approved by 95 per cent of the shareholders.

`(2C) The Commonwealth must not reduce its shareholding in the Development Bank or, as a shareholder, agree to any proposed amendment of the memorandum and articles of the Development Bank unless each House of the Parliament, by resolution, approves a proposal for such an amendment.".

My amendment is to the schedule. This amendment seeks, as I said in my speech at the second reading stage, to ensure that the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank cannot be bartered away between the Commonwealth Bank and future Treasurers because, as they see it, there are some fiscal imperatives to produce so-called budget surpluses.

PARA.TAB: This amendment seeks to minimise the number of losers from this inappropriate privatisation. It seeks to ensure that these losers do not include the rural and small business operators who make up the clientele of the Commonwealth Development Bank. The amendment makes it clear that, prior to the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, the future role and funding of the Development Bank is finalised and in a written agreement. This agreement would incorporate the charter activities currently set out in sections 72, 73 and 74 of the Commonwealth Banks Act. The clause would require that the memorandum and articles of the Commonwealth Development Bank would require that the charter could not be altered without the approval of 95 per cent of shareholders' equity.

The third part of the amendment then requires that the Commonwealth cannot sell its share below five per cent or agree to changes to the charter without a resolution of both houses of the parliament—none of this ministerial whim. This will guarantee that, before the Commonwealth Development Bank role changes, there must be public debt. Through the parliament, the rural and small business sectors who rely heavily on the Development Bank will be able to have a say as to whether the proposed changes should or should not be supported.

This amendment is attempting to put into black letter law the first limb of what we just saw in the opposition's second reading amendment. It is an opportunity for the Senate to say to the government, `Listen, we are not buying these empty assurances. We are very dubious about commitments given that are later breached. We are no longer prepared to make a pyrrhic stand on the second reading and then hope maybe that the government gets the message.' It does not work like that. It is quite clear that, unless we guarantee the future of the Development Bank in black letter law, the Commonwealth Development Bank will cease to exist, probably sooner rather than later.

The government assures us, `Don't worry, all will be well. The Development Bank charter will be incorporated into a written, legally enforceable agreement between the minister and the Commonwealth Bank and the agreement is already largely complete.' The first part of my amendment provides a legislative necessity for completing this process.

But the agreement makes it clear that the Commonwealth Bank will only agree not to amend the charter while there is an adequate subsidy in place. As I remarked in the second reading debate, I do not get the impression that the Commonwealth Bank is terribly keen on its charter business. Its annual report made that pretty clear when it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bank's objective remains to achieve a proper commercial balance between the consequences of the charter and the size of any subsidy received in support of it.

Read carefully, that means the Commonwealth Bank does not see any community service obligation in continuing to provide a lender of the last resort facility to rural and small business operators, unless it can make a good buck out of it or unless the government pays. Why should it? It is a private company and its shareholders will expect a return on their investment.

PARA.TAB: But trying to place community service obligations into a contract is not as preferable as placing them in legislation. This amendment is a compromise: it leaves them in the contract and in the memorandum and articles of association; but it makes it clear that the federal Treasurer, as the minority shareholder, will take his instructions from parliament on how he will act. The amendment also makes it abundantly clear well in advance of the float that the Commonwealth Bank will have to abide by the charter whether it likes it or not. In that way, it can discount the value of its shares according to the restriction, if it needs to.

We have heard a little bit about community service obligations—not a lot. As I am finding myself saying more regularly here, the whole concept of the public interest is a dying concept in this brave new world. But the community service obligations of the Development Bank are very important; they are too important just to be ditched like this.

The Commonwealth does play a vital role in rural finance, which the Democrats believe we should not relinquish—especially now with the financial pressures existing in the area of rural finance. Despite what Senator Schacht has said, I do think the Development Bank plays a vital role in small business finance. We have a third of the small businesses still reporting that they are constrained by finance, and the Development Bank has a continuing role to play in plugging that hole in our financial system.So the Democrats are of the very firm view that the Development Bank should not be sold.

Today we have been told all about how times change, that there is no role left for government to have a bank with which to set standards of any sort and that that has all gone. Even if there were an argument that the Commonwealth Bank as a whole is operating on a purely commercial basis with no real public interest constraint, the role of the Development Bank is different. It does have community service obligations and public interest constraints; they are set out in sections 72 to 74 of the Commonwealth Bank Act.

Before we say a public sector intervention role is not fashionable or appropriate, I think we should look at where else it has been employed recently in legislation. The first thing I would point to is the One Nation package in 1992, with its capital injection of $30 million and a continuing $20 million subsidy to ensure that the financing of projects which would not otherwise qualify for assistance indeed do qualify. Working Nation committed a further $2 million to the Development Bank for the advertising of its services to the small business sector. So the government recognises the strategic importance of a body like the Development Bank.

That bank should stay in public hands. It is really regrettable that the government is so determined to sell it. To the opposition parties, and to all of those who have made the observation in the debate that `We cannot incur these liabilities; we cannot expect privatised entities to have to carry any kind of community service obligation', I would point out that it is not unusual to privatise a public utility, subject to that entity maintaining certain community service obligations.

I will give some examples. In Victoria, there is the office of the regulator-general holding a watching brief over privatised utilities. The sale of the State Bank of New South Wales was subject to the new owners agreeing to a long list of conditions about the carrying on of New South Wales business, the security of employees, maintaining a New South Wales emphasis, and so on. In this parliament, when we were debating the sale of the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline, that ended up being made subject to an access regime. Also, in the Qantas sale, a string of conditions exist entrenching Australian control of the board.

So what has the good old Development Bank done wrong? Why not add this to the Development Bank? Aren't its community service obligations of sufficient value and importance to rural producers and small business to be preserved?

If the opposition is not prepared to sanction a community service obligation such as this being entrenched ahead of privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank, we have to ask the question, for example: if you have won government and gone ahead and privatised Telstra, why aren't rural communities and consumers of Telstra entitled to believe that you will do away with the current Telstra community service obligations? If you will not support them now for the Commonwealth Development Bank, what makes it any different for Telstra?

So I say to the opposition, but I say to the National Party in particular: we have seen much hand wringing and heard much angst, we have seen the statements that have been made in the other place, but a second reading amendment is not good enough. You profess to be very worried about the future of the Development Bank; here is the solution. Let us put the whole role and the financing of the Development Bank into a disallowable regulation—and that enshrining the charter. Let us guarantee a future for this lender of the last resort, commonly known and appreciated as the farmer's friend.

Let us have an end once and for all to all this wailing and gnashing of teeth against a measure on the one hand, and then a very convenient quiet little voting for it on the other. You are about to be tested, Senator McGauran, Senator Boswell, if you are listening, and other members of the National Party. It is not good enough to stand up and say how terrible it is and then vote for it. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be voting for this amendment. I share the Democrats' concern about the Commonwealth Development Bank, and I think we made that clear in our amendment in the second reading debate. But we do not believe that it is right for the government, in getting out of the Commonwealth Bank, divesting itself of the Commonwealth Development Bank and the Commonwealth Bank, selling it, to be retaining an eight per cent share. The Treasurer would then come back in with a disproportionate power. He would come back with virtually the same power over the Development Bank as that which the government held previously. That just goes against the principle of privatisation.

PARA.TAB: We do not believe that the Treasurer should have the same degree of involvement in a privatised Commonwealth Bank as he did in the past when the Commonwealth was a major shareholder. Let us face it, the major concern we have about the Commonwealth Development Bank is the loss of the subsidy. No matter which political party or parties may make up the government of the day, if that subsidy is there, open and up-front for everybody to see, then the government of the day will be showing its true colours: whether, in fact, it supports the Development Bank and, through that, small business and the rural sector—not by some other deal which is being done through the backdoor, as may have been occurring in the past. That was our concern: that the subsidy by the government of the day would continue to be paid to the Commonwealth Development Bank.

It may be that the government of the day may decide to assist small business and the rural sector in other ways, not just through the Development Bank. That is a decision for the government at the time. What we are on about today is a complete privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. We oppose the Democrats amendment purely and simply because we do not believe the Treasurer, as an eight per cent shareholder in this bank, should have the powers that the Democrats propose in this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with the view that Senator Calvert has in relation to this bill. Let me explain why. If you take the route that is proposed by Senator Kernot, you do, as Senator Calvert has said, create a disproportionate power in favour of the Treasurer. It is also an inflexible route—
—What about the farmers, Senator O'Chee?

—Well, I am going to tell you about the farmers, Senator Kernot, if you will stop bleating. The reason being that a future government may choose to deal with this in an entirely different way. A future government may decide, for example, to leave the Commonwealth Development Bank in there and to take the loan portfolio out of the assets to be privatised and put it into a different entity. A future government may find different ways in which it wishes to assist small business and the transfer of the loan portfolio out of the bank before it is sold might be the appropriate way to do that. The amendment that Senator Kernot has put before the chamber denies a future government that opportunity. That is why I think the amendment is short-sighted.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot should understand that there are very real reasons why we, on this side of the chamber, do not concur with her. It is not that we do not care about farmers—we care about farmers a great deal more, judging by some of the nonsense that has come out of the Democrats—but our concern is to do things the right way.

What Senator Kernot is doing has the potential to reduce the attractiveness of the remaining tranche of the Commonwealth Bank because institutional investors of the bank will say, `We have concerns as to how independent it can really be because we are going to have this federal Treasurer leaning over the bank's shoulders at every opportunity, every time there is some political pressure.' That is inappropriate, that is short-sighted and it shows that Senator Kernot does not understand the sensitivity of the market when you come to do these privatisations.

The fact is that I do happen to know a little more about privatisations and the capital markets than Senator Kernot and anything of this nature runs the risk of degrading the value of the remaining stake in the bank. We see the best way, if it is to remain within the Commonwealth Bank, as to subsidise and then, of course, good banking practice has to prevail.

There is a subsidy and that meets the Commonwealth's obligations. If you are to say we want a private sector bank to receive a Commonwealth subsidy and on top of the subsidy ignore good banking practice for whatever reason, then people are going to say, `We don't want to take a stake in this sort of bank.' They are going to say, `We believe this reduces the potential for profit and therefore we believe it reduces the value of the bank as a privatised entity.'

TALK.START.PARA: —And it creates conflict with the government of the day.

—And it creates conflict with the government of the day and nobody who is a banker wants to have a conflict with the government. In other words, you are saying to whoever buys a stake in the bank, `Come and put your money up, put your money into this bank—
—Where do the farmers fit into your argument, Senator?

—I am going to get onto that in a minute, Senator Kernot—`put your money into this bank and just put your head on the chopping block for every argument with the Treasurer of the day every time the political heat gets a little bit too much.' I do not think any sensible banker wants to put his money up in that regard. Senator Kernot says, `Where do the farmers come into this?' as though chanting this mantra is going to achieve some sort of intelligent contribution to the debate. There are ways in which we can deal with the concerns that the farming sector has.
—How? Tell them.
—I have just told you once already, Senator Kernot.
—That is the shareholders.

—No, Senator Kernot, you weren't listening. I will repeat it for you but, quite frankly, my patience is wearing a little bit thin. I said that a future government may decide that the best way to deal with it is to transfer the loan portfolio out of the Commonwealth government prior to privatisation.
—I rise on a point of order. Do you, Temporary Chairman, think you could direct the speaker's comments through the chair rather than have a nasty fight across the chamber?
—On the point of order: I accept that but I would also accept the fact that I have a right to speak without continual interjection from the far end of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—If there were fewer interjections I am sure Senator O'Chee would speak through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. As I was saying, a future government may choose, for example, to transfer the loan portfolio out of the Commonwealth Bank, in which case the named entity, the Commonwealth Development Bank, would not actually have any loans to farmers anyway.
—Like they do with housing loans.
—As Senator Calvert has said, that is something that was done with housing loans.
—Westpac.

—Yes, exactly. That would be a perfectly feasible way to do it. But those who continually interject, `What about the farmers?' without listening to the answer that has already been given in relation to that point show that they do not understand the slightest bit of banking practice. It is not the named entity with which we should have concern; it is the loans that that entity currently has on its books.

PARA.TAB: If on a future date—and remember this privatisation is not going to occur until after the election—whichever government is in power chooses to take a different route in relation to the loan portfolio that is currently in the name of the Commonwealth Development Bank and it meets the concerns of the farming sector, that is fine. We do not need to concern ourselves with the named entity anymore. It is the loans that are of more concern. We in the coalition just do not accept the assertion that this is the best way to deal with those concerns. We believe it to be short-sighted. We believe it to be inflexible, and we believe it shows the ignorance of banking practice by those who moved this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the rationale behind Senator Kernot's amendment. The problem we see is that government wants to have its cake and eat it too. I think it might end up not having it, not eating it and it might seem a much simpler outcome. The government wants to sell the Commonwealth Development Bank along with the Commonwealth Bank. At the same time it wants the programs and loans of the Development Bank to continue. It proposes to sell the bank with a guaranteed subsidy to assure this.

PARA.TAB: The government wants to keep the Development Bank going. I cannot understand why it cannot, as a majority owner of the Commonwealth Bank, sell the Development Bank to the Commonwealth. It would then administer the Development Bank in whatever way it likes and promote the policies it likes in the most direct manner. It would be ultimately accountable to parliament.

I do not see that as a bad thing. It makes far more sense than to sell the Development Bank along with the Commonwealth Bank, have the new owners of the Commonwealth Bank onsell the Development Bank and then have the government subsidise an unknown private sector owner to attempt to have an influence on its practice. Frankly, the latter course seems to be a virtual guarantee of a bad outcome. The government objective is to primarily sell the Development Bank. I guess it can do so. Either it should have a vehicle for acting upon investment policy or it should abandon it or it should regulate that all banks have certain obligations.

This creation of a high bred private sector quasi government business enterprise reminds me of nothing more than the government's attempt to create a private sector superannuation industry that it can run to accomplish its policy objectives outside of parliamentary scrutiny. It is bad practice and the success of such a strategy is extremely dubious.

The Democrat amendment is substantive. It effectively says that the Commonwealth cannot sell the Commonwealth Bank until 15 sitting days after it gets an agreement, including the whole raft of things that have been specified under proposed section 3A. We have some problems with this amendment, as I mentioned. I understand the intent and appreciate what the Democrats are trying to do here, but I think the effect is to make the government's scheme work.

Under the Democrats' function section, subsection A, they basically outcome a good intention for the Development Bank to continue as was originally intended—that is, to provide funds for industry and primary producers, especially small business. But the test is in the opinion of the Development Bank, which would now be in private hands. Its opinion may vary significantly from that of government or parliament. In subsection B, it seeks to tie a private bank to accordance with policies approved by the Treasurer. In other words, it seeks to make a private bank exactly the sort of quasi government business enterprise that I referred to above.

There is no provision at all for such an organisation to report to parliament, in spite of the fact it still gets government subsidy, and no provision at all for the Treasury to be accountable for the policies promoted or endorsed in regard to such a quasi GBE. This is a dangerous precedent. The fact that the Democrats have proposed a general definition of functions does not make it less dangerous, since it is clearly a definition subject to interpretation. It cannot be questioned.

The final section on contributions may also be a problem in that it is an undefined agreement for expenditure of Commonwealth money, with no real mechanism for accountability of either the Development Bank or the minister. I am sure that estimates would just show it as an expenditure for subsidy of share subscription as a public company rather than a true public sector company—the Development Bank. It would not even need to give parliament an annual report.

In short, although I appreciate the sense in which it is put forward, and although we all feel fairly desperate and depressed by this whole measure, we cannot support the amendment. As I have indicated, if the Commonwealth wishes to ensure loans are available for certain purposes and to have some measure of control over such investments, it should do so through a business which it directly and accountably controls.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a full debate on this most important bill regarding the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. There is no doubt that the minor parties and Senator Harradine have been emotionally attached to this debate, particularly Senator Kernot. Not only has she given a second reading address and a committee stage address, but she has consistently interrupted speakers along the way. Such is her emotion on this bill—and in many respects rightly so. There is a great deal of community attachment to the Commonwealth Bank, given its origins and its ideals, which go back to 1912. Just because they go back to 1912 it does not make them any less an ideal or any more old-fashioned in their origin.

PARA.TAB: For all intents and purposes, we are quite aware that, whatever the perception of the Commonwealth Bank, real or not—probably not real—it is a very romanticised bank. We understand that. We know the public attach themselves to certain banks. In my own state of Victoria when the State Bank collapsed in 1990 and was, ironically, taken over by the Commonwealth Bank, such was the attachment of the local investors that they were not willing to transfer their funds to another bank, even though it was the Commonwealth Bank. They saw the Bank of Melbourne as a great opportunity to keep their money in the state, as they viewed it. I am glad there is a sentimental attachment to the banking sector. That is part of its competitive nature. It is not all as rational as many from the other side of the House would lead us to believe.

Having said that, I must again address the government's attitude to this bill. Only one government senator addressed this bill during the second reading stage. I dare say we will not be getting another contribution from that side during the committee stage. Senator Wheelwright was the government senator who spoke during the second reading stage. He is a new senator, virtually unknown to this chamber, virtually unknown to the public. They wheeled in Senator Wheelwright to address this bill. Given the emotion and the importance of this bill—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Senator Boswell?

—I am sure Senator Boswell is watching this debate, line by line, on the television set in his room. He has the same sentiments as the coalition. He knows all too well the origins not only of the Commonwealth Bank, which was a Labor Party initiative, but also of its attachment, the Development Bank, which was established by Artie Fadden, the National Party leader.

PARA.TAB: This chamber has every right to be emotional about this bill. I have no doubt those on both sides of the house have mixed feelings about this, but the time has come to privatise the Commonwealth Bank. But where is the left wing of the party which has made the Commonwealth Bank the cornerstone of their ideology and philosophy, just as the National Party would with the Australian Wheat Board? Where are Senator Carr, Senator Coates, Senator Colston and Senator Childs—the four big Cs from the Left? Where are they on this bill? Can't they even muster the slightest bit of emotion on this bill? We know which way they are going to vote and we are not asking them to cross the floor with the Democrats. But can't they even contribute a minute to this debate?

They were rolled embarrassingly at budget time. They were caught by surprise. They were ambushed at budget time when this sale of the bank was dumped on their desk. But since then they have had time to at least find some form of words that will not sell out the government but which would mean they would have on paper, for their little socialist meetings down at the trades hall, that at least they have contributed something to this debate, so that they did not just roll over once or twice on this bill. That is where the real disappointment lies—that they have not got the courage to put their view, even in the mildest form, not even to wave goodbye to the final cornerstone upon which they built a whole socialist dream. It is the end for them. They will not even have the courage to come into the chamber.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—Order! It might be better to get back to the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which way are you voting, Julian?

—The point is, minister, as I said, we are all entitled to our views on this bill. We will not be supporting Senator Kernot's amendment. It has to be asked: why didn't Senator Kernot support our second reading amendment?
—I said I couldn't support (b) but (a) and (c) I could.
—Why didn't you ask us to separate them for you?
—I did—last week.

—I never heard you. Senator Kernot, as usual, you are splitting straws. There was the amendment for you to support, you had the numbers on that. It went straight to the heart of the Commonwealth Development Bank—a National Party initiative, way back in 1960, just pre-Jack McEwen days. In fact, that was seen as the golden era of the National Party. The point is that Senator Kernot should not cry crocodile tears for the Commonwealth Bank. It was lost when the first tranche was privatised.

PARA.TAB: It is critical that the finance sector remain competitive or we will have a closed financial market and the client, the consumer and the depositor will be the losers. Ironically, now that we have reached this stage, the full privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank will add to the competitiveness of the market. An unleashed Commonwealth Bank will be able to take on the other top three banks. At the moment it is handicapped, so an unleashed Commonwealth Bank, in many respects, will add to the competitive nature of the financial sector.

It is also critical that the regionals and the small banks be protected in some form or other. That has been done by the Trade Practices Commission. The rise of the regional banks has created a tremendous amount of fresh and invigorating competition in the financial market against the top four. The Trade Practices Commission recently handed down a ruling that has set in place a competitive banking sector—that is, in each state there must be at least one major regional. In Victoria, it is the Bank of Melbourne; in New South Wales, it is the St George Bank; in Queensland—

TALK.START.PARA: —Bank of Queensland.

—Bank of Queensland—thank you, Senator O'Chee. Those banks are serious competitors against the top four banks. They have now joined the market. Indeed, I say to Senator Kernot that that is where the real competition will come, not from a government owned Commonwealth Bank.

PARA.TAB: For those reasons we will not be supporting the Democrats' amendment which would give the Treasurer extra powers. We see that these extra intervention powers that you want to give the Treasurer could in many respects stifle the maximum return from the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. We are concerned about the subsidy process for the Commonwealth Development Bank. Again we ask the minister: what is the future of that subsidy? Does the Commonwealth Development Bank have a future?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —No amount of bluster, whether from Senator O'Chee or Senator McGauran, can disguise the mantra that we are hearing. That mantra is maximise the price and minimise the obligations because that is what best banking practice requires. I do not think that farmers will place much store on the kind of alternative that Senator O'Chee raised this evening.

PARA.TAB: They see banks' practice over the last couple of years as closing down branches in rural communities all around Australia. Banks' best practice and good banking practice these days means maximising the profits, maximising the price and minimising the obligations. I think it is a great pity that members of the National Party are trying to dress up a debate in this way. They are deserting the farmers who have severe concerns about what the end of the Commonwealth Development Bank, which they have relied on, really means for them and who is going to replace it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to some of the points made in this debate. The community service obligation will continue as outlined in the memorandum of association of the CDB. The bank will continue to lend to small- and medium-sized businesses, including in the rural sector. The government will continue to pay a subsidy to the Commonwealth Development Bank accordingly.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth has already provided a commitment that it will enter into a legally enforceable agreement with the CBA prior to transfer time, as defined in the legislation, for the future operation of the CDB. The agreement will provide an undertaking by the CBA that it will not use its voting power to repeal or amend the CDB's charter which will be included in the CDB's memorandum of association. The CDB's charter will not be changed—that is, the charter currently in sections 72 and 73 of the CBA Act 1959 and will be in the CDB's memorandum of association. The shareholders' agreement will also define the annual subsidy arrangements.

The shareholding of the CDB will be owned 91 per cent by the CBA and 8.1 per cent by the Commonwealth of Australia. The proposed amendment fails to recognise this fact. The amendment should not be accepted as it may contravene the Corporations Law. This amendment could raise a number of serious Corporations Law issues for the CDB which is to become a public company under the Corporations Law. The amendment would remove the normal powers of the shareholders from the Corporations Law to the parliament. This is unacceptable given that the Commonwealth is only a small minority shareholder.

I have responded to the amendment moved by the Democrats and explained why it is unacceptable. I did listen to some of the remarks made by Senator O'Chee and Senator McGauran. I must say that for a large part of their remarks I actually thought they were supporting the amendment moved by the Democrats and had the same views as the Democrats.

I think it is a bit cheeky for Senator McGauran to say that there are people in the Labor Party who are embarrassed by this legislation when it is quite clear that a large section of the National Party is embarrassed by it, probably because of the old saying of the Country Party, as it then was, that it is basically about socialising your loses and capitalising your gains in economic policy in rural areas of Australia. We are quite open about the fact that there were and are people in the Labor Party who are unhappy about this measure. But a substantial majority of the Labor Party supported this as part of a budget measure. The government will support the legislation and I ask that the amendment be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put my point to the minister one more time. As I understand it, he said the future of the subsidy will be announced in the shareholders' agreement. I ask the minister: is there a future for the subsidy and will the subsidy be maintained?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the subsidy will be defined in the shareholders' agreement and the shareholders' agreement will be publicly available before the sale.
—Is there a process by which the subsidy would be withdrawn if it was not being used for the specified process?
—The subsidy will continue to be provided so long as the Commonwealth Development Bank continues to provide the service that is in the memorandum and in the agreement.
—What is the process of accountability by which the minister makes a decision about whether or not the subsidy continues?
—It is obvious that the subsidy will be an appropriation in the annual budget and will be debated in the parliament.
—If it is an appropriation and will be debated in the parliament, are you suggesting that it will be a separate measure that the Senate could amend?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The subsidy will obviously be prepared by government as part of the budget process and will therefore be put to the parliament. It will be contained in the normal measures. On the advice I have, it will be in the portfolio outlays and that means that it will probably be in an appropriation bill.
—Are you suggesting that it will be tacked on to the ordinary annual services bill?
—Yes.
—I take your word for it that that is what the government intends to do, but I would seriously suggest that the government reconsider that intention.
—What do you suggest we do, Senator?
—It would present serious difficulties for the Senate in exercising its powers, although I do not think in the long run the Senate would quibble about that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been pointed out to me that at the moment we are providing an annual subsidy to the CDB of $20 million. That is in the portfolio allocations for Treasury because it is responsible for the Commonwealth Bank and the Treasurer is responsible to the parliament for the Commonwealth Bank. The normal processes will continue.
—The point is that we are talking about the sale of the Commonwealth Development Bank—
—No, we are talking about the subsidy.

—I know. It is one thing to provide a subsidy of $20 million—I think that was the amount last year—for the bank because it had the community obligation and it had, presumably, the government looking over its shoulder to ensure that the community obligation was observed. It is another thing entirely for the government to act in a similar fashion when the bank is privatised and this obligation is simply part of an agreement. What I am asking you, and pointing out as well, is: what happens in future years in respect of that particular agreement?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I will just point out to you that the shareholding for the CDB will be 91.9 per cent by the CBA and 8.1 per cent by the Commonwealth. I am advised that is the existing shareholding structure of the Commonwealth Development Bank. That is not changing, and the subsidy that they were getting is the arrangement of the subsidy continuing. Obviously the amount may well change from time to time and will be debated in the parliament as part of the budget appropriation.

PARA.TAB: We are not selling the Commonwealth Development Bank. We are not changing the existing structure in shareholding arrangements of the Commonwealth Development Bank. I think that ought to be put on the record and made quite clear. The subsidy arrangement is presently being provided on an annual basis through the appropriation bills. The outlays, when printed in the budget outlays, are for the Treasurer, who is responsible for the Treasury department and for the Commonwealth Development Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just point out to the committee that it is not the same shareholding arrangement. What you have is 91 per cent owned by the Commonwealth Trading Bank, which in turn is majority owned by the Commonwealth. You cannot get up here and say it is the same ownership; in other words, that the Commonwealth does not have the same say and muscle over what happens. So really it is not appropriate for you to get up here and suggest that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I accept that point, Senator Harradine: that because the Commonwealth Bank will own 91.9 per cent of the Commonwealth Development Bank, now that the Commonwealth Bank is totally sold off, that 91.9 per cent now has a different combination because it is partly owned by the private sector and partly owned by the Commonwealth. I accept that. But I have pointed out that the agreement for the operation of the Commonwealth Development Bank will be a shareholders' agreement and a memorandum of understanding, and that will be made public. So the way the subsidy will work will be publicly transparent. Obviously someone may disagree with it, but it will be publicly transparent. Obviously each year there will be a line in the outlays for the Treasurer's department saying what the subsidy is for the Commonwealth Development Bank.

PARA.TAB: I know the point you may well make is that it is in the appropriation and it is a bit hard to get up and move an amendment in view of this changing the budget and stopping supply and so on. I am sure a public debate about the size, or the lack of size, of the subsidy or how the subsidy is being used would create more than a passing interest in the community. Any government which tried to be a bit slippery about it, to use that term, would have to take its chances of the public opprobrium of not being able to justify what it did. I think that public transparency is the major protection. In view of the fact that there is a lot of interest on all sides of this chamber, no matter how people are voting here—and we have had an example of some members of the National Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your fellows?

—Yes, all right. Knowing full well the clients of the Commonwealth Development Bank—and overwhelmingly they are in the rural sector at the moment—and knowing how well farmers organise through their organisations, I am sure they would be rolling stuff down here pretty quickly if they thought the Commonwealth Development Bank was being got at because the subsidy had changed adversely or the memorandum or the shareholders' agreement was being undermined in some way. There would be a very public debate about it. That transparency is the major protection for the long term from all sides of politics.

That the amendment (Senator Kernot's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister: in respect of the subsidy for the newly owned CDB, what number appropriation bill is that to be included in? If he cannot say, could he take that on notice?
—I will take that on notice, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) welcome this initiative to promote Australian shipping and Australian crews and will be supporting the passage of the International Shipping (Australian-Resident Seafarers) Grants Bill 1995. I understand that both the Australian Shipowners Association and the Maritime Union also support this bill.

PARA.TAB: Many people will be aware of the ongoing concern that I have had in relation to Australian shipping and, in particular, to the industrial relations transport policy and environmental concerns. It is absolutely vital for this island continent that we have a viable and safe Australian owned or controlled shipping industry. This government should be committed to ensuring this aim.

Unfortunately, this initiative is one of the few positive policy decisions that have emanated from the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in relation to Australian shipping whilst I have been a senator in this parliament. In fact, the broad thrust of the government's economic and trade policies to promote international free trade and competitiveness at any cost has acted against the interests of the Australian shipping industry. We cannot afford to accept the international trend to lower standards in safety and labour all in the name of international competitiveness. We have seen many examples in recent years of the potentially disastrous effects of a major shipping accident on the fragile ecosystems of our large coastline.

I trust that this bill, which will assist shipowners in maintaining Australian crews on Australian flag shipping, will pass and we will see some more positive initiatives from this government to protect the Australian shipping industry and the Australian Maritime Union.
