DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be supporting the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2). The purpose of the bill is to give effect to certain 1995-96 budget initiatives announced in May this year. Firstly, there will be a cessation of the gifted and talented children's scheme, resulting in a saving of $1.1 million during the 1996 calendar year. Secondly, there will be a cessation of the gender equity program, resulting in a saving of $1.5 million a year. Thirdly, there will be a cessation of the rural hostels program, resulting in a saving of $1.1 million a year. Fourthly, there will be the commencement of transitional support in non-government schools to assist students with disabilities to make the transition to mainstream school education or pursue further training or employment. This program involves an additional expenditure of $3.2 million in the calendar year 1996. Fifthly, there will be an extension of the early literacy program, leading to the expenditure of an additional $8.9 million.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will not be opposing the measures in this bill. In taking this position the coalition is not giving its imprimatur to the decisions made by the government which are included in the bill. Indeed, in office the coalition may well look again at some of these decisions. The government's actions in the 1995-96 budget mean that no new grants will be provided in 1996 for key programs in primary and secondary schools, such as the program to improve the learning experience of girls and the special project for non-government rural schools student hostels. They also mean an end to the program to assist gifted and talented children.

These decisions are all very short-sighted and educationally unsound. However, it is clearly unreasonable to ask the coalition to act as a de facto government in this instance and make judgments about expenditure priorities to this level of detail when it does not have the advantage of the advice and perspective of the government's many public servants. It is for this reason the coalition will establish a commission of audit immediately following the next election. After 13 years of Labor government and Labor expenditure, it is not only necessary but vital that Australia takes a very detailed and critical look at how and where the government spends the people's resources.

This bill provides funds to extend a number of programs introduced by the government over recent years. It also withdraws funding from a number of other programs. Where the government has withdrawn funding from programs, I would welcome the government explaining to the Senate on what efficiency and effectiveness grounds those decisions have been made. If efficiency and effectiveness were not grounds for withdrawing funds, the question needs to be raised as to why funding was provided in the first place. What performance measures were established for the programs, and what evaluations were conducted of these programs? These are not merely academic questions.

Under the government's own reform of the Public Service, performance measures should have been applied to these programs and it should have been on the basis of evaluation of these performance measures that the government made these decisions to withdraw funds. The coalition would welcome the government advising the Senate on these matters. The decision in the bill to withdraw funding for the three programs that I mentioned earlier were the decisions of a Labor cabinet, a Labor government, advised by the Public Service but with responsibility for decisions resting entirely with the Labor Party, its ministers and its parliamentary representatives.

The coalition wants the government to be judged by the Australian people on this sort of record. Its record will now include withdrawal of funding from the gifted and talented children's program, from the disadvantaged and isolated girls program and from an access to school scheme for isolated children from rural communities. Let the government defend its record. The coalition will not be opposing these measures in the states grants bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been told in some detail by Senator Tierney about the provisions of the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2). There is no way I can disagree with his description. It is accurate and quite succinct. But I am a little concerned about the circle that he drew in attempting to explain where the coalition was getting any logic from in its position. It went something along the lines we heard before the 1993 election: we are not going to oppose this but when we get into government we are going to have another look at it. That leaves most people in Australia somewhat confused, if not concerned. You either support a bill for the reasons it deserves to be supported or you are not informed enough about an issue to adopt a position which is a position you will continue to have next year.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats think it is much more honest to state the position and then to stick by that position. I seem to recall we had this argument when the pensioner shares issue was debated, which pursued us in this place for some time. I recall it being trotted out on a number of other issues as well. The opposition is not prepared to oppose it but is prepared to suggest that somehow or other it would be a priority for a different government. We are told in the second reading speech of the minister—it occupies one page of Hansard—that the elements of programs which are to be cut by this bill are initiatives that have served their purpose or are now more appropriately the responsibility of other bodies.

The previous speaker, Senator Tierney, was a keen participant, as I was, in an inquiry conducted by the Senate Education, Employment and Training References Committee into state-federal financial relations. As chair of that committee, Senator Tierney has chaired inquiries into various aspects of education on which state and federal financial relationships impinge strongly. Senator Tierney and I have heard witnesses from all around Australia who are concerned about the way education in Australia is heading. He and I have heard a great number of witnesses suggest that they are concerned about the way state education departments are taking opportunities to use federal money to meet the obligations that the state departments have and have abrogated their responsibilities and are not properly funding state education.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to measure.

—Senator Tierney says, by way of interjection, that it is something which is very difficult to measure. He and I have heard time after time witnesses saying that tied grants at least identify the end purpose of the money and can be evaluated as to whether the money was spent on that which it was intended to be spent on. We have three programs which are identifiable, which have had a priority attached to them and on which the electorate at large can see whether their money has been spent.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats are concerned that this government and the state governments are making arrangements, whether at ministerial councils or at COAG meetings, on how the federal-state financial arrangements will be arrived at and where the spending priorities will be. Those arrangements are then brought into this chamber for what is best described as ratification. Sometimes it is more accurately described as rubber stamping.

The last occasion I recall that happening was when Minister Cook suggested that one of these concoctions—it was not in the education area but in another area—should not be amended, modified, changed, challenged or even looked at carefully by this chamber because it was subject to `the weight of agreement of all the states of Australia and the federal government'. I think that was Senator Cook's phrase. The implication was: who the heck are we to put up our hand and say, `Excuse me'? That is turning the role of this place and the role of the federal parliament into one which it was not designed to be.

The people of Australia are not silly. They recognise the threat to their sovereignty and their democratic processes. They recognise the threat that this arrangement brings about. I am not suggesting for one moment that this bill has been through that process.

In removing three specific programs, the government is heading towards a trend which has not been supported by those people who have brought their evidence to committees at which I have shared the inquiry table with Senator Tierney. Those people are concerned about this trend and would like us to do something about its continuation.

Today I received a letter from the National Association for Rural Student Accommodation Inc. It is dated 22 November this year. It is current. This is a concern which is held by the group. I will read only the first part, which will enable the Senate to understand the direction of the concerns. It is a little too detailed to take any further. It is addressed to me. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: We ask that you take urgent representation on our behalf in support of the enclosed Submission to the Commonwealth Government, presented to Ross Free, Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, seeking his urgent consideration of funding to the Association from January 1996, to enable NARSA to undertake an ambitious three year program of information, training and communication support and professional development for the rural student hostel industry.

This group is writing about these concerns at a time when the government is making cuts to a program which is directly associated with this group's concerns. It may well be that the association is doing a post-stable door operation. It may also well be that this is reflective of the government saying that such an initiative is now more appropriately the responsibility of another body. I do not know. I have not had time to go into the details.

PARA.TAB: I hope the government is informed. I hope Minister Free pays attention to the concerns of this group. I hope the government is not cutting a program which is in the interests of the group that has written to me.

The other parts of the bill which deserve comment have been mentioned by Senator Tierney. It makes it very hard to adopt a position which totally opposes these provisions, because the government is expending more money in the areas of disabilities integration and the extension of early literacy. They are significant amounts and are worthy of support and even congratulation.

The problem is that all these proposals have been lumped in together. Our concerns about gifted and talented students, the gender issues and rural hostels have been cut while other areas have been expanded. My position on this is that the entire funding of education in Australia is seen as the problem area by the people who made submissions to and appeared as witnesses at a number of inquiries and committee hearings that I have attended. They have also communicated in person with me.

A collection of their concerns is being represented by the trend to fund education either under general purpose grants or in a manner which removes the capacity of this chamber and this parliament to amend, to oppose, to comment or to modify. Those processes are taking place in another forum—not a representative forum but a forum which is exclusive and in which negotiations can take place without being influenced by the parliamentary process. It is of great concern to us.

Because the coalition will not oppose this bill, we feel cheated of the capacity to exercise our democratic right to change the bill. Because the government has bundled these provisions into one bill, we also feel cheated of the opportunity to take a significant stand on them. We are frustrated by this. I take this opportunity to express that frustration. I do not promise that the Democrats will grant passage to this concoction. I will listen to the debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank both senators who made a contribution on this important piece of legislation. I commend the bill to the Senate.

Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995CUSTOMS TARIFF BILL 1995CUSTOMS TARIFF LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 22 November, 23 October and 27 November on motions by Senator Faulkner, Senator Bob Collins and Senator Schacht:
That the bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Customs Tariff Bill and associated bills—the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill. We are debating these bills cognately. I will address first of all the Customs Tariff Bill.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to redraft and consolidate the Customs Tariff Act 1987 and to incorporate the harmonised commodity description and coding system classification modifications. This system was developed in 1988 as a classification system for administrating imports and exports and for collecting foreign trade data. This system was established by the Customs Cooperation Council, which is an international body of which Australia is a member.

The harmonised system is now known as the harmonised description and coding system and is the international tariff system sponsored by the World Customs Organisation in Brussels. The new system will replace the former outdated one by providing a universal six-digit code removing old domestic subheadings and the archaic tailored Australian tariff. Once implemented the universal classification and coding system will be of assistance to international trade. This universal code is essential in the modern world of the global economy where a countless number of goods are being traded internationally at all times.

The new system will incorporate new products that have come on to the international trade market in recent years. Value added, technically advanced products and components emerge without a suitable separate tariff classification to cater for them, which leads to the introduction of these new classifications. Australia is adopting the classification changes as agreed and will be adding 200 national tariff splits to maintain its tariff program. The harmonised system is essential to the collection and quantification of foreign trade statistics. This is essential for Australia to monitor trends in world trade so that we can develop essential mercantile strategies.

New item 17 of the bill tightens the eligibility definition in respect of goods that are exported from Australia and may be altered overseas. This is where Australian industry sends materials overseas to be enhanced using relatively cheap foreign labour and then to enjoy a duty-free return to Australia. This item introduces a more surgical definition which will discourage labour going overseas for Australian products. The bill provides for the duty-free importation of goods which are replaced under a safety recall. This covers goods which are being sent to consumers to compensate them for a product they have already purchased which has a design fault or safety concern. It also allows for the duty-free return of goods which are part of a repair process to replace goods exported from Australia for repair or renovation.

The main body of the bill is a technical implementation of a more updated system to administer imports and exports in Australian customs and to collect statistics on foreign trade. This in effect constitutes a consolidation of the original act. The new provisions in this legislation are reasonable additions in the interests of Australian labour, industry and consumers. The coalition supports the implementation of a new tariff classification regime in order that Australia becomes a cooperative and efficient player in world trade. We must not jeopardise Australia's ability to meet its international agreements, especially in respect of trade, and must maintain our reputation as a facilitator of trade. It is a pity the Labor Party continues to tarnish its image on this front with its multiple failures in the realm of micro-economic reform.

The Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill contains five schedules of amendments to enact a range of changes to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The main purpose of the bill is to increase the excise on light fuel oil. This provision is in schedule 4. Schedule 4 amends the Customs Tariff Act 1987 and had effect from 1 July 1995. The schedule provides statutory enforcement to the custom tariff proposal already tabled in parliament which proposes an increase in the excise on light fuel oil as defined in the bill. The increase will bring the rate of excise on light fuel oil up to the same rate as diesel fuel. There have been operators who have shifted to using light fuel oil to take advantage of the reduced excise.

The bill contains other amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Schedule 1 amends the act and had effect from 17 March 1995. This amendment follows an Industry Commission report which inquired into the customs commercial tariff and by-laws system in 1990-91. This amendment will change the tariff treatment of textiles used in the manufacture, repair and maintenance of aircraft. Textiles used in the manufacture, repair and maintenance of aircraft are subject to a concessional rate of duty of two per cent. This amendment will remove the concession given to textiles and goods for use in the servicing of aircraft. The tariff rate of these textiles will be the conventional rate of duty—all above 10 per cent. The materials which include generic items such as seat fabrics will be subject to the normal tariff rates that apply to textiles.

Schedule 2 amends the Customs Tariff Act 1987 and had effect from 1 April 1995. This is intended to restore the intended level of assistance to blood packs and blood pack systems such that they do not face an immediate removal of the 10 per cent tariff. This amendment is a result of a classification challenge to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As the blood packs industry stands, having operated so far under tariff protection, it would be effectively decimated by the instantaneous and comprehensive removal of tariff assistance. The industry should be allowed to move in consonance with the overall tariff reduction phase-down.

Schedule 3 amends the Customs Tariff Act and had effect on 10 May 1995. On 13 December 1994 there was a joint ministerial statement announcing a package of measures that were `aimed at facilitating adjustment by the Australian tobacco industry towards international competitiveness.' These measures were in response to the Industry Commission report No. 39 of June 1994, Tobacco growing and manufacturing industries. In this package was the removal of customs duties from tobacco leaf, manufactured tobacco and tobacco products from 1 January 1995.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1995 instituted amendments to make imported unmanufactured tobacco and tobacco products free of customs duties. This was done in order that our local tobacco growing industry would contract with exposure to international competition. This was desirable in the face of the Industry Commission report. The IC report advised that tobacco products was a moribund industry and had existed in an artificial environment created by the tobacco industry stabilisation scheme and the local leaf contents scheme.

The removal of customs duties from leaf and tobacco products was a concession that the tobacco industry agreed to in return for a contribution from state and Commonwealth governments—financial assistance and an ad valorem tariff—and long-term contractual obligations from the cigarette manufacturers. This amendment will increase the duty on imported manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by 10 per cent. The increase in duty on tobacco products is also consonant with the coalition policy of dissuading people from smoking.

The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 will incorporate excise tariff proposals 1, 2 and 3 of 1995 into the Tariff Act and will enact changes to the excise treatment of condensate and topped crude petroleum. The bill has many provisions.

This bill removes the rate of excise applicable to beer produced from micro-breweries and U-breweries from indexation. Micro-breweries and U-brews are pre-prepared home brewing kits which allow people to brew their own beer. When this category of beer was made excisable in April 1994 the applicable rate of excise was not intended to be subject to indexation. This section removes the rate of excise of these products from indexation.

The bill raises the rate of excise duly on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by 10 per cent. This rise in excise on tobacco products is confluent with the coalition's health policy in regard to tobacco.

The bill amends the definition of physical characteristics of fuel oil to effectively exclude light fuel oil. Light fuel oil will become excisable at the same rate as diesel fuel oil. This addresses the issue of transport industries using light fuel oil as an alternative.

I now wish to direct my attention to the aviation amendments. I foreshadow that in the committee stage of this bill we will make a request for amendments to the excise on aviation gasoline in respect of the charge being made on airways services.

In the budget, the government increased the duty on aviation gasoline, avgas, by 1.847c per litre, and increased the duty on aviation turbine fuel, avtur, by 0.883c per litre. Avgas is the fuel used in piston engined propeller aircraft, the one most used by the general aviation industry. Avtur is used in jet aircraft and turbine powered propeller aircraft.

The duty rate on avgas is now 19.652c per litre. The duty rate on avtur is much lower, 2.451c per litre. The avtur duty is much lower because most of the duty on avgas, about 17c a litre, is assigned to Airservices Australia to pay for air traffic services used by avgas powered aircraft. Avtur operators, the jet aircraft, pay for the air traffic services they use through a system of charges—a user pays approach. Both avgas and avtur users pay the same, 2.451c per litre, for air safety regulation.

On 1 July, the Civil Aviation Authority, CAA, was divided into two organisations: the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, CASA, which is responsible for air safety regulation; and Airservices Australia, which is responsible for managing the air traffic control system and allied systems, such as fire fighting. CASA's 1995-96 budget is $86.3 million, a figure substantially higher than the CAA's aviation safety regulation budget for 1994-95 of $61.5 million.

In 1994-95, the safety regulation duties on the two fuels generated $24.3 million. The 0.883c per litre increase in the duties is forecast to raise an additional $22.5 million, increasing CASA's revenue from the fuel duties to $46.8 million. Approximately $43.5 million, or 93 per cent, of the total would be generated by the duty on the aviation turbine fuel used by jet aircraft.

The coalition recognises the need for an increase in CASA's funding to pay for safety. We will not be opposing the increase in the duty on avtur, nor will we be opposing the 0.883c per litre increase in the air safety component of the avgas duty. As I pointed out, however, most of the revenue generated by avgas is allocated to funding airways services used by avgas operators.

Earlier this year, the CAA recommended a 3.4c per litre increase in the airways services component of the duty. That was rejected by the government following a lot of industry concern. The government announced instead that it would increase the component by 0.964c per litre, raising an additional $1.1 million a year. I have indicated that I will be moving a request to reverse this increase in the airways services component of the duty.

TALK.START.PARA: —A request?
—I found out in the last half an hour that, under the constitution, it must be a request, the reason being—
—No, I understand.

—The coalition believes that it is inequitable to recover with a fuel duty the cost of providing airways services to general aviation. Most general aviation operators and private pilots use the airways system only rarely but still have to pay thousands of dollars a year in duty. For example, agricultural operators are now paying the government an average of $7,800 per plane per year for services they do not use. If they have converted their aircraft to avtur they do not pay at all.

PARA.TAB: The government has conceded that the current funding system is unfair. Airservices Australia is currently conducting a review of the services it provides to general aviation. This will include a review of the way the cost of services is allocated. We in the coalition do not believe that there is any justification for increasing the airways component of the avgas duty while the review is being conducted. There is no justification, we believe, at this stage for making the present unfair system even more unfair.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. The importance that the Australian Democrats attach to these bills may be gauged by my attire tonight. I have some difficulty in understanding why the minister at the table, Senator Schacht, cannot match it because these bills are extremely important. I will now deal with some of the more significant aspects of them.

PARA.TAB: Schedule 1 of the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 alters the treatment of textiles used in the manufacture, repair and maintenance of aircraft. Currently, textiles used in the manufacture, repair and maintenance of aircraft are subject to a concessional rate of duty of only two per cent. The amendment in schedule 1 of the bill will remove the concession available for textiles used in the manufacture, repair or maintenance of aircraft. Such materials, which include generic items such as seat fabric, will be subject to the normal tariff regime applying to textiles.

Schedule 3 of that bill increases the rate of duty on imports of manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by approximately 10 per cent. The Democrats support the use of higher taxes to discourage the consumption of products that are known to have contributed to the deaths of tens of thousands of Australians.

Schedule 4 contains a number of amendments. The first changes the definition of fuel oil so that light fuel oils attract the same rate of duty as diesel fuel oil. The second amendment will increase the price of aviation gas by 0.883c per litre on aviation kerosene and by 1.847c per litre on aviation gasoline.

I understand that the coalition is unhappy about this increase in the price of avgas. It argues that it is inequitable to use fuel duties to recover the cost of providing airways services to general aviation, particularly when some rural operators do not even enter controlled air space. The Democrats certainly believe that there is a point in this argument and have great concern for the costs that are loaded onto people in country areas who are struggling to make ends meet.

The government has acknowledged the potential problems with such a pricing structure and has stated that new charging arrangements are being considered by Airservices Australia. The government appears to be saying, `Allow us to increase the price of fuel and we'll deal with the distributive effects later.' On balance, however, the Democrats believe that the coalition's view is the better one and we will be supporting their amendment.

It is my understanding that the government wishes to ensure that this amendment is not retrospective and that the funds collected so far remain in the government's hands. I certainly would support any amendment which would ensure that the amendment of the coalition does not have retrospective effect.

The Senate is also debating Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. Schedule 2 of that bill increases the rate of excise on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by 10 per cent. Consistent with our position on the previous bill, the Democrats will not be opposing this aspect of the bill—indeed, we welcome it.

Schedule 3 mirrors the provision in the previous bill. Item 1 of schedule 3 of the bill changes the definition of fuel oil in the Excise Tariff Act 1921. It changes the definition of fuel oil so that light fuel oils attract the same rate of excise as diesel fuel oil. In addition, schedule 4 proposes to implement changes in the excise treatment of condensate and topped crude petroleum oil-topped crude oil.

We have heard from a number of sectors in industry, particularly rail transport and some tourism operators, who say they will be hard hit by this redefinition of light fuel oil. But the facts of the matter are that a lot of uses of light fuel oil were only suddenly found to be appropriate when it was found that money could be saved compared with ordinary diesel fuel oil. In many areas it was not the appropriate fuel to be used.

If there are good and sound arguments for reducing the cost of diesel fuel for some operations, then that should become the subject of exemptions. I can see the minister going pale at that. I know this has been a very live issue for quite some years now. We are only just now moving towards tightening up the regime so that the revenue losses through the diesel fuel excise rebate are not getting out of hand. But that, I believe, is the best way of dealing with it if there is an argument that certain uses in industry should be supported by a reduction in energy costs. With that one exception that I foreshadowed concerning the amendment by the opposition, the Democrats will be supporting these bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rising to speak on the Customs Tariff Bill 1995, because it is being debated cognately with the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. I will not waste much time on this. I know the coalition have indicated support for the bill, so there is not a great deal of point, but I will just put a few things on the record.

PARA.TAB: I think this is a classic example of what should not be occurring in the Senate. Here we have a 946-page bill. It was passed in the House of Representatives a little over a month ago and was dropped into the Senate. The government considers it so little problem that it made it cognate with two other bills. All three bills have spent almost no time in the other place, the other two bills being introduced in the Senate today. So much for scrutiny!

We are told that the Customs Tariff Bill does not require scrutiny because it is basically a technical reclassification. This is not so. If it were, the speed with which this is moving through the parliament might be acceptable. It is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think it is?

—Minister, if you listen, you might just find out what the bill is about. The changes in this bill are not just technical reclassifications; they are substantive changes that will incur costs of hundreds of millions of dollars. These changes are simply buried in this tome. If they were presented on their own in a separate bill, we all know they would probably be debated substantially. That will not be, because no-one can cope with ploughing through 950 pages to figure out what is going on and then consult with the community and so on. They would rather preserve the myth that this is just a technical bill.

PARA.TAB: I note that on page 129 of this bill there is an introduction of a definition—a definition that never existed in the prior acts. It is not obvious. This new definition is not mentioned anywhere. The definition reclassifies diesel fuel oil. It will impose hundreds of millions of dollars of extra cost, mainly on our nation's railroads. Of course, the railroads are owned by the state, mainly the state governments. But do not simply expect this cost to be transferred from state grants back to the Commonwealth as a fuel tax. We all know the cost will be transferred to the users of the railroads, mainly primary industry. It will increase the cost of fuel by about 26c per litre.

I note that in the explanatory memorandum there is no mention of this change—a change involving an imposition of hundreds of millions of dollars on wheat farmers and other primary producers. It was not worth a mention. In fact, there is no mention of the chapter it occurs in. Page 9 of the explanatory memorandum goes from chapter 26 to chapter 28. Changes to the definition of dental floss are considered important, but not a change that will impose about $260 million on farmers and significantly damage the competitive position of rail.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the point of this discussion about dental floss compared with farmers?

—The minister asks what the point is of this discussion. We are pointing out that buried in this tome are significant changes which the government has put in such a way as to not get a debate. That is why, Minister, we are here in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: If this change was left out of the explanatory memorandum, what other significant changes are buried in this bill? Who has examined it in detail against the previous legislation, the bill as at 1989 with all its subsequent amendments? Maybe there are changes here to building tiles. Has anyone checked? Maybe there are changes to luxury cars. Who knows? The government knows, but it is obvious from the fuel oil issue that it is not willing to tell.

I think it is a disgrace that the Senate should pass this bill unexamined. I firmly believe that it has not been adequately examined. We have no idea of what the impact of this bill is likely to be. One thing is clear: it goes far beyond simple harmonisation of standards. I could go on about the importance of rail or the impact of fuel oil changes to rural communities; it has been said before. If you want to know more, consult Hansard. I will say a few things about the supposed environmental benefits of this measure the government is trying to sneak through.

Firstly, I would like to say that this will do very little to improve the environment. What is being done is to reclassify some fuel oil as industrial diesel. This means that petroleum companies may now sell the same fuel as industrial diesel to all buyers, where before they were selling a higher grade of fuel, and only those who bought fuel oil could get this grade.

Secondly, the evidence of engineers in New South Wales and Western Australian rail services are that railroad engines can be, and have been, designed so that they can use fuel oil more efficiently than industrial diesel oil. They have done particulate testing and emission testing and it runs cleaner. There are engineering efficiencies gained in the way the fuel fires. So for rail applications, currently fuel oil is the cleaner fuel.

I will not go on any further, but I will say that this issue and all the other issues in this bill are not being adequately examined or debated. The government should be ashamed of itself for this. It is a shameful thing to undermine the scrutiny of legislation. The coalition should be ashamed of itself for allowing this pile of unscrutinised legislation to slip through the Senate with no justification other than the invocation of the magic words `World Trade Organisation obligation'.

Given your disdain of international treaties, I am always irritated when we kowtow to that one. What you really have is disdain for international environmental and human rights standards. Trade treaties that give power to global corporations are quite different. I am disgusted at this bill and at the fact that it will pass here virtually without question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to thank senators for their contributions. But after listening to Senator Margetts's contribution, I am not quite sure whether I can say that. I will deal first with her comments about the Customs Tariff Bill 1995. You came in here and in your remarks said that, because this is a thick bill, some swiftie was being pulled by the government. That is just not right.

PARA.TAB: This bill does not change any level of tariff amount paid anywhere. This document has been available to the industry, to that large class of people called consultants, advisers, lobbyists, et cetera, who live on this material. I have been told by my advisers that they have received no complaint that any tariff has been increased or changed surreptitiously.

TALK.START.PARA: —Page 129, I have been advised, changes the definition which changes the excise.
—Changes the excise?
—Yes, you change the definition of what you pay excise on, you change the excise.
—As I say, whoever said that to you has not—
—Has no-one told you?

—No-one has told us; no-one has put it to us. I look at page 129, and I do not know which level here in the definitions you have got. The only one on that whole page that I can see that talks about a `tariff' is a description at the bottom of the page—and I hope I have this right—where it says `coal gas, water gas, producer gas and similar gases, other than petroleum gases and other gaseous hydrocarbons, five per cent or DCS free'. All the rest are listed as free.
—There is an additional note at the top of the page.
—At the top of the page?
—Yes.
—The definition is in the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill 1995.
—I am talking about the additional note at the top of the page.
—Of page 129?
—Yes.

—I am advised that the additional note at the top to which you have referred, the definition, does not come into effect until July of next year and does not change the tariff level. That is what I am advised.
—About 20c a litre, I am advised.

—That is the light fuel oil, which is in another bill. I am very cautious in saying this because I accept the fact that three cognate debates with a tariff bill and two customs excise bills can lead to some confusion. However, Senator Margetts, I believe that you have this confused with the light fuel oil which is in the other bill.
—No. If you change the definition, you therefore change the actual rate for the same thing. It just calls it something else. The fact that it's next year doesn't make much difference.

—I do not think that is right. We have not had that raised with us by the industry. I have to say that I would have thought the industry would have come and seen us first before anybody else—and I am not in any way denigrating the position of the Greens. But I would have thought, in this issue of definitions, they would have come and seen Customs. And I am advised by Customs that nobody has raised this query of the definition.
—It is on record.

—I would have presumed that, if someone had a concern about a definition accidentally leading to an increase in tariff or excise, it would have been raised. I have to say, though I have only had 3 years experience as customs minister, the ability of this industry to jump up and down within 10 seconds and raise issues when it sees a tariff or an excise level being changed is pretty remarkable. There is a level of people out there who make their living out of determining the definitions in these sorts of documents. We went through a harmonisation process as part of our international obligations; it did not change any level of tariff. We have changed the definitions, that is true. But the level of tariff has not been changed. So it is not changing the revenue base. I think you have confused light fuel oil in another bill with what is in here.

PARA.TAB: I accept the fact that this is detailed legislation. Anything listing a tariff is detailed. No person, humanly, will remember all of that, even if they had sat down and read the lot. I accept all of that. But people do go through it in those areas they are concerned about. They have not raised it with us. I have just checked with the advisers and asked whether we had had any complaints anywhere on this bill—this 946-page bill. There has been not one complaint or query.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've just had one.

—You have raised one, but it has not been raised with us. Please tell whoever your person is who has spoken to you about it that we are more than happy to discuss it with them. So please send them to us.
—You've had one from me.

—Yes, but what I am referring to is the industry itself. I am in no way denigrating your status as a senator, but we have had no complaint from industry. It is from industry we usually get them. I am not saying that in areas dealing with light fuel oil and avgas people have not raised issues with us. But they have not raised them on the bill which is listed No. 7 on the list, Customs Tariff Bill 1995.
—You will just get complaints after the bill is passed.
—No. This has been out since the budget; this was tabled in September.
—I would do a bit of clarification here, Senator, if that is all right with you.
—Certainly.

—What Senator Margetts refers to is certainly in the Customs Tariff Bill. But, in fact, in both the other two bills we are debating—the excise one and the customs one—there is the same definition. That is what you are referring to—not the Customs Tariff Bill 1995, which does not really relate. The definitions that are in both the excise bill and the customs tariff bill are identical.

—I have just been advised that this amendment was drafted in consultation with industry and the oil companies to make sure that we had it correctly. It has been available since September; it is now late November. So, in that period of nearly three months, knowing this industry, if people had had a complaint, they would have been battering on the door pretty quickly.

PARA.TAB: I note from the comments, other than those of Senator Margetts, that the only query or amendment that has come forward in all of these three bills taken together is about the avgas level. I have just spoken privately—although I have not had a chance to speak to Senator Margetts—about the amendment moved by the opposition. I have said to both Senator Spindler and Senator Parer that we would be willing to look at a further amendment, if we can keep the money that we have already collected. It will mean that we are not paying that money back. Administratively, it would be difficult to hunt it all down to get it back. So we will keep that money, but in the amendment the existing rate would maintain. I think this is probably a reasonable compromise.

I accept the fact that over all this is about $1 million worth of revenue. It will not send the budget spinning madly into deficit, or whatever, compared with some of the other things that the Senate has done. So I am happy to put that as an amendment. It is now with the Assistant Clerk and being run off and circulated. But the intent will be: what we have already collected, which will have been from 1 July, at that rate as proposed, we will keep as revenue so we do not have to refund it because, as I have said, the administration of refunding is difficult. But as from tomorrow, the old rate would maintain. I think that is a reasonable compromise.

I note in the speeches from the other parties that, in particular, the senators accepted the changes to light fuel oil. I thank the parties for accepting that measure. I have to say that, if it had not been accepted, and the differential between light fuel oil at 6c a litre compared with diesel fuel at 32c a litre had maintained, within two or three years we would have had a massive leakage of revenue probably approaching $1 billion.

Technically, once people go out there explaining how you put certain filters on such things as interstate diesel trucks—that you could use diesel at 6c a litre—everyone will swap over. As of four or five months ago, one of the major oil companies was preparing a major marketing campaign to convince people to swap to light fuel oil, which they would produce, and to explain to people with diesel engines how you put the filters on so you could use it. We would have ended up with, as I say, an estimated $1 billion of lost revenue, which would have meant a significant change in taxation somewhere else to make up for the lost revenue.

I appreciate the fact that it appears that the other parties will support the government on this measure. I accept the fact that there will be some momentary agitation and irritation in a couple of areas. People have, over the last year or so, moved to using light fuel oil such as some tourist boats in North Queensland, but that has only been in the last year or so. They will have to pay more than what they were expecting. I am told that some of their marketing and costs of tickets on their boats have been set to cover the cost of running the whole service at 6c a litre.

I also accept the fact that railways in Australia were overwhelmingly the ones who moved into using light fuel oil. Their complaint is that they had not been eligible for the diesel fuel rebate even though they run on their own rail tracks and so on and that this itself was probably costing $100 million already in lost revenue. The railways will complain, I should imagine. They have not complained as much—I am not trying to encourage them either—as some of the operators. I will not go through all the other measures. They were all outlined in the second reading speech. I thank the Senate for its support. Do we have the amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a rough draft here.
—Can we show Senator Margetts and Senator Spindler? I want them to have a look at it. This is the government amendment to split the revenue. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) is dying to give me some further information. I feel that the kind of information given so far has been inadequate. It has been admitted that there will be a change in definition effective from next year. There is a revenue implication. There is an implication in terms of the price of fuels that are now going to be defined as something else. Whilst it may be true that excise has not changed on those fuels, the fact that a fuel that used to be defined as one thing is now defined as something else means that, in effect, the people using those fuels will have a different rate. I am asking the minister to clarify that so that everybody can understand what the implications are.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The definition in the Customs Tariff Bill is there because, as Senator Parer pointed out, we have put the new definition in the other bills.
—They have to coincide.

—Yes. It is in this bill for consistency sake. Elsewhere we are amending the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 to put the new definition in and have it consistent. But the change in tariff excise in this bill is only because we are amending another bill, if it is carried by the Senate, which it looks as though it will be.

—That is not the question I am asking. I am asking the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) to tell me the implications of the cost to people who have had their definition changed on them and the revenue implications of this change.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the definition for light fuel oil. I have just outlined—I will say it again—the technical definition of light fuel to make sure that it applies properly. We want to stop an emerging loophole. The excise rate will go from 6c per litre to 32c per litre, which is the diesel—
—That is exactly what I was saying.

—Yes. From 6c to 32c per litre, which is a 26c per litre increase. It has been brought to the same level as the diesel fuel excise. We have made it very clear that that is what we are doing. To make sure that we closed the loophole, we had to put this definition in. That is the definition. We have made no attempt to hide the fact that we are closing a loophole by increasing the excise level for light fuel as it is being used by trains, and trucks that could put filters on; most of them could, if they chose to do that. They will have to pay the same as they would for diesel, which they normally use. There will then be no loophole and we will not lose in two or three years possibly up to $1 billion of revenue.

—Perhaps the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) can tell me which kinds of people will be affected and what the revenue implications will be from this change for 6c to 32c per litre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —An example is the trains of Australia. The state rail systems will have to pay, as I understand it, 32c per litre compared with 6c per litre. Going back a few years, they applied for the diesel—

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The minister, in response to Senator Margetts, is addressing the wrong bill. This bill is the Customs Tariff Bill. The questions that Senator Margetts should be asking are about the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995.
—I accept Senator Parer's correction. I am now debating the other bill. Initially, I explained why the description went in the Customs Tariff Bill from the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition initially had a request for an amendment to the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill. The reason for that was explained in the second reading debate and was also referred to by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht). The reason for this request was that it was felt it was unfair, inequitable and unjust to require the general aviation industry, which uses avgas, to pay Airservices Australia type charges when, in the main, they did not use them. We have before us two bills which require two amendments. The one I am addressing now is the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill and the one that will come later with a very similar amendment is the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill.

PARA.TAB: The reason for the two amendments is that where there is an increase in excise on locally produced avgas, there has been an amendment to the charge. In some places, notably the Northern Territory, avgas is imported from places like Singapore and there has to be an equivalent increase in the customs tariff. They equal one another.

I initially circulated an amendment in my name, which has now been amended, to the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill, which reflects the proposal put to the opposition and the Democrats by the minister. The proposal put was that the government would agree to our amendment—in other words, to reduce the tariff on avgas so that the general aviation industry using aviation gasoline would not be required to make that contribution to Airservices Australia type charges.

In view of that arrangement between the minister and the opposition, the government will now agree to that amendment, provided it applies from tomorrow. So the amendment circulated in my name still contains the same figures in respect of the avgas tariff but is applicable from 28 November, which means there will be a reduction as from tomorrow. The minister has put this to us on the basis that this tariff has been collected since 1 July. The logistics of paying back some of those charges are such that it would be cleaner if the amendments proposed by the opposition and supported by the Democrats applied from tomorrow. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments.

AMENDMENT OF THE CUSTOM TARIFF ACT 1987 HAVING EFFECT FROM 28 NOVEMBER 1995

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendment of the Customs Tariff Act 1987 having effect from 28 November 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —Having asked my questions and sat down, it was pointed out to me that my questions were relevant to all three bills. You cannot say these definitions are in all three bills and then say I am asking the wrong questions on the wrong bills because the change has been introduced in all three bills as a requirement. I will try to carry on from where I was rudely interrupted. What, Minister, are the revenue implications of increasing this oil price from 6c to 32c a litre for such people as train users?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment we estimate that the revenue saved or the increased revenue, whichever way you want to put it, will be around $100 million overwhelmingly, as I am advised, from train use. But there are increasing examples that the road transport industry and similar users will be switching over. We understand that since we announced this as a budget measure those attempts and further examples of promoting the substitution of light fuel oil for diesel oil have basically stopped and have not been proceeded with. The industry has accepted that this measure would mean it would not be able to proceed with it.

PARA.TAB: Overall, the revenue implication is that we will actually collect an extra $100 million. As I understand it, that revenue will come mainly from the rail industry. But, even more importantly, we are stopping the trend towards wholesale substitution of light fuel oil for diesel, and we estimate the excise level collected on diesel was over $1 billion. Much of this would have been put greatly at risk with the way the industry was starting to promote the substitution of light fuel oil by putting certain types of filters on diesel engines.

TALK.START.PARA: —In deference to the notes, `We would've been lobbied if people had realised there were any major changes,' I therefore ask: the fact that this was not highlighted in the explanatory memorandum, do you think this might have had something to do with whether or not you were lobbied on this issue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —We were spoken to and people did query us about the light fuel oil change. They did not query us about the general definitions of the new tariff descriptions in here.
—Because that is where it was implemented.

—No, the definition of light fuel oil and what we were doing were put in this and the other bill. We put the consistency in this bill but only after we amended these two bills. We were spoken to. We were lobbied. Straight after the budget I was asked questions in Senate estimates by some senators from Queensland about the use in the tourist industry by the tourist blokes who go out to the Great Barrier Reef. They had switched over to light fuel oil in the last year or so. They wrote in and lobbied about the impact on them. So, yes, in that case we did get lobbied and we have not denied that. This was certainly raised with us in the estimates hearings back in May and June but we explained that the overall revenue implications were quite horrendous to the government if it were not closed.

These amendments amend the original request, incorporate the reduction in the excise on avgas and are a mirror image of what we have put in in respect of the Customs Tariff Bill. They simply mean that the reduction that the general aviation industry will pay for avgas of 0.883c a litre will apply from 28 November—that is, tomorrow—rather than being retrospective to 1 July.
