DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995EMPLOYMENT SERVICES AMENDMENT BILL 1995SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CARER PENSION AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 22 November, 25 October and 27 November on motions by Senator Faulkner, Senator McMullan and Senator Schacht:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill 1995 and the Employment Services Amendment Bill 1995. These bills are being dealt with cognately.

PARA.TAB: The first two bills contain the main budget measures, but there a number of non-budget measures to be dealt with also. The bills are long and complex and range over many issues. In a cognate debate it is quite frankly not possible to cover all the issues. This raises concern about the way in which these bills have been handled and the complexity that becomes apparent day by day in relation to social security law.

The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 contains some 229 pages. The second bill contains some 167 pages. Including the explanatory memorandum, the two social security bills alone contain over 741 pages and over 40 amendments.

The law contained in these bills is complex. It adds to legislation that is already exceedingly complex and the government does not help itself by providing inadequate time for consideration of bills of this sort. Almost weekly one sees comments from independent observers, such as the ombudsman and the Auditor-General, about the complexity of social security legislation. The Welfare Rights Movement has also put on record over a long period its concern about the complexity of the social security system. Therefore, if we as legislators have difficulty in getting on top of this legislation what hope has the man on the street of keeping up with and understanding changes to social security legislation.

It is not consistent with efficient and effective government to introduce bills with more than 40 amendments so late in the parliamentary session. Time should be allowed, and time is certainly required, to constructively study and comment on changes and to consult with interested parties. Both the function of the parliament and the opposition's responsibility to act as a check on the government is undermined by this government's inability to manage its legislative program.

The first bill I wish to discuss tonight is the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill 1995. This bill amends the Social Security Act 1991, the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990, the Child Care Act 1972, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Farm Household Support Act 1992. It contains a large number of significant measures.

Schedule 1 amends the Social Security Act 1991 to provide a fairer and more lenient legislative and administrative regime for persons who leave Australia without a departure certificate. Schedule 2 makes amendments to the Child Care Act 1972 to enable the collection of tax file numbers from recipients of child-care assistance and to the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 to repeal the sunset clause, replace annual reporting to parliament with a requirement to report every three years and authorise the provision of the date of a person's most recent ATO assessment to the data-matching agency.

Schedule 3 contains six amendments to the waiver provisions of the Social Security Act 1991—the principal act, of course—to provide more consistency and flexibility. Schedule 4 contains amendments to increase rent assistance thresholds by a further $5 per fortnight to coincide with the March 1996 CPI increases to these thresholds. In addition, the maximum rates of rent assistance for families will increase by $5 per fortnight with effect immediately following the March 1996 increase to the rates.

Schedule 5 amends the Social Security Act to enable the rent assistant savings provisions to be phased out more quickly and to ensure that the operation of those savings provisions is not affected by proposed amendments to the veterans' affairs rent assistance saving provisions. The measure described in schedule 6 replaces rent assistance for people residing in nursing homes and hostels with a new residential care allowance. The rate, threshold, indexation and all other arrangements for the new allowance will be the same as for the rent assistance currently being paid to these people.

Schedule 7 amends the Social Security Act 1991 to provide that persons who leave their homes to receive or give community based care are immediately entitled to rent assistance. The schedule 8 amendment extends the two-year exemption period for former home owners to include persons who receive or give community based care or are in residential care.

Schedule 9 contains measures which will enable the carer pension to be paid for 14 weeks after caring ceases due to the permanent institutionalisation of the person receiving care. Schedule 10 extends qualification for carer pensions to include situations where a person cares for a non-pensioner. It is proposed to pay a carer pension to a person in situations where the care receiver is not in receipt of a social security pension or benefit or a service pension. In order to ensure that the carer pension correctly targets those in need of financial assistance, it is proposed to apply an assets and income test modelled on the family payment assets and income test—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have watched you chair the Senate over very many years. At the risk of needing indulgence, I would have thought—I do not need to quote the standing order for you—that since Senator Knowles has been here 10 years she could have either learned to read a speech without looking as though she is reading a speech or learned to write a speech so that she does not need to read somebody else's speech. I am quite certain she will say she is observing copious notes. You and I both know that in fact she is reading every single word that has been written by her research officer. If the standing order is not to be in some vague way abided by, I suggest that you report to the President and suggest that the standing order be rescinded.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: Senator Knowles in effect is fulfilling the role of a shadow minister here—and I suspect also the role of someone who is absent for good reason. Therefore I say to Senator Crichton-Browne that in delivering a speech on behalf of the whole opposition she is entitled to the precision of a written speech because every word she says will be, I suppose you could say, `taken down and used in evidence against her'. To my mind, on this occasion, she is giving the equivalent of a second reading speech by a minister. This is the official response of the opposition. It will be for later speakers to stray, thrust and parry in the debate. Senator Knowles is adequately putting down the position of the opposition. I think that is quite in order on this occasion. It is a tradition of this chamber.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the same point of order: my view is that whoever responds ought be able to respond in an intelligent way of their own volition without having to be riveted to every single word that has been written by somebody else. Otherwise, I suggest, with respect, that we incorporate both speeches. We ought to incorporate Senator Ray's speech, if he happens to be the minister on the second reading, and we ought to change the standing orders and have the shadow minister incorporate their speech as well.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—It is generally accepted that opposition senators who occupy a shadow position are able to read their speech, for the reasons set out by Senator Ray. I would suggest, Senator Crichton-Browne, that if you feel strongly about the matter you could write to the President yourself.

TALK.START.PARA: —The care receiver must also be a legal resident of Australia and be 16 years of age or older. Schedule 11 removes the requirement that, in order to receive carer pensions, the carer must live in the same home as, or in the adjacent home to, the person being cared for.

PARA.TAB: Schedule 12 contains amendments to allow certain recipients of some pensions and benefits to access advance payments of their social security payments to assist in meeting their or their family members' living or capital expenses. Those recipients will be able to capitalise up to six per cent of their payments over a 12-month period, with an advance payment range of between $250 and $500. The advance payment will be repaid by deductions from ongoing fortnightly social security payments over a period of 13 fortnights.

Schedule 13 increases the fortnightly rate of guardian allowance by $4 per fortnight from 1 September 1996, and schedule 14 contains two measures relating to the parenting allowance. Schedule 15 contains two measures: the first relates to entitlements to periodic compensation payments converted to a lump sum; the second relates to the treatment of compensation affected payments, where one member of the couple is a Social Security client and the other is a Veterans' Affairs client.

Schedule 16 makes sure that customers who transfer between different types of allowance during a waiting period are also able to transfer any of the waiting period already served so that they are not disadvantaged compared to customers who do not transfer between allowances. Schedule 17 contains three measures relating to sickness allowance and claimants. Schedule 18(a) amends the bereavement provision for the carer pension to provide that bereavement payments will be paid to the principal carer, when the person being cared for dies during respite care, and 18(b) allows the bereavement period for short-term bereavement payments to commence on the day after a child dies.

Schedule 19 relates to the nomination of bank accounts for payments of benefits or pensions. Schedule 20 amends the sole parent pension and the sole parent special needs pension provisions to clarify the situations where a person is obliged to pursue maintenance. Schedule 21 ensures that all social security payments, whether they are paid by instalments or in the form of a lump sum, are absolutely inalienable and are protected from garnishee action.

Schedule 22 contains amendments to exclude as income certain payments received by a person who is engaged in part-time training or vocational training activities under a labour market program. Schedule 23 contains amendments relating to cross-references in penalty provisions to the Crimes Act 1914.

The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), representing the Minister for Social Security in the Senate, did give an undertaking during the second reading debate on the Social Security (Parenting Allowance and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Act 1994 that amendments would be made to the act at the earliest possible opportunity to refer the reader to the ability to convert an imprisonment term to a monetary penalty via the operation of the penalty unit scheme. This schedule amends all provisions in the act that refer to imprisonment terms by inserting a note that refers the reader to the ability to convert an imprisonment term to a monetary penalty by way of the operation of the penalty units scheme and the Crimes Act 1914.

Schedule 24 contains a number of minor and technical amendments, with schedule 25 amending all provisions in the Farm Household Support Act 1992 that refer to imprisonment terms by inserting a note that refers the reader to the ability to convert an imprisonment term to a monetary penalty by way of the operation of the penalty units scheme and the Crimes Act 1914.

There are a number of issues which I would like to address in relation to this bill. These include carer's pension, rent assistance, waiver of debts and the guardian allowance. The major issue, however, relates to data matching. On behalf of the coalition I will be moving an amendment relating to the data matching amendments in this bill.

Data matching is an issue which the coalition, and Senator Patterson in particular, has kept under close scrutiny since it was first introduced. At that time there were wildly unrealistic estimates of millions of dollars in savings and huge increases in efficiency. Neither of these predictions have actually eventuated. Despite the government's attempts to claim otherwise, the data matching system has not lived up to expectations. It has not delivered the huge savings it promised and it continues to pose a real threat to the privacy of Australians in general. We must be vigilant to keep it under control.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill 1995 contains a number of amendments to the current data matching program. It proposes to extend the data matching program to cover the child-care assistance payment. While the coalition is not opposing this measure, we are very concerned about the insidious extension of data matching. In this case, data matching is being extended into yet another portfolio, Health, which jointly administers, with the Department of Social Security, the child-care assistance payment.

There is also the proposal to remove the sunset clause for data matching. The coalition will be proposing an amendment which will extend the sunset clause for data matching until January 1999, effectively for another three years. The government has proposed changing the reporting requirements for the Data-matching Agency. These amendments would mean that the agency would have to provide a comprehensive report to parliament only every three years rather than the current requirement of reporting annually. The coalition will be opposing this amendment. As I have already mentioned, the coalition is very concerned about protecting the privacy of individuals. To ensure this, the agency must remain accountable to the parliament.

Also, the bill will authorise the provision of the date of the person's most recent tax assessment to the Data-matching Agency. We will in fact be proposing an amendment to the effect that the operation of data matching will be extended for a further three years to January 1999, but we certainly want to ensure that the efficacy of the process is something that is still tested.

Amendments have been put forward in relation to departure certificates. Presently, the act provides that a person's qualification for a pension ends if they leave Australia without a departure certificate and stay overseas for more than six months. This amendment will provide that if a person leaves the country without a departure certificate, after six months their pension will be suspended rather than cancelled and will only be cancelled after 12 months. It also provides that in special circumstances the secretary has the discretion to restore a pension with full arrears up to two years from the date of departure.

This amendment has been made in response to the Commonwealth Ombudsman annual report, which commented that about 1,200 pensioners per year had their pensions cancelled this way. The report also mentioned the problems that arise when pensioners go overseas intending to stay for less than six months and are unable to return because of illness or medical treatment. They could face losing their pensions permanently and then lose their major means of paying for medical treatment.

In this year's budget the government announced that the guardian allowance would be increased by $4 a fortnight as of September next year. That is $2 a week for the people who are seen to be the most needy and the most vulnerable in our community. This has been identified particularly by ACOSS. What does this government do? It acknowledges that this is a problem, that there is a need that ought to be addressed, but it delays the introduction of the measure by 16 months, to the budget after next.

Why such a small increase? After all, ACOSS has identified that there has not been a real increase in the allowance since 1986 and that, in fact, since 1973 the real value of the allowance has dropped by 48 per cent. This increase has left the payment $10 per week short of the amount needed to meet the benchmark of 10 per cent of the married pension rate. The government has acknowledged this problem, but is responding in a most inadequate way to a group of people who are really in need.

There are also amendments relating to rent assistance. Rent assistance is to be increased by $5 per fortnight for families with children; however, the rent assistance threshold is to be increased by $5 per fortnight at the same time. The end result is that the government is pretending to be generous in handing out an increase when in fact some recipients have to pay an additional $5 in rent before being eligible for rent assistance. In addition, the rent assistance entitlements of certain recipients which had been preserved under the act, including some boarders and lodgers, certain residents of retirement villages and recipients of rent assistance, will not be frozen until they are in line with all other rent assistance recipients.

These changes will bring about a saving to the government of around $16.9 million over 3 1/4 years. That is a saving of $5 million a year for the needy. This highlights the hypocrisy of the government. Admittedly, the 190,000 families will receive up to $5 a fortnight. However, the government has estimated that 310,000 recipients will lose up to $3.75 as a result of the increase in the threshold, 8,700 recipients will lose entitlements to rent assistance as a result of the increase in the threshold and 556,100 recipients not be affected.

The second bill being debated as part of this package of bills is the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. This bill also gives effect to a number of measures announced in the government's 1995-96 budget. Again, these measures were announced in May and here we are some six months later and they are being rushed through in the final days of the sitting. The legislation amends the Social Security Act 1991, the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, the National Health Act 1953, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Child Care Rebate Act 1982 and the Disability Services Act 1986.

This bill contains another 230 pages of changes to the social security legislation. It contains 17 schedules, which propose a wide range of measures. Many of those measures are particularly significant. I wish to focus on the most important ones tonight in the interests of time. One of those is the question of extended deeming. The main issue in the social security and veterans' affairs bill is the introduction of a new extended deeming regime and the resulting repeal of the unrealised capital gains provision which treats as income any gain on shares and other investments.

The coalition has long pledged to repeal the unfair unrealised capital gains provision and the government has been criticised by all sections of the community for the unfair nature of the unrealised capital gains provision. It created uncertainty amongst the pensioner population and was a complex and inequitable system of assessing income. For many it became impossible to plan ahead as their pensions could reduce significantly four times each year. The government did not receive the revenue it expected from the treatment of capital gains as income for social security and the extended deeming introduces a new system of calculating income from financial investments. Initially, a standard deeming rate of five per cent will apply to the first $30,000 of financial investments for single people and to the first $50,000 for couples. Above these a standard deeming rate of seven per cent will apply.

The government has argued that the new deeming rules are attractive because they will create certainty and they are comparatively simple. The problem is that the government has made no provision in the bill to determine how often a person's financial assets are to be valued. At present people are required to notify the department each time the value of their assets change and their pensions will be adjusted accordingly. There is a penalty involved if a person fails to advise the department of a change which leads to a debt due. This matter was referred to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee, which considered the issue of appropriate timing and regularity of valuation, and reported to the Senate today.

While the coalition supports a simplified and more equitable valuation of assets, it believes that the timing of the valuation of financial investments should be incorporated in the bill. This system of timing of valuation must not only be administratively simple and workable, it should also place minimum demands on the clients of the Department of Social Security who will be affected by extended deeming. To that end, I foreshadow that I shall move an amendment to ensure that valuation of financial assets takes place at six-monthly intervals with the option of the client being able to seek a valuation at any time during the year.

The new system of extended deeming has been lauded by the government as being advantageous to pensioners and other social security recipients, but it needs to be pointed out that the government itself estimates that it will result in savings of $62.58 million in 1996-97 and $65.02 million in 1997-98. (Extension of time granted)

The new system of extended deeming has been lauded, as I said, by the government, but there are problems—in addition to those I have already mentioned—in that the government has also estimated that 270,000 pensioners and part pensioners will see a decrease in their pensions if they do not rearrange their assets. Pensioners or part pensioners who lose their pension will also lose their fringe benefit entitlements arising from concession cards. The government estimates that 120,000 people will see an increase in their pension, but this increase will on average be $4 per week. Regardless of how the government attempts to simplify the system, it needs to be clear that it remains Labor's income and assets test in operation.

The government has failed in this bill to assist investors of the Estate Mortgage trusts who have been adversely affected by the unrealised capital gains provisions. The trust collapsed in 1990, and investors lost a considerable amount of money at the time. The trust has now been relisted as the Meridian Investment Trust and, since that time, investments have increased considerably. However, the gains have not been sufficient to make up for the loss.

Investments in the original trust were exempt from the unrealised capital gains rules as they were classified as a saved investment. When the trust was relisted, they were no longer exempt, and the total gain since that time has been assessed under the income test. This is causing a reduction in investors' pensions.

The coalition indicated last week that it would be proposing amendments in the committee stage to treat Meridian Investments as saved investments until July 1996. We heard today that the government intends to give people an ex gratia payment, but it is not going to put those people into the position they would have been in if these were saved investments.

Additionally, considerable representations have been made to members and senators from the umbrella friendly society organisation, the Australian Friendly Societies Association. The organisation has asserted that provision should be made to treat tax prepaid investments, such as friendly society bonds, differently to products on which tax is not prepaid but where the investors pay tax at their own marginal tax rate. The association argues that returns from prepaid tax products will necessarily be lower than those available to non-prepaid tax investments, as the tax has been paid prior to distribution to the investor.

The Australian Friendly Societies Association has argued that they will be unfairly prejudiced under the new rules as they do not have the ability to deliver returns equal to or more than the deeming rates of five per cent or seven per cent. A majority of friendly society members and associations are located in Victoria.

The Australian Friendly Societies Association has made alternative suggestions to solve one of the problems to do with pension investments. Two suggestions have been made: firstly, introduce a differential deeming rate for pre-tax paid investments which would take account of the fact that the tax has been paid prior to distribution to the investor; and, secondly, amend division 8A of the Income Tax Assessment Act to enable friendly societies to provide income stream products, which pensioners may switch to without tax penalty.

The Senate committee on community affairs held an inquiry to assess the merits of the representations of the friendly societies and assess whether the deeming rules should be changed, whether the tax legislation should be amended or whether no changes should be made. In its report, the community affairs committee concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has considered these arguments (from the Friendly Societies) but considers that extended deeming has considerable benefits and that organisations claiming to be affected by the proposed changes need to develop more attractive products; and that consumers have a responsibility to seek the best possible return for their capital.

There are other measures in this bill which should be discussed at greater length—for example, changes to the earnings credit scheme and the mature age allowance, and the amalgamation of the jobsearch and newstart allowance schemes. However, the government is ramming these measures through at such a rate before the end of the session that time does not allow for debate at this stage.

PARA.TAB: The third bill being debated cognately tonight is the Employment Services Amendment Bill 1995. My colleague Senator Tierney will also be speaking on this bill, so I will only give an outline of it at this stage. The Employment Services Act 1994 established the case management system and established the Employment Services Regulatory Authority, as an independent statutory authority responsible for regulating the case management system. This bill would make machinery changes arising from changed case management arrangements for certain part-time and seasonal workers. It would also streamline certain administrative procedures relating to CES notification requirements and allow the ESRA to obtain goods and services by using a credit card.

The bill would allow for consequential amendments arising from proposed changes to the Social Security Act 1991 that would amalgamate the jobsearch allowance and the newstart allowance. It would also amend the Social Security Act 1991 to provide for the National Convenor of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal to delegate his or her powers under the Employment Services Act 1994.

At present, the CES is required to send out two notices to people under case management. The first letter notifies people that they have begun participating in the case management system. These people may have to wait for months before they actually meet their case manager. They receive another notice when they are referred to a case manager. Under this present system the government can inflate immediately the number of people in case management, by totalling the number of letters initially sent out even though large numbers of these people had not even met their case managers, and those who are actually consulting with case managers.

One of the biggest constraints this system faces is that there are many more people in case management than there are case managers to handle them. The coalition has long been concerned that the number of clients per case manager is sometimes ridiculously high. There have been reported instances of case managers servicing up to 200 clients each. Clients cannot possibly expect an adequate level of attention or advice when they are competing for their case manager's attention with so many other people. The recent Auditor-General's report No. 3 into CES case management revealed very serious weaknesses in the functioning of the CES which it said must be `very quickly' remedied `as they reduce its capacity to assist the long-term unemployed'.
This bill also makes provision for the ESRA to purchase goods and services on a credit card. The coalition will monitor closely the way in which this ESRA credit card is used.

The bill relates also to job compact eligibility for certain seasonal and part-time workers. The definition of persons eligible for the job compact is amended to include the requirement that, in addition to having been in receipt of the jobsearch allowance, newstart allowance or the youth training allowance for a period of 18 months, a person must have been registered with the CES for a period of 18 months. This is apparently to take account of persons who may have had their CES registration date reset to zero. When seasonal and part-time workers elect not to participate in case management, the period of 18 months registration required to be eligible under the proposed amendments would be taken to commence for seasonal workers from the time of that election and for part-time workers after they have completed at least 13 weeks of work.

A new subsection will be added to provide that a person's CES registration will be added to provide that a person's CES registration is reset to zero by deeming that the person has ceased to be registered on the day specified in the determination under section 39(14) and to have recommenced registration on the following day. A new subsection 39(16) will be added to make it clear that CES registration means being registered by the CES as unemployed.

The opposition will not be opposing this bill but notes that this government has failed to adequately address the massive unemployment problem still faced by this country. In concluding the coalition's comments, I thank the Senate for allowing me additional time to cover this number of bills in this cognate debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Knowles very much for her lengthy contribution. I know that it has been done at short notice. I found it most interesting. The issues I would like to concentrate on tonight are valuation and extended deeming. They were the two issues that were referred to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee for us to investigate. We had some hearings a week ago. It is important for people to remember that both these issues affect all social security recipients and not just those who are age pensioners. I think a number of the people who made submissions to our committee of inquiry obviously had forgotten that.

PARA.TAB: On the issue of valuation of assets, I understand that the department does have a preference for six months. That certainly was the impression we gained from the inquiry, but a lot of other organisations who would have a keen interest in this appeared not to have given this a great deal of thought. The department is undertaking additional consultations on this matter and has worked out a number of alternatives and options that are available. For that it is to be commended. It has looked carefully into this issue. Importantly, under the six-month valuation the recipient has the opportunity to go, if there is a major change in the value of their product, to Social Security and seek an earlier revaluation.

One issue that got a lot of attention was the extended deeming provision. It is important to state very clearly that deeming is not new in the area of social security benefit. It has certainly been around for some time with bank accounts. Initially, it was thought of and spoken about as being the end of Western civilisation as we knew it. However, it has turned out to be a very beneficial product, a very beneficial way of assessing income because it has enabled people to have certainty and to make an investment choice so that their investment can be put away and left in a vehicle that will give them a reasonable return and they do not have to worry about fluctuations—it is just taken care of by the deeming.

It also means that if they are earning over and above the deeming rate they are able to say that that is money for jam and it is beneficial. The deeming rate, of course, has not been set at a high level. I have seen some comments in the media that it has been set at a high level to encourage risky investment. That is not the case, it has not proved to be the case to date and it will not be the case in the future.

We are encouraging pensioners and, in particular, aged people to make investments to provide, as best they are able, for their retirement. The pension is seen to supplement their income or, if they are only on a small investment, they are able to supplement their pension. It is very important for pensioners to be aware that supplementing their incomes leaves them financially better off; it leaves them in a financially superior position because it gives them more disposable income to live on. We will not go the way of trying to reduce their income levels from outside sources and trying to live solely on the age pension. More and more people are having superannuation investments and having small amounts of money, which are getting larger, to invest to assist them in their old age.

It is important that we get the pensioners and the older people to carefully think about and assess the sort of product that will suit them best as they get older. It should not be construed from anything that has been said here tonight that age pensions will disappear, because they certainly will not.

Extending the deeming enables simplicity and transparency, the two key things that pensioner groups and older retirees keep asking for—they want something that is simple and transparent. That is what we have in this provision. There is a guaranteed deeming rate of five per cent up to $30,000 for single people, up to $50,000 for couples and for amounts above that the deeming rate is seven per cent.

It is important that if elderly people are making investment decisions they make them in a considered and wise manner. Sometimes one wonders how wisely people have made decisions—they might get a bit concerned and a bit scared. Deeming is not a new issue. The issue of income for elderly people is one that has been around for a while.

This community affairs committee also undertook an inquiry into the treatment of pensions and shares. A variation on deeming was one of the options that came out of that committee inquiry in August 1993. Following that, John Barber undertook a consultation process in Targeting for equity which was published in December 1994.

It is very important that people remember that this work has been going on for some time. The thing that kept coming out of the consultations from that strategic review of income and assets test was that there were over 6,000 submissions to that consultation and review. Without a doubt the things that kept coming through in all of those issues were simplicity and stability, minimal intrusion and minimal impact on investment choice.

That is what the extension of deeming allows. It is also what setting down a set period for valuation will allow. People will be able to plan ahead. People will be able to make assessments and know that, if that is their amount of income or that is the amount they have to invest, they are going to have this return on that and this is what the effect is going to be on their age pension. It is very important that people recognise that.

The friendly societies certainly appeared before us. For pensioners who have significant amounts of income and who are paying higher marginal tax rates, those investments are quite good. In fact I would say that they are very good. They are secure. They also have the tax taken out. For some people that would in fact give them a bit of a tax break. For the 70-odd per cent of pensioners who do not pay any income tax, these products are not the best products for them. It is vitally important that people look at what the best products for them are.

It is not as if deeming is something new. It was announced in the May budget. It is not going to be implemented until July next year. This will certainly allow a number of organisations time to alter or to amend the product they are able to offer as well to people. I think it is vitally important that we remember these particular points.

The telling thing that came out of the inquiry, to me, was the plea and the urging by the pensioner and aged persons organisations that we not halt or slow up the deliberation on this bill and that we not amend it in any way. The APSF say that they believe `the message of the extended deeming system is that pensioners should make investment decisions on the performance of that investment—not on their favourable treatment under Social Security rules'.

They also go on to talk about reminding `the Senate committee that every single pensioner or retiree organisation across the country that took part in the strategic review of the income and assets test review has enthusiastically welcomed the extended deeming changes because they are simpler, fairer, offer more predicability, increase incentives for self-provision and simplify the choice of investment options for older people'. Those are the sorts of comments that we kept getting—that we would not delay this legislation in any way; that we would get it enacted as quickly as possible, because they all could see that this was a bill that was actually going to enable them to have simplicity, surety and stability.

Even the Financial Planning Association urged the Senate committee not to succumb to special pleading for any extension of deeming. They said that `for any extended deeming to work fairly and equitably there must be no exceptions among financial institutions'. That is very important. Of course the Financial Planning Association actually represents those bodies and those people who are involved in advising people how to plan their money. Those people are probably talking themselves out of business, but it is important that the aged people of this country get a product that is simple and get something they understand. It is with much pleasure that I support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill 1995 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. As Senator Knowles said, this is an incredible amount of legislation to be trying to deal with at this time of the year, but we will do our best.

PARA.TAB: Looking firstly at the carer bill, overall the Australian Democrats support the thrust of this bill. We believe, however, that in a number of areas the reforms proposed could have, and certainly should have, gone further. For example, the departure certificate changes proposed in this bill are a great step forward. The operation of the current provisions has been criticised as being overly harsh by a number of groups and individuals.

The Ombudsman's attention was drawn to this issue by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which referred on 17 cases where the AAT was compelled to follow the legislation and decide in the department's favour but was concerned about the fairness of some of the decisions. I am sure you will agree that that is quite a significant step for the AAT to take.

In response to the concerns raised, the bill will require the department, if the department becomes aware of the fact that a pensioner has left Australia without a departure certificate, to send a notice to the person informing them of their obligations. The bill will also provide the Secretary to the Department of Social Security with greater discretion to exempt a person, where their circumstances warrant it, from losing their payment for failing to satisfy the departure certificate requirements: for example, if they should become ill while overseas. These decisions, however, will not be open to appeal.

I believe that it is appropriate that the exercise of this discretion should be subject to review. As a matter of fact, all decisions of this nature should be subject to review. I will be moving an amendment at the committee stage to ensure that decisions made under the new section, 1218A, can be reviewed by authorised review officers, by the SSAT and by the AAT.

This bill will also make changes to the operation of the data-matching program. I do not think anyone in this place needs to be reminded that the Democrats oppose the introduction of the data-matching program—we have opposed it all along—and the use of the extended tax file number. In fact, we remain horrified by these measures. I certainly remember speeches made by my colleague Senator Meg Lees in this debate placing on the record our opposition.

We oppose the data-matching program on two grounds: firstly, that the savings it was claimed would be achieved through the program were wildly exaggerated—I underline `wildly'—and, secondly, that the program presented major privacy concerns. In response to those privacy concerns, the Senate imposed a requirement that all data-matching agencies submit an annual report to parliament which includes reference to guidelines issued by the Privacy Commissioner.

This bill now seeks to replace that requirement for annual reporting to parliament with the requirement that such reports be provided only every three years. Why bother? If you are going to report every three years, then obviously there is no intention to take that requirement seriously. You will not be surprised when I say that the Democrats will be opposing this move, as we still believe that it is important for the parliament to maintain a reasonable level of scrutiny over the operation of this program.

The bill provides for the waiver of a debt where that debt is attributable `solely to an administrative error'. Firstly, the Welfare Rights Centre has argued that debts often result from a range of complex circumstances, and as such this term is too narrow and should be replaced with `the dominant cause of which can be attributed to administrative error'. I will pursue this at the committee stage.

Secondly, Welfare Rights has suggested that the new provisions may not be available where assurance of support payments has been made, since the person who incurs the debt is not the one who receives the payments. I understand that the government has provided Welfare Rights with an undertaking to address this issue. I welcome that undertaking.

That brings me to the changes announced in the budget and contained within this legislation that will increase the maximum amount of rent assistance available to families and will increase the lowest threshold above which rent assistance becomes payable. It is estimated that around 191,000 families will benefit from the $5 a fortnight increase in rent assistance with a cost to government of around $26 million per year. At the same time, however, ACOSS estimates that nearly 365,000 households will be worse off as a result of the $5 increase in the rent assistance threshold.

The government says that increasing the threshold by $5 per fortnight `will reduce outlays and improve the targeting of rent assistance by reducing levels of assistance to customers who pay low or moderate rents'. The effect of this so-called better targeting will be that rent assistance recipients will lose a total of around $30 million per year. An amount of $7 million will be taken from aged pensioners—just think of that, Mr Acting Deputy President—who, ACOSS expects, will be mostly elderly single women, my mother included. Disability support pensioners will lose $5.5 million. The unemployed will lose $10 million, the worst affected likely to be single young people. And $7 million will be taken from additional family payment recipients—that is, sole parent and low income families who are in the greatest need. The Democrats will be opposing the raising of the rent assistance threshold.

I should say that the two changes proposed in this bill to the operation of rent assistance seem to exemplify the pattern of changes in the Social Security portfolio: any winners from policy changes gain at the expense of other Social Security clients. Talk about bad news-good news stories—this must be the ultimate. In this case, to quote ACOSS:

SPEECH.PARA: Rent Assistance increases to families with children will be paid for by single people, couples without children, and by families with the lowest incomes—that is, by those people who make up a high proportion of the most marginalised groups in the community.
They will be paid for, and the government will also make a windfall of around $6 million per year. So much for their generosity.

PARA.TAB: The next issue from this bill that I want to discuss is the $2 a week increase in the guardian allowance, which will not take effect until September next year. I think all parties will have received a submission from ACOSS in which it points out, firstly, the gross inadequacy of this increase and, secondly, the inequity of the September 1996 starting date, particularly in light of the fact that the new maternity allowance, available to those with incomes up to $61,000 per year, will commence in February 1996.

ACOSS has pointed out that the real value of the guardian allowance has dropped by a massive 48 per cent since 1973 and that there has been no real increase in payments since 1986. In particular, in the early 1990s, the allowance was paid at a rate equal to 22 per cent of the married pension. Since that time, the allowance has plummeted in value to the point where it is currently just 5.5 per cent of the married pension.

ACOSS and the Social Policy Research Centre have stated a view that the appropriate benchmark for the allowance is 10 per cent of the married pension and, to achieve this, ACOSS was pursuing a $12 a week increase in the payment for this year's budget. Instead of $12 a week, of course, the government has granted just $2 a week. For all the reasons I have just given, it can be seen that this increase is quite inadequate and to delay the increase until the end of next year simply adds insult to injury.

Finally, as the name of this particular bill indicates, there is a package of measures for carers. The first of those measures will provide that a recipient of the carer pension will continue to receive their payment for 14 weeks after the person they have been caring for is permanently institutionalised. This will allow the person some time to adjust to their new circumstances. One of those new circumstances is that they will have to transfer to a new social security payment. In the majority of cases that will mean the loss of some income and, more importantly, the loss of their pensioner concession card. Having run a campaign for thousands of widows who are in this situation, I am well aware of the significant loss which this indicates.

I am sure all of us in this place are aware of how highly pensioners value their concession card. I believe that the government should be looking to provide the concession card to these people for six or even 12 months after coming off the carer pension. In fact, I believe they ought to continue it indefinitely until that person's circumstances have changed significantly enough for them to lose that concession card. But 14 weeks is simply not long enough for them to be able to adjust completely to their changed circumstances. While the concession card is not the total answer to this, it would certainly be greatly appreciated by these people.

Turning now to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, there are a couple of issues from this bill that I want to touch on. The first is the proposed changes to the operation of the earnings credit scheme, which is currently available to those unemployed people who are receiving a jobsearch or newstart allowance. The earnings credit scheme allows unemployed people to earn a very limited amount of outside income without affecting their social security payments. The scheme is a very valuable initiative: it allows people to accept work opportunities which they otherwise may have knocked back for fear of losing their social security payment.

However, if we make the restrictions on the scheme as tight as this bill seeks to do, people simply will not take advantage of it. Just recently a friend of mine, who has a PhD and who sought higher qualifications because he was encouraged to do so by government policy, was telling me that he has been unable to get full-time work. He took four weeks part-time work recommended to him by the CES but found at the end of the four weeks that he had lost a significant amount of money.

Surely, the earnings credit scheme is meant to encourage people to find work and to get into the work force so that they can get back self-esteem and in that way become full-time and permanent workers. If we are going to make this scheme so restrictive that people will not take advantage of it, then we are simply, as they say, cutting off our noses to spite our faces. The Democrats will be opposing that part of the bill which seeks to limit to $100 the amount of earnings credit which can be used in any one fortnight.

The final issue I want to comment on tonight relates to the changes proposed to the mature age allowance. The mature age allowance was introduced as an interim measure to assist older long-term unemployed people. It is now proposed to make the allowance a permanent part of the social security system. Of course, the main reason for there being an ever increasing need for the mature age allowance is as a result of the government and opposition decision to increase the pension age for women.

Many older women are now finding themselves in the very difficult position of not qualifying for the pension but having very little hope of finding work. I might underline that in a soon to be tabled report of the super committee, we received a lot of evidence on this very issue. All of the evidence underlined the fact that it was a significant disadvantage for women to have this imposition on them. Indeed, I predict that the soon to be tabled super committee report—a report entitled Super and broken work patterns—will prove the point that the Democrats and some others in this place have been making.

Given that the increased pension age for women is going ahead, however, the Democrats believe that the extension of the mature age allowance is the least that can be done. The Democrats, however, are strongly opposed to the idea that new grants of the allowance after 1 July next year will be made under the benefit income and assets tests.

Let me just explain about these nasties. We believe that these are nothing more than a cost cutting exercise. As senators will be aware, the benefit income and assets tests are much tighter than the pension tests. For example, while both assets tests allow single persons to hold assets up to $118,000, after this amount the pension phases out gradually but benefits cut out immediately. In other words, for benefits, the $118,000 is a sudden death limit. Single people with assets between $118,000 and $231,750 would qualify for some mature age allowance under the old test but will not qualify under the new test—and neither will they qualify for the unemployment payment.

The practical effect of this will be that people will be forced to run their assets down at the very time we should be encouraging them to maintain their assets for retirement. Minister, this is a crazy proposition—just crazy stuff. I cannot understand it. Why should the government even be considering such a proposition?

Finally, as the welfare rights people have pointed out, this change will also lead to greater complexity within the social security system as you will have two categories of mature age allowance recipients: those who applied before 1 July 1996 and who are subject to the pensions income and assets test; and those who applied after that date who are paid under the allowance income and assets test. I am aware that the coalition will be supporting these changes. So I simply state for the record the Democrats' opposition to the imposition of the benefit income and assets test to the mature age allowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak with reference to the Employment Services Amendment Bill 1995, which was spoken to earlier by my colleague Senator Knowles. This bill changes case management arrangements for some part-time and seasonal workers. It also streamlines the administrative procedures for CES case management and allows ESRA to obtain goods and services on a credit card. It amalgamates the jobsearch and newstart allowance as well.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will not be opposing this bill but there are several pertinent comments that I wish to make with regard to it. Firstly, I would like to look at case management. The coalition has had concerns with the case management system; most noticeably the high number of clients per case manager which must preclude adequate attention being given to individual clients. The recent Auditor-General's report No. 3 into CES case management revealed very serious weaknesses in the functioning of the CES which, it said, `must be very quickly remedied as they reduce its capacity to assist the long-term unemployed'.

It was evident from this report that many unemployed people had very tenuous links with their case manager or are not receiving effective assistance at all. Indeed, I met a lady in Tasmania on Saturday who after two years is still waiting to meet her case manager.

The survey results were critical in their assessment of the CES case management system. It was found that 30 per cent of clients did not recognise that they had a return to work plan—a key element of case management. Surely, if this government is failing to get across information about a key element of the Working Nation program to a large proportion of the participants, there is something wrong with the emphasis of the scheme. Twenty-nine per cent of clients had not been asked for feedback about the usefulness of elements of their return to work plan in finding them employment. Again, neglecting to get information and failing to inform clients of a key element of the program begs the question: how serious is the minister about the duties of his department?

Only 43 per cent of clients in employment or studying at the time of the survey indicated that they had received post-placement support—and this support is supposed to help clients in their transition to employment or study. Given that the people who are receiving case management are the long-term unemployed, you would think that this ought to be the group who are receiving 100 per cent support in transition. Coming back into the work force after a two-year or more gap—possibly after retraining—would entail an enormous amount of readjustment.

One of the most damning findings in the Auditor-General's report was the suggestion that, while most clients were satisfied with the length and type of contact, 30 per cent—almost one-third—of clients who had visits or personal contact did not believe that contact with the CES was useful. For such a large minority to be unhappy with this system indicates that there are some serious problems. This negative perception by clients is an indictment of the efficacy of the whole program.

The bill also makes provision for ESRA to purchase goods and services on a credit card. I reiterate the concerns expressed by Dr Kemp in the other place regarding the provision of this credit card to the chair of ESRA, who is presently Mrs Joan Kirner, the former Premier of Victoria. Last week in the other place Mr Peter Costello revealed in an answer to a question on notice that Mrs Kirner used her position as the chair of ESRA to fly to Perth for a board meeting which surprisingly coincided with the appearance of her federal colleague, Dr Carmen Lawrence, at the Marks royal commission.

While in Perth, Mrs Kirner not only attended the Marks royal commission but addressed a Labor women's forum where she called on the audience to `stand shoulder to shoulder with Carmen Lawrence as she takes the witness stand'. On one of the four evenings she spent in Perth Mrs Kirner was also interviewed by Paul Lyneham on the 7.30 Report, where she defended Dr Lawrence—all this in a four-day visit to Perth for the purpose of conducting ESRA business. Needless to say, given this highly questionable use of taxpayers' money in her capacity as chair of ESRA, the coalition will continue to monitor closely the way in which the ESRA credit card is used. This bill also makes provision for CES registration for seasonal and part-time workers who choose not to remain in case management. This issue of case management flexibility was highlighted in the recent report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into long-term unemployment. Recommendation No. 1 of that report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee recommends that mature age workers—
that is, 35 years and over—
who become unemployed be eligible to access labour market programs within three months of becoming unemployed.
Many mature workers feel that early intervention is essential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to continue a series of speeches on the disastrous state facing this nation and the impact that long-term unemployment is having on Australia. It is very timely that I do this in light of Senator Troeth's comments in that recent debate. In some ways what I am saying may seem like a continuation of her comments relating to some of the failures of Working Nation. I want to focus on this tonight, because our Senate committee held hearings right across Australia over a three-month period and scrutinised exactly how the so-called Working Nation program was working—or, to be more precise, how it was not working.

PARA.TAB: In the matters of public interest debate last week I focused on evidence given to the committee that highlighted the voice of despair of the long-term unemployed—people who felt abandoned by this government and the system that has been set up by its Department of Employment, Education and Training; mature aged people who felt that they were only qualified now to be on the scrap heap of life; youth who were giving up and slipping between the cracks in our society; children who were living in families where no-one was working—and the health effects on the long-term unemployed and their families, particularly their children, who, as I outlined last week, were beset with a greater amount of chronic illness.

Tonight I want to focus on the stark evidence that reveals how this so-called ALP Working Nation program is not working. The program was set up to solve the problems of the long-term unemployed, and the evidence we gathered around the country showed again and again across the regions of Australia how it was not working. The government is creating a situation where the long-term unemployed are becoming increasingly entrenched as part of the Australian landscape.

This government likes to talk about its so-called Working Nation program in dollar terms. It will boast that it has spent $2.2 billion on Working Nation. However, when all the rhetoric is laid aside, the government cannot escape the simple disgraceful fact that 8.7 per cent of the Australian work force remains on the official unemployment list. That does not include the unofficial list of people who have just given up or who are underemployed. Even on the government's own shonky figures, there are still 760,000 Australians without work. Of that number, one-third are long-term unemployed.

Labor's recent document on labour market programs, Shaping our Nation, boasts that Australia is leading the OECD nations in the generation of new jobs. This is just a nonsense claim. The incidence of long-term unemployment in the country is near 30 per cent, and this was much worse than comparable OECD countries. By comparison, in Japan it is 15 per cent and in the US it is 12 per cent. So the Keating government's claim that Working Nation programs are having a significant impact is just not true.

The evidence provided to our committee showed the scale and the dimension of the long-term unemployment problem—the striking increases in long-term unemployment from 4.5 per cent in the mid-1970s to almost 40 per cent in 1993 at the height of the recession. The main victims of long-term unemployment are the young and the mature aged. Our Senate committee did a major study on youth unemployment two years ago, which to this government's great shame it virtually ignored. In this recent report on long-term unemployment we focused on the mature aged.

The youth unemployment that they ignored is still rife in our society. In parts of regional New South Wales it has reached 38 per cent and in the Hunter it is rising to 50 per cent on the far north coast. The long-term unemployment report says that over half—56 per cent—of unemployed males over 55 years were unemployed for 52 weeks or more, as were 53 per cent of males aged 45 to 54. The mature aged are unwanted and unhelped by Labor's so-called world-class labour market programs.

As we moved around the country and as we heard from these people, as they came before us and told us their story, not only of losing their jobs but of the total frustration and demoralisation that occurred when they tried to access this Labor government's labour market programs, it showed the stark reality of the failure of Working Nation to us. We found this particularly in regional areas, where this government does not seem to have made enough leeway for the regional differences in the programs that might work in some regions and not in others. At page 58 of the report it says:

SPEECH.PARA: We had aggregate national figures showing economic growth that was regarded as too high for some, so as a very blunt instrument, interest rates was used to dampen demand. . . That might be fine in parts of Queensland and Western Australia, where growth was up to 11 per cent. But in the western and northern suburbs of Adelaide, for example, we still have a regional recession.

It is this lack of flexibility in the Labor government's programs that shows how regional Australia misses out. The focus is not on what is needed in those areas. The dimensions of the long-term unemployment problem present a massive task to put everyone back to work. We heard evidence that, with a million unemployed, to get everyone back to work we will have to create the equivalent of 20 entire BHPs or 50,000 to 100,000 small businesses Australia-wide. That is the scope of what we are facing. To have the government coming up with a program that creates training that does not lead to work and where dole queues are constantly churned is not the answer to put people into long-term work. The scale of what is required to create new employment to absorb these people is shown by the figures I indicated in the numbers of small businesses and big businesses needed to take up this sort of slack.

PARA.TAB: Working Nation is a cover-up to hide the dimensions of long-term unemployment in this country. It brings together the numbers of people on long-term unemployment training schemes and those with short-term subsidised jobs and places in the them in the same category as those who have gained unsubsidised employment. This is dishonest, skews the outcome of a Working Nation initiative and shows what a cover-up it is when they do those sorts of combinations. I reject as dishonest the notion that the placement of long-term unemployed in subsidised work or formal training justifies their removal from the official unemployment figures.

As we moved around the country we found a number of other major criticisms. One of the main ones focused on training that was not leading anywhere. In Whyalla people are sick and tired of training for the sake of it, they told us. They are disillusioned with training programs that get them nowhere. There was a report of the mismatch between jobs and talent. Training in the absence of real jobs is pointless, and evidence on page 80 of the report underlines this. Too often there is a mismatch between the training offered, which must be accepted or benefits are forfeited, and the talents and abilities of the long-term unemployed and the local employment opportunities.

Training is often used just as a time filler in some regional areas and to reduce the unemployment statistics. The perception of many older long-term unemployed in regional areas with high structural unemployment is that no amount of training will make a difference and that these DEET programs are indeed time fillers. We have evidence of the churning of the dole queue in this situation. The unemployed and the professionals in the labour market program delivery express the view that labour market programs are merely recycling unemployed people. This was highlighted at page 81 of the Senate report. I quote—(Time expired)

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Vietnam: Visit of Mr Do Muoi

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) In what capacity has Mr Do Muoi been invited to Australia.
(2) Has Mr Do Muoi been invited as Viet Communist Party (VCP) Chief or as an official Head of State.
(3) By inviting Mr Do Muoi, has the Government confirmed that the monopoly and anti-democratic VCP is the right, acceptable and official governing body of the 74 million people in Vietnam.
(4) How much of the taxpayers money is being spent on Mr Do Muoi's visit to Australia.
(5) What is the itinerary for Mr Do Muoi's visit.
(6) Will the Department be organising a meeting between Mr Do Muoi and members of the Vietnamese community in Australia.
(7) Will the Minister be meeting with members and leaders of the Vietnamese community to hear their views on Mr Do Muoi's visit prior to his visit.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) Mr Do Muoi was invited to visit Australia as Secretary General of the Communist Party of Vietnam. The invitation for Mr Muoi to visit can be compared to that for the visit to Australia in 1985 of the General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, Mr Hu Yaobang.

(3) The Vietnamese Constitution stipulates that Vietnam is a one party State. In this system, the Communist Party and the Government are indistinguishable. As leader of the Communist Party, Mr Do Muoi is the most influential figure in the development of Vietnam's domestic and international policies. Australia recognises states rather than their governments. It follows that we do not take a formal position on the body which governs Vietnam (or any other country).

(4) Mr Do Muoi was accorded Head of Government status during his visit to Australia. In accordance with standard practice, the Government met internal costs for some members of his delegation during their stay in Australia. The total cost to the Commonwealth of the visit, as calculated by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet based on advice from relevant departments, was $337,512. The delegation travelled to and from Australia at the Vietnamese Government's expense.
(5) The itinerary focused on major industrial centres in NSW, Victoria and Queensland, and on meetings with the Federal and State Governments and Australian companies.
(6) Neither Mr Muoi nor the Vietnamese community sought the Australian Government's assistance in arranging such a meeting.

(7) The Prime Minister met with Vietnamese community leaders prior to Mr Muoi's visit. Representatives of my Department, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs met leaders of the Vietnamese community prior to the visit to hear their views.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 26 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: Why is there a delay in the implementation of the national Hepatitis C action plan relating to the availability of treatment in the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The National Hepatitis C Action Plan which identifies key activities to be undertaken in relation to four priority areas of: epidemiology and surveillance; hepatitis C testing; clinical management and treatment; and education and prevention, was endorsed by the Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council (AHMAC) in October 1994.

In endorsing the Action Plan, States and Territories agreed to fund and implement their own responsibilities under the National Hepatitis C Action Plan which includes clinical treatment for hepatitis C.

Funding of $3.8 million over a two year period was allocated in the 1995/96 Federal Budget to allow the Commonwealth to implement its responsibilities under the Action Plan in relation to national education and improving national surveillance activities.

In accordance with the recommendations of the Action Plan, the Commonwealth has also taken steps to improve the quality of hepatitis C testing under the Therapeutic Goods Act, and has provided support for the development of guidelines for the detection and management of hepatitis C currently being prepared by the NHMRC.
In relation to treatment for patients with chronic hepatitis C, in September 1994, I approved the use of interferon as a Section 100 pharmaceutical benefit under the National Health Act 1953.
The Commonwealth is subsidising funding of interferon available under Section 100 and this is estimated to have cost $3.8 million in 1994-95 and $5.3 million in 1995-96.

The Commonwealth has an agreement with the States and Territories to fund the use of interferon in the treatment of eligible out-patients assessed in accordance with the criteria specified by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee.

In administering this treatment, each jurisdiction has been required to register approved centres for interferon treatment. It is a requirement of each treatment centre to provide reports on individual patients receiving treatment to the National Interferon Data Base administered by the Australian Gastroenterology Society. This Data Base began in October 1994 and currently has 724 patients receiving treatment and over 2000 follow-up reports.

I am advised that the ACT currently has one hospital registered as an approved interferon treatment centre, however, due to the lack of funds provided by the ACT Government, there are currently no clinical resources available to deliver and monitor the treatment. I understand that the ACT Government is currently working on a solution to address this problem.

Further issues surrounding the provision of clinical services and approval of treatment centres to allow interferon treatment for people with hepatitis C in the ACT should be referred to the ACT Minister for Health.

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Does the department have a target or targets for the number of its employees (including agency board and other consultative committees' members) who are: (i) overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background, (iii) can speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) if so, can details be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Finance has targets in relation to its number of employees (including agency board and other consultative committees' members) who are: (i) overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background, (iii) can speak one or more languages other than English. These targets are consistent with the Australian Public Service wide targets as articulated in the Equal Employment Opportunity Strategic Plan for the Australian Public Service for the 1990's. This target is to increase the number of these people to 15% of Australian Public Service employment by the year 2000. The Department of Finance Equal Employment Opportunity Program for 1993-1996, contains several strategies to achieve this target.

(2) In the 1993-94 financial year 99 employees identified as being from a non-English speaking background. This represents 11% of total staff members. In the 1994-95 financial year 103 employees identified as being from a non-English speaking background. This represents 11% of total staff members. The Department records data on staff from non-English speaking backgrounds but does not formally record data on the number of staff who were born overseas or able to speak one or more languages other than English.

(3) No members of Finance's advisory bodies and panels, agency boards, consultative committees and other tribunals or councils, in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years identified as being from a non-English speaking background.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 3 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Does the department have a target or targets for the number of its employees (including agency board and other consultative committees' members) who are: (i) overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background, (iii) can speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) if so, can details be provided.

(2)(a) How many employees of the department in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years: (i) were overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking background, (iii) able to speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) what percentages of total employment do the above numbers represent.

(3)(a) How many members of your department's advisory bodies and panels, agency boards, consultative committees and other tribunals or councils, in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years: (i) were overseas born, (ii) of non-English speaking backgrounds, (iii) able to speak one or more languages other than English; and (b) what percentages of total members do the above numbers represent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) and (b)(i) The Department does not have a target for the number of its employees who are overseas born per se, however, it has a target for the number of employees of non-English speaking background in the context of its Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Program. This EEO group includes employees born overseas of non-English speaking background. The target, expressed as a percentage of total staff in the Department's EEO Program 1995-1998, is for non-English speaking staff representation to increase to 30%, (ii) Yes, the Department's target for the number of its employees who are of non-English speaking background is set under its EEO Program 1995-1998 at 30% of total staff numbers, (iii) The Department does not

ANSWER.PARA: have a target for the number of its employees who can speak one or more languages other than English, however, the Department encourages employees to acquire and maintain languages other than English through the provision of studies assistance, specific training programs for employees posted overseas and the payment of the Linguistic and Performance Allowance to employees required to use language skills in the performance of their duties.
