TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 17 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) What is the Federal Government's position on the contribution of funds towards preserving the coastal lowland forest habitat of the mahogany glider in the Ingham and Tully areas; and (b) how much funding will be allocated and under which program.

(2) Will the Federal Government's assistance involve purchasing properties; if so: (a) identify the properties; (b) their location; (c) owners; (d) dollar value; and (e) their significance to the mahogany glider; if not, then in what way will the funding assist in the preservation of these habitats.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) On 20 October 1995, together with the Queensland Minister for Environment and Heritage, the Hon Tom Barton MLA, I announced that the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments would jointly fund a rescue package totalling $16 million to protect the endangered mahogany glider and other unique flora and fauna along the Queensland coastline.

(b) The Commonwealth contribution to the package is $8 million. Administrative arrangements for the package are being developed between the respective Commonwealth and Queensland Government Departments.

(2) The package will involve the acquisition of fifteen freehold and three leasehold properties, totalling some 38,000 hectares. In addition, the package provides for the financial incentives for landholders to enter into voluntary conservation agreements for a further area of approximately 5,000 hectares.

(a),(b),(c) and (d) Negotiations are proceeding with the individual land and leaseholders regarding the acquisition of properties. Full details on the individual acquisitions will not be available until these negotiations have been completed.
(e) The areas to be acquired will ensure the continued protection of the four remaining significant mahogany glider habitats.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 19 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that benzene, an additive to unleaded petrol, is a known carcinogen.

(2) Is the Government aware that the National Society for Clean Air in the United Kingdom has removed their support for unleaded petrol and that, in the United States, all new cars are fitted with anti-fume filters so that the fumes emitted whilst refuelling are kept away from the person doing the refuelling.

(3) In light of concerns about the problems associated with the additive benzene to unleaded petrol, what is the Australian Government doing to protect the health of Australians, particularly since there is a price discrimination against leaded fuels.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, benzene is a known carcinogen. Benzene is not added to unleaded petrol in Australia. It is a normal constituent in all petrol.

(2) Yes. Unleaded petrol in the UK is quite different from unleaded petrol in Australia. Anti fume filters (carbon canisters), to reduce evaporative emissions from the fuel system are also standard equipment in Australian cars.

(3) Australian Standard 1876 (Petrol for motor vehicles) restricts benzene to 5% by volume. The benzene content of leaded and regular unleaded petrol in Australia is essentially the same and averages approximately 2.6% by volume. Premium unleaded petrol has a slightly higher benzene content than regular unleaded petrol (approximately 3.6%). It accounts for approximately 1.5% of the market and retails for 10c per litre more than regular unleaded petrol. Emissions of benzene from vehicles not fitted with catalytic converters using either leaded or regular unleaded petrol are also essentially the same.

Since 1986 all new cars sold in Australia must operate on unleaded petrol and are almost exclusively fitted with catalytic converters. Catalytic converters substantially reduce benzene emissions from vehicle exhaust.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre in Townsville may be forced to close by the end of November 1995 due to financial difficulties.
(2) Is it a fact that the centre currently provides places for 51 children, with another 27 on the waiting list for places.

(3) Is it a fact that the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre is the only department child care centre which is not located on a Defence base and has to pay its own utilities bills, including electricity, water and telephone.

(4)(a) Is it a fact that the department has acknowledged responsibility for the centre's utilities bills, but has so far refused to pay them; (b) why has no payment been made for the centre's utilities bills; and (c) when will payment be made.
(5) Why has no increased funding been made available to the centre to reflect the increase in the number of child care places from 41 to 51 since its opening.
(6) Is it a fact that the centre, in its current funding circumstances, will be unable to provide the equipment required to have its licence renewed following an upcoming review in January.

(7) What was the reason for the provision of an Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff child care grant to the child care centre at Holsworthy for a third year, when the Defence Child Care Centre Guidelines state that such a grant is only available for the first two years of a centre's operations.
(8) Will a similar grant be made available again to the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre.
(9) What action has been taken by the department and local Australian Defence Force commanders to address the financial difficulties being encountered by the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre.

(10) Is it a fact that, if the current financial difficulties force the closure to the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre, displaced children of Defence personnel will be forced to wait for up to two years for places at other non-Defence child care centres in Townsville.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre in Townsville will not be forced to close due to financial difficulties. Funding has been authorised which will ensure the financial viability of the centre.

(2) The Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre provides places for 51 children at the present time. There are currently 30 children on the waiting list; this reflects the fact that inquiries about child care places are at a peak over the October—December period, when Army families are preparing to move to Townsville and are making arrangements for housing and child care.

(3) The Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre is not the only Defence child care centre not located on a Defence base. The payment of utilities bills, including water, electricity and telephone, is authorised by the local commander in accordance with Defence policy guidelines. Generally, this would involve the establishment of an agreement between the child care centre and the local commander. In the case of the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre, an agreement with the local commander was not established; consequently there was no visibility of the costs associated with the Centre, and funding provision was not made. This matter has now been addressed, and the local commander has determined that all utilities costs will be paid by Defence.

(4)(a) and (b) The issue of responsibility for the centre's utilities bills has not arisen previously, as the bills were paid by the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre Management Committee as they arose.

(c) As a determination has now been made within Defence policy guidelines contained in Defence Instruction (General) Administration 35-1 that the centre is eligible to have its utilities costs met by Defence, funds already expended by the centre's Management Committee on utilities bills will be reimbursed. Reimbursement is being effected now.

(5) Under the Defence Employer Sponsored Child Care Program, operational funding is provided by the office of the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff (ADFILS). Operational funding is based on a formula which allows funding to be allocated on the basis of $1,000 per licensed place per year. Funding is provided in quarterly instalments in advance. The Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre commenced operations in Townsville in January 1994 as a 44 place centre. It was therefore eligible for operational funding of $44,000 per annum. In October 1994, the centre advised ADFILS that it had increased its number of licensed places to 51. Accordingly, in April 1995 its operational funding was increased to $51,000.

(6) A request for additional equipment funding to allow the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre to meet the January 1996 licensing inspection requirement was made to the Army during October 1995. This request has been processed, and the local commander has been authorised to assist with the equipment purchases. This will allow the centre to meet the licensing inspection requirement.

(7) The Defence Child Care Guidelines state that an operational subsidy of up to $1,000 per annum for each licensed place will be issued in quarterly instalments for the first two years of operation. The Guidelines also state that child care services must be economically viable, and fee structures must be geared to cost recovery. When the Defence Child Care Guidelines were developed, it was envisaged that the employer-sponsored child care centres would be able to operate on a self-sufficient basis after the first two years. It is now recognised that this may not be achievable for reasons including the extended hours of operation of the centres, the high number of places for babies, the centres' ineligibility for sales tax exemptions, and the effect of posting cycles on enrolments. These difficulties have been recognised by Defence, and a decision was taken in November 1993 that operational funding for Defence Employer Sponsored Child Care centres would be provided on the basis of $1,000 per annum per licensed place for two years, and thereafter would be subject to need with the level of subsidy reducing as centres approach self-sufficiency.

(8) The Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre, as with all Defence Employer Sponsored Child Care centres, will continue to receive operational funding beyond the first two years, in accordance with the policy outlined above.

(9) Liaison officers and advisers have worked closely with the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre Management Committee to provide assistance, particularly in relation to ensuring continuing provision of funding from Defence. The local Army commander has tasked a senior military officer to work closely with the centre's Management Committee to assist with establishing and maintaining visibility of the Centre's financial position. In addition, local commanders from both the Army and the Air Force provide staff support, advice and financial support (within Departmental guidelines) with the intention of ensuring a viable and sustainable child care centre for the Defence community in Townsville.
(10) The Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre will not be forced to close, therefore children of Defence personnel will not be displaced.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the postmark for Australia Post's first day cover of an issue released on 12 October 1995 include the words "Christmas Island WA 6798".
(2) Is Christmas Island part of Western Australia; if not, why did the official postmark on 12 October 1995 imply that it is.
(3) When did Christmas Island postage stamps become valid for postage in Australia.

(4) How many official postmarks have been used by Australia Post for Christmas Island stamp issues since then and, of these, which bore the initials "WA" or in any way suggested that Christmas Island was part of Western Australia.
(5) Will future postmarks for official first day covers carry the initials "WA" or in any other way suggest that the Island is part of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on information provided by Australia Post:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The postmark for the Marine Life issue on 12 October 1995 included the words "Christmas Island WA 6798", rather than "Christmas Island 6798."

(2) No. The initials "WA" were inadvertently included in the postmark and, unfortunately, the mistake was not picked-up in subsequent checking procedures. It should be noted that for all other postmarks, the inclusions of an Australian State is mandatory (except for the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, for which the abbreviations ACT and NT are required).

(3) On 2 March 1993, following amendments to the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989, Australia Post took over postal and philatelic services on Christmas Island. The stamps of Christmas Island issued after that date are valid for postage throughout Australia, and Australian stamps are valid for postal use on the Island. To denote their new status, "Australia" has been substituted for "Indian Ocean" on Christmas Island stamps.

(4) Since March 1993, a total of 13 first day of issue postmarks have been used by Australia Post for Christmas Island stamp issues. The postmark for the Marine Life issue on 12 October 1995 was the only postmark that included the initials "WA".
(5) No. Australia Post regrets the mistake and has advised that there was no intention on its part to imply that Christmas Island is part of Western Australia.
